quotation: A bove majori discit arare minor.
translation: The young ox learns to plough from the older
notes: See Ne sus, &c.

quotation: A capite ad calcem.
translation: From top to toe

quotation: Aera nitent usu; vestis bona quaerit haberi; Canescunt turpi tecta relicta situ.
translation: Brass grows bright by use; good clothes require to be worn; uninhabited buildings grow white with nasty mould.

quotation: Aerugo animi, rubigo ingenii.
translation: The rust of the mind is the blight of genius.
notes: Said of idleness.

quotation: Amicum ita habeas posse ut fieri hunc inimicum scias.
translation: Live with your friend as if you knew that he might become your enemy.
notes: This maxim, though inculcating caution, a considerable virtue, is better adapted to the political world than to the sphere of private friendship. See Ama tanquam, &c.

quotation: Amicum Mancipium domino et frugi.
translation: A servant faithful to his master, and true.

quotation: Accidit in puncto, et toto contingit in anno.
translation: It happens in an instant, and occurs throughout the whole year.
notes: Said in reference to those occurrences which are ruled by the uniform laws of nature.

quotation: A fonte puro pura defluit aqua.
translation: From a clear spring clear water flows
notes: A man is generally estimated by the company he keeps, as his habits are probably similar to those of his companions.

quotation: Accidit in puncto, quod non contingit in anno.
translation: That may happen in a moment, which does not occur in a whole year.

quotation: A fortiori.
translation: From stronger reasoning
notes: With much greater probability. If a pound of gunpowder can blow up a house, a fortiori a hundredweight must be able to do it.

quotation: A fronte praecipitium, a tergo lupus.
translation: A precipice before, a wolf behind
notes: Said of a person between the horns of a dilemma.

quotation: A latere.
translation: From the side
notes: A legate a latere is a pope's envoy, so called because sent from his side, from among his counsellors.

quotation: A mensa et toro.
translation: From table and bed
notes: or, as we say, "from bed and board." A sentence of separation of man and wife, issuing from the ecclesiastical courts, on account of acts of adultery which have been substantiated against either party. It is not of so decisive a nature as the divorce A vinculo matrimonii; which see.

quotation: A posteriori.
translation: From the latter

quotation: A priori.
translation: From the former
notes: Phrases used in logical argument, to denote a reference to its different modes. The schoolmen distinguished them into the propter quod, wherein an effect is proved from the next cause, as, when it is proved that the moon is eclipsed, because the earth is then between the sun and the moon. The second is, the quia, wherein the cause is proved from a remote effect; as, that plants do not breathe, because they are not animals; or, that there is a God, from the works of the creation. The former argument is called demonstration a priori; the latter, demonstration a posteriori.

quotation: A re decedunt.
translation: They wander from the point

quotation: Aerumnabilis experientia me docuit.
translation: Sorrowful experience has taught me.

quotation: A teneris unguiculis.
translation: From your tender little nails (From your very earliest boyhood)
notes: From your very earliest boyhood. See Sed praesta, &c., and Amores de, &c.

quotation: Accipe nunc, victus tenuis quid quantaque secum afferat. In primis valeas bene.
translation: Now learn what and how great benefits a temperate diet will bring along with it. In the first place, you will enjoy good health.

quotation: Aes debitorem leve, gravius inimicum facit.
translation: A trifling debt makes a man your debtor; a more weighty one, your enemy.

quotation: Accipe, si vis, Accipiam tabulas; detur nobis locus, hora, Custodes: videamus uter plus scribere possit.
translation: Take, if you like, your tablets, I will take mine: let there be a place, a time, and persons appointed to see fair play; let us see who can write the most.

quotation: A verbis legis non est recedendum.
translation: There must be no departure from the words of the law
notes: The judge must not give to a statute a forced interpretation contrary to the reasonable meaning of the words.

quotation: Aes erat in pretio; chalybeia massa latebat; Heu! quam perpetuo debuit illa tegi.
translation: Copper became valuable; the iron ore still lay hid. Alas! would that it had ever remained concealed.

quotation: Accipe, sume, cape, sunt verba placentia papae.
translation: Take, have, and keep, are pleasant words from a pope.
notes: It may also be translated, "to a pope."

quotation: Aesopo ingentem statuam posuere Attici, Servumque collocarunt aeterna in basi, Patere honoris scirent ut cuncti viam.
translation: The Athenians erected a lofty statue to Aesop, and placed him, though a slave, upon an everlasting pedestal, that all might know that the way to fame is open to every one.

quotation: Amicum perdere est demnorum maximum.
translation: To lose a friend is the greatest of losses.

quotation: A vinculo matrimonii.
translation: From the bonds of matrimony
notes: See A mensa, &c.

quotation: Aestimatio delicti praeteriti ex post facto non crescit.
translation: The delinquency attaching to a crime that has been committed, is not increased by anything that has happened since.

quotation: Ab actu ad posse valet illatio.
translation: From what has happened we may infer what will happen

quotation: Ab alio spectes alteri quod feceris.
translation: As you do to another, expect another to do to you

quotation: Ab amicis honesta petamus.
translation: We must ask what is proper from our friends

quotation: Ab honesto virum bonum nihil deterret.
translation: Nothing deters a good man from the performance of his duties

quotation: Ab inconvenienti.
translation: From the inconvenience
notes: The Argumentum ab inconvenienti, is an argument to show that a proposition will be unlikely to meet the expected end, and will therefore be inexpedient.

quotation: Amicus certus in re incerta cernitur.
translation: An undoubted friend shows himself in doubtful circumstances.
notes: Very similar to our proverb, "A friend in need is a friend indeed."

quotation: Amicus curiae.
translation: A friend of the court.
notes: A member of the bar who makes a suggestion on any point of practice as to which the judge is in doubt is so called.

quotation: Aestuat ingens Imo in corde pudor, mixtoque insania luctu, Et Furiis agitatus amor, et conscia virtus.
translation: Deep in his heart boils overwhelming shame, and frantic rage, with intermingled grief, and love racked with furious despair, and conscious worth.

quotation: Amicus magis necessarius quam ignis aut aqua.
translation: A friend is more needful than fire or water.

quotation: Aetas parentum, pejor avie, tulit Nos nequiores, mox daturos Progeniem vitiosiorem.
translation: The days of our parents, more dissolute than those of our forefathers, produced us more wicked than they; we, who are destined to produce a more vicious progeny still.
notes: Horace is here a laudator temporis acti, a praiser of the "good old times."

quotation: Amicus Plato, amicus Socrates, sed magis amica veritas.
translation: Plato is my friend, Socrates is my friend, but truth is a friend I prize above both.

quotation: Aetatem non tegunt tempora.
translation: Our temples do not conceal our age.
notes: The wrinkled forehead betrays the hand of time

quotation: Aetatem Priami Nestorisque Longam qui putat esse, Martiane, Multum decipitur falliturque, Non est. vivere sed vita.
translation: He, Martianus, is much mistaken and deceived, who thinks that the life of Priam and of Nestor was long: not existence, but health, is life.

quotation: Amicus usque ad aras.
translation: A friend to the very altar.

quotation: Aetatis cujusque notandi sunt tibi mores.
translation: You must carefully observe the manners of every age.
notes: By inattention to this rule, even Shakespeare has committed anachronisms.

quotation: Aeternum inter se discordant.
translation: They are everlastingly at variance with each other.

quotation: Aethiopem dealbare.
translation: To wash a blackamoor white.

quotation: Amissum quod nescitur non amittitur.
translation: The loss that is not known is no loss.
notes: "What the eye don't see the heart don't grieve." So also Gray's line, "Where ignorance is bliss 'tis folly to be wise."

quotation: Aevo rarissima nostro Simplicitas.
translation: Simplicity, a thing most rare in our age.
notes: Ovid, like Seneca, sometimes praises a simplicity and self-denial, which he himself failed to practise.

quotation: Amittit merito proprium qui alienum appetit.
translation: He who covets that which belongs to another, deservedly loses his own." Covetous men not unfrequently fall into the pit which they have dug for others."

quotation: Affectum dantis pensat censura Tonantis.
translation: The judgment of the Thunderer weighs the intention of the giver.
notes: A mediaeval line.

quotation: Amor omnibus idem.
translation: Love is in all the same.

quotation: Afflavit Deus et dissipantur.
translation: God has sent forth his breath, and they are dispersed.
notes: In the reign of Queen Elizabeth, a medal with the above inscription was struck, to record the destruction of the Spanish Armada.

quotation: Amor et melle et felle est fecundissimus.
translation: Love is most fruitful both in honey and in gall.

quotation: Amor tussisque non celantur.
translation: Love and a cough cannot bo concealed.
notes: A proverbial saying.

quotation: Amore nihil mollius, nihil violentius.
translation: Nothing is more tender, nothing more violent than love.

quotation: Amores De tenero meditatur ungui.
translation: She plans amours from her tenderest years.

quotation: Amoto quaeramus seria ludo.
translation: Joking apart, let us give our attention to serious matters.

quotation: Amphora coepit Institui: currente rota cur urceus exit?
translation: A fine jar is intended to be made; why, when the wheel goes round, does it come out a humble pitcher?
notes: A figure taken from the potter's wheel. It has the same application as the Fable of the Mountain in Labour.

quotation: Ampliat aetatis spatium sibi vir bonus; hoc est Vivere bis vita posse priore frui.
translation: The good man extends the period of his life; it is to live twice, to enjoy with satisfaction the retrospect of our past life.

quotation: Accipere quam facere praestat injuriam.
translation: It is better to receive than to do an injury.

quotation: Accipio revocamen.
translation: I accept the recall.

quotation: Ab initio.
translation: From the beginning

quotation: Ab ovo usque ad mala.
translation: From the egg to the apples (from beginning to end)
notes: From the commencement to the end; eggs being the first, and apples the last, dish served at the Roman entertainments.

quotation: Ab Urbe condita.
translation: From the building of the city
notes: more usually denoted in the Latin writers by the initials A. U. C; Rome, B.C. 753.

quotation: Abeunt studia in mores.
translation: Pursuits become habits
notes: Use is second nature.

quotation: Abi in pace.
translation: Depart in peace

quotation: Abiit nemine salutato.
translation: He went away without bidding any one farewell

quotation: Abite nummi, ego vos mergam, ne mergar a vobis.
translation: Away with you, money, I will sink you, that I may not be sunk by you.

quotation: Abiturus illuc quo priores abierunt, Quid mente caeca miserum torques Tibi dico, avare spiritum?
translation: As you must go to that place to which others have gone before, why in the blindness of your mind do you torment your wretched existence? To you I address myself, miser

quotation: Abnormis sapiens.
translation: Wise without instruction
notes: Naturally gifted with a sound understanding.

quotation: Abracadabra.
notes: A cabalistic word, the name of a deity formerly worshipped by the Syrians. The letters of his name, written on paper, in the form of an inverted triangle, were recommended as an antidote against various diseases.

quotation: Age, libertate Decembri, Quando ita majores voluerunt, utere.
translation: Come, since our forefathers would have it so, use the freedom of December.
notes: Said in allusion to the Saturnalia, during which the slaves at Rome were allowed a greater latitude than usual.

quotation: Absens haeres non erit.
translation: He who is at a distance will not be the heir
notes: Out of sight out of mind

quotation: Absentem laedit cum ebrio qui litigat.
translation: He who disputes with a drunken man, offends one who is absent
notes: The senses of a drunken man may be considered as absent.

quotation: Age quod agis.
translation: Attend to what you are about.
notes: or, as the clock at the Inner Temple formerly had it, "Begone about your business."

quotation: Absentem qui rodit amicum, qui non defendit alio culpante; solutos qui captat risus hominum, famamque dicacis; Fingere qui non visa potest, commissa tacere qui nequit, hic niger est, hunc tu, Romane, caveto.
translation: He who backbites an absent friend, who does not defend him when another censures him, who affects to raise loud laughs in company and the reputation of a funny fellow, who can feign things he never saw, who cannot keep secrets, he is a dangerous man; against him, Roman, be on your guard

quotation: Agere considerate pluris est quam cogitare prudenter.
translation: It is better to act considerately than to think wisely.
notes: Very similar in meaning to the maxim, Paulum sepultae, &c, which see

quotation: Absque argento omnia vana.
translation: Without money all is in vain.

quotation: Agnosco veteris vestigia flammae.
translation: I recognise the remains of my former attachment.
notes: A somewhat similar expression to that of Gray, "E'en in our ashes live their wonted fires."

quotation: Absque hoc.
translation: Without this, ...
notes: &c. The technical words of exception used in pleading a traverse.

quotation: Agnus Dei.
translation: The Lamb of God.
notes: A cake of wax stamped with the figure supporting the banner of the cross. It is supposed by the Romish Church to have miraculous powers for preserving the faithful. A part of the mass for the dead is also so called, from the circumstance of its beginning with these words.

quotation: Absque sudore et labore nullum opus perfectum est.
translation: Without sweat and toil no work is made perfect.
notes: Without exertion and diligence success is rarely attained.

quotation: Agricola incurvo terram dimorit aratro; Hinc anni labor; hinc patriam parvosque nepotes Sustinet: hinc armenta boum, meritosque juvencos.
translation: The husbandman cleaves the earth with his crooked plough: hence the labours of the year: hence he supports his country and his little offspring: hence his herds of kine and the steers which have earned his sustenance.

quotation: Absque tali causa.
translation: Without such cause.

quotation: Agri non omnes frugiferi sunt.
translation: All fields are not fruitful.
notes: So too all men are not equally susceptible of improvement.

quotation: Abstineto a fabis.
translation: Abstain from beans.
notes: The Athenians, at the election of their public magistrates, balloted with beans. It is also worthy of remark that the Pythagoreans had a superstitious belief that the souls of the dead were harboured in the centre of the bean.

quotation: Ah miser! Quanta laboras in Charybdi, Digne puer meliore flamma!
translation: Into what an abyss hast thou fallen, unhappy youth! deserving of a more happy flame!
notes: A parallel case to that of Samson and Delilah.

quotation: Absurdum est ut alios regat, qui seipsum regere nescit.
translation: It is absurd that he should govern others, who knows not how to govern himself.
notes: Quoted by Kabelais, B. i. c. 52.

quotation: Ah! nimium faciles, qui tristia crimina caedis Fluminea tolli posse putetis aqua.
translation: Ah! too credulous mortals, who imagine that the guilt of bloodshed can be removed by the waters of the stream.

quotation: Albae gallinae filius.
translation: The son of a white hen.
notes: Said of a person extremely fortunate. An eagle is said to have dropped a white hen, with a sprig of laurel, into the lap of Livia, the wife of the Emperor Augustus.

quotation: Album calculum addere.
translation: To give a white stone.
notes: In voting, among the ancients, approval was signified by putting into the urn a white stone; disapproval, or censure, by a black one.

quotation: Alea judiciorum.
translation: Chance judiciary.
notes: The uncertainty of judgments;" which too often, as it were, depend on the throw of a die. "The glorious uncertainty of the law."

quotation: Aleator, quanto in arte est melior, tanto est nequior.
translation: The gambler, the more skilful he is in his art, the more wicked is he.

quotation: Abundans cautela non nocet.
translation: Excess of precaution can do no harm.

quotation: Alexander victor tot regum atque populorum irae succubuit.
translation: Alexander, the conqueror of so many kings and nations, was himself subdued by anger.

quotation: Abundat dulcibus vitiis.
translation: He abounds with alluring faults.
notes: Said in allusion to an author the very faults of whose style are fascinating.

quotation: Aliam quercum excute.
translation: Go, shake some other oak.
notes: Said by a person who has already shown his liberality to an applicant.

quotation: Ac veluti magno in populo cum saepe coorta est Seditio; saevitque animis ignobile vulgus, Jamque faces et saxa volant, furor arma ministrat.
translation: And as when a sedition has arisen amongst a mighty multitude, as often happens, and the minds of the ignoble vulgar are excited; now stones, now firebrands fly; fury supplies arms.

quotation: Alia res sceptrum, alia plectrum.
translation: A sceptre is one thing, a fiddlestick another.

quotation: Accedas ad curiam.
translation: You may come to the court.
notes: A writ issued out of Chancery when a man had received false judgment in a hundred court or court baron, was so called.

quotation: Alias.
translation: Otherwise.
notes: Applied to persons who assume two or more names; as A, alias B. It also means a second writ, issued after a first writ has been issued to no purpose.

quotation: Accede ad ignem hunc, jam calesces plus satis.
translation: Approach this fire, and you will soon be too warm.
notes: Said in allusion to the seductive beauty of the courtesan Thais.

quotation: Accensa domo proximi, tua quoque periclitatur.
translation: When the house of your neighbour is in flames, your own is in danger.
notes: See Proximus ardet, etc.

quotation: Acceptissima semper Munera sunt, auctor quae pretiosa facit.
translation: Those gifts are always the most acceptable which our love for the donor makes precious

quotation: Alibi.
translation: Elsewhere.
notes: Law Term. When a person accused of an offence endeavours to prove that he was absent from the place at the time when the crime was committed, he is said to set up an alibi.

quotation: Acclinis falsis animus meliora recusat.
translation: The mind intent upon false appearances refuses to admit better things.

quotation: Aliena negotia centum Per caput, et circa saliunt latus.
translation: A hundred affairs of other people come into my head, and beset me on every side.

quotation: Aliena negotia curo, Excussus propriis.
translation: I attend to the business of other men, regardless of my own.
notes: This quotation - may be aptly applied to such busy-bodies as Aesop met, when carrying his lantern at mid-day. See Phaedrus, B. iii. F. 19.

quotation: An boni quid usquam est, quod quisquam uti possit Sine malo omni; aut, ne laborem capias, cum illo uti velles.
translation: Is there any good whatever that we can enioy wholly without evil, or where you must not endure labour when you would enjoy it?

quotation: Aliena nobis, nostra plus aliis placent.
translation: That which belongs to others pleases us most, while that which belongs to us is most valued by others.
notes: Few men are content with their station: so true it is that — "Men would be angels, angels would be gods; Aspiring to be gods, if angels fell, Aspiring to be angels, men rebel." Pope's Essay on Man."

quotation: Aliena opprobria saepe Absterrent vitiis.
translation: The disgrace of others often deters us from crime.

quotation: Aliena optimum insania frui.
translation: It is best to profit by the madness of others.
notes: A proverb quoted by the Elder Pliny. See Optimum est aliena, &c.

quotation: Aliena vitia in oculis habemus - a tergo nostra sunt.
translation: We have the vices of others always before our eyes — our own behind our backs.
notes: See Ut nemo in sese, &c.

quotation: Aliena vivere quadra.
translation: To eat off another man's trencher.
notes: To live at another's expense.

quotation: An dives sit omnes quaerunt, nemo an bonus.
translation: All inquire whether a man is rich, no one whether he is good.
notes: A translation from Euripides.

quotation: An erit qui velle recuset Os populi meruisse, et cedro digna locutus Linquere?
translation: Will there be any one to disown a wish to deserve the people's praise, and to leave words worthy to be preserved in cedar?
notes: Presses for books were made of cedar, and the paper was steeped in oil of cedar, that wood being esteemed for its antiseptic qualities.

quotation: An nescis longas regibus esse manus?
translation: Knowest thou not that kings have long arms?
notes: that they can reach you at a distance even?

quotation: Alieni appetens, sui profusus.
translation: Covetous of another's, lavish of his own.
notes: Catiline is here described by the historian.

quotation: An potest quidquam esse absurdius, quam quo minus viae restat, eo plus viatici quaerere?
translation: Can there be anything more absurd, than to be making all the greater provision, in proportion as the less of your journey remains to be performed?
notes: A reproof of covetousness in old age.

quotation: Alieni temporis flores.
translation: Blossoms of a time gone by.
notes: Flowers that bloomed in other days.

quotation: An quisquam est alius liber, nisi ducere vitam Cui licet, ut voluit?
translation: Is any man free, but he who is at liberty to spend his life in whatever manner he may please?

quotation: Alieno in loco Haud stabile regnum est.
translation: Over a distant realm sovereignty is insecure.

quotation: Anceps remedium est melius quam nullum.
translation: A doubtful remedy is better than none.

quotation: Alienos agros irrigas tuis sitientibus.
translation: You are watering your neighbours' fields, while your own are parched with drought.
notes: Said to an interfering busy-body.

quotation: Anguillam cauda tenes.
translation: You hold an eel by the tail.
notes: You have got to deal with a slippery fellow, and if you do not hold him fast, he will slip through your fingers.

quotation: Arcana imperii.
translation: The mysteries of governing.
notes: State secrets.

quotation: Anima est amica amanti.
translation: His mistress is the very life of a lover.

quotation: Alii sementem faciunt, alii metent.
translation: The one sows, the other will reap.

quotation: Alio patriam quaerunt sub sole jacentem.
translation: They seek a country situate beneath another sun.

quotation: Arcanum demens detegit ebrietas.
translation: Frantic drunkenness reveals every secret.

quotation: Aliorum medicus, ipse ulceribus scates.
translation: The physician of others, you are full of ulcers yourself.

quotation: Arcanum neque tu scrutaberis ullius unquam, Commissumque teges et vino tortus et ira.
translation: Enquire not into the secrets of others, and conceal what is intrusted to you, even though racked by wine and anger.

quotation: Aliquando gratius est quod facili quam quod plena manu datur.
translation: Sometimes that is more acceptable which is given with a kindly, than that which is received from a full hand.
notes: Presents are acceptable according to the spirit in which they are given.

quotation: Arctum annulum ne gestato.
translation: Do not wear too tight a ring.
notes: Do not by imprudence waste your property.

quotation: Anima magis est ubi amat quam ubi animat.
translation: The soul is more where it loves than where it lives.

quotation: Aliquem fortunae filium reverentissime colere ac venerari.
translation: To treat with the greatest reverence and respect a man who is the darling of fortune.
notes: To "follow that false plan, That money only makes the man."

quotation: Arcum intensio frangit, animum remissio.
translation: Straining injures the bow, relaxation the mind.
notes: This maxim is in words not unlike that taught in the Fable of "Aesop at Play," except that he warns us against giving, not too much, but too little, relaxation to the mind. See Phaedrus, B. iv. F. 14.

quotation: Animasque in vulnere ponunt.
translation: And they leave their lives in the wound.

quotation: Animi cultus quasi quidam humanitatis cibus.
translation: Cultivation is to the mind what food is to the body.

quotation: Ardeat ipsa licet, tormentis gaudet amantis.
translation: Although she herself may burn, she delights in the torments of her lover.

quotation: Animo aegrotanti medicus est oratio.
translation: Words are as a physician to an afflicted spirit.
notes: See Sunt verba, &c.

quotation: Ardentia verba.
translation: Words that glow.
notes: Expressions full of warmth and ardour.

quotation: Aliquis non debet esse judex in propria causa.
translation: No man ought to be judge in his own cause.

quotation: Animoque supersunt Jam prope post animam.
translation: They display spirit even though they have all but breathed forth their spirit.
notes: There is a play upon the resemblance of the words animus, "courage," and anima, "soul."

quotation: Accusare nemo se debet nisi coram Deo.
translation: No man is bound to accuse himself except before God.
notes: It is a maxim of our law, that no man can be forced to become his own accuser.

quotation: Ardua cervix Argutumque caput, brevis aleus, obesaque terga, Luxuriatque toris animosum pectus.
translation: Lofty is his neck, and his head slender, his belly short, his back plump, while his proud chest swells luxuriant, with brawny muscles.
notes: A fine description of what a horse should be.

quotation: Alis volat propriis.
translation: He flies with his own wings.
notes: He is able to take care of himself. Motto of the Earl of Thanet.

quotation: Animorum Impulsu, et coeca magnaque cupidine ducti.
translation: Led on by the impulse of our minds, by blind and headstrong passions.

quotation: Acer et vehemens bonus orator.
translation: A good orator is pointed and forcible.

quotation: Aliter catuli longe olent, aliter sues.
translation: Puppies have one smell, pigs quite another.
notes: All animals have an instinct by which they recognise their young.

quotation: Animula, vagula, blandula! Hospes, comesque corporis.
translation: Dear, fluttering, fleeting soul of mine, thou guest and companion of the body.
notes: The beginning of the address of the emperor Adrian to his soul, composed in his last moments, and preserved by the historian Spartianus, as expressive of his uncertainty as to a future existence. The idea of Pope's "Dying Christian's Address to his Soul," was suggested by these lines, which are replete with exquisite beauty."

quotation: Acerrima proximorum odia.
translation: The hatred of those most nearly connected is the bitterest of all.

quotation: Alitur vitium, vivitque tegendo.
translation: Vice is nourished and lives by concealment.

quotation: Acerrimus ex omnibus nostris sensibus est sensus videndi.
translation: The keenest of all our senses is the sense of sight.

quotation: Animum nunc huc celerem, nunc dividit illuc.
translation: Now this way, now that, he turns his wavering mind.

quotation: Animum pictura pascit inani.
translation: He feeds his mind with an empty picture.
notes: He amuses himself with unsubstantial anticipations. Sea the stories of the Barmecide's Feast, and of Alnaschar and his brittle ware, in the Arabian Nights.

quotation: Acribus initiis, incurioso fine.
translation: Zealous at the commencement, careless towards the conclusion.
notes: Said of those who commence an undertaking with more zeal than perseverance or discretion.

quotation: Alium silere quod valeas, primus sile.
translation: That you may impose silence upon another, first be silent yourself.

quotation: Acriora orexim excitant embammata.
translation: Savoury seasonings stimulate the appetite.

quotation: Alma mater.
translation: A kind," or ""benign"", mother.
notes: A term originally used in reference to the earth, but employed by students to designate the university in which they were educated. It is said to have been first applied to Cambridge.

quotation: Acta exteriora indicant interiora secreta.
translation: The outward conduct indicates the secrets of the heart.

quotation: Animum rege, qui nisi paret Imperat.
translation: Control your temper, for if it does not obey you, it will govern you.

quotation: Alta sedent civilis vulnera dextrae.
translation: The wounds inflicted by civil war are deeply seated.

quotation: Actio personalis moritur cum persona.
translation: A personal action dies with the person.

quotation: Altera manu fert lapidem, altera panem ostentat.
translation: In one hand he carries a stone, while in the other he shows bread.
notes: So our proverb, "He carries fire in one hand, and water in the other."

quotation: Actum est de republica.
translation: It is all over with the republic.
notes: The constitution is overthrown.

quotation: Actum ne agas.
translation: What has been done do not over again.

quotation: Animus aequus optimum est aerumnae condimentum.
translation: A patient mind is the best remedy for affliction.

quotation: Ardua molimur; sed nulla nisi ardua virtus.
translation: I attempt an arduous task; but there is no merit but what is to be secured by arduous means.

quotation: Animus est in patinis.
translation: My thoughts are among the saucepans.
notes: I am thinking of something to eat.

quotation: Arena sine calce.
translation: Sand without lime.
notes: If sand is used too plentifully, the mortar will not adhere. This saying was used by the emperor Caligula with reference to the desultory works of the philosopher Seneca.

quotation: Animus furandi.
translation: The intention of stealing.
notes: It is the animus, and not the act, that constitutes an offence.

quotation: Animus homini, quicquid sibi imperat, obtinet.
translation: Whatever it resolves on the human mind can effect.

quotation: Arenae mandas semina.
translation: You are sowing your grain in the sand.
notes: You are labouring at an impossibility.

quotation: Animus hominis semper appetit agere aliquid.
translation: The mind of man is always longing to do something.

quotation: Arescit gramen veniente autumno.
translation: The grass withers as autumn comes on.
notes: Applicable to the sear and yellow leaf of old age.

quotation: Animus meminit praeteritorum, praesentia cernit, futura praevidet.
translation: The mind remembers past events, scans the present, foresees the future.

quotation: Altera manu scabunt, altera feriunt.
translation: They scratch you with one hand, and strike you with the other.
notes: Said of treacherous and deceitful persons.

quotation: Argentum accepi, dote imperium vendidi.
translation: I received money with her, and for the dowry have sold my authority.

quotation: Animus quod perdidit optat, Atque in praeterita se totus imagine versat.
translation: The mind still longs for what it has lost, and is wholly intent upon the past.
notes: The contemplation of lost opportunities has a kind of fascination, which at the same moment both invites and repels.

quotation: Alter idem.
translation: Another self.
notes: See Verus amicus.

quotation: Argilla quidvis imitaberis uda.
translation: With moist clay you may imitate anything you please.
notes: Early impressions are most indelibly fixed.

quotation: Animus si te non deficit aequus.
translation: If your equanimity does not fail you.

quotation: Argumentum ad hominem.
translation: An argument direct to the man.
notes: An argument which admits of a personal application.

quotation: Argumentum ad ignorantiam.
translation: An argument to ignorance.
notes: An argument founded on the ignorance of your adversary.

quotation: Alter ipse amicus.
translation: A friend is a second self.
notes: The thought occurs more than once in the works of Aristotle.

quotation: Argumentum ad judicium.
translation: An argument by appeal to the judgment.

quotation: Anno Domini.
translation: In the year of our Lord;
notes: for brevity, A. D.

quotation: Alterius non sit qui suus esse potest.
translation: Let no man be the servant of another, who can be his own master.

quotation: Argumentum ad verecundiam.
translation: An argument to decency.

quotation: Alterius sic Altera poscit opem, res et conjurat amice.
translation: Thus does one thing require the co-operation of another, and they join in mutual aid.

quotation: Argumentum baculinum.
translation: The argument of the stick.
notes: Club law.

quotation: Argutos inter strepit anser olores.
translation: He gabbles like a goose among the tuneful swans.

quotation: Anno Mundi.
translation: In the year of the world;
notes: for brevity, A. M.

quotation: Alter remus aquas, alter mihi radat arenas.
translation: Let one of my oars skim the water, the other touch the sands.
notes: By acting thus, we shall not find ourselves out of our depth.

quotation: Arma cerealia.
translation: The arms of Ceres.
notes: Implements of husbandry, of which Ceres was the goddess.

quotation: Anno Urbis conditae.
translation: In the year from the building of the city.
notes: See Ab urbe, &c.

quotation: Alter rixatur de lana saepe caprina, Propugnat nugis armatus.
translation: Another raises a dispute about a lock of goat's wool, and has recourse to arms for trifles.
notes: Potentates, as well as wolves, have often acted upon this principle, when they have deemed it to their interest to "pick a quarrel".

quotation: Arma tenenti Omnia dat, qui justa negat.
translation: He who refuses what is just, grants everything to his opponent when armed.
notes: Consciousness of rectitude inspires us with that confidence which so greatly conduces to success.

quotation: Annosam arborem transplantare.
translation: To transplant an aged tree.
notes: Said of a person late in life quitting an employment in which he has been long engaged, for a new one.

quotation: Altissima quaeque flumina minimo sono labuntur.
translation: The deepest rivers flow with the least noise.
notes: Of similar application to our proverb, "Empty vessels make the greatest sound."

quotation: Annosa vulpes haud capitur laqueo.
translation: An old fox is not to be caught with a springe.
notes: Old birds are not to be caught with chaff.

quotation: A. M. for Artium Magister.
translation: Master of Arts.
notes: The highest University degree in Arts. See also Anno Mundi, Ante meridiem.

quotation: Annus mirabilis.
translation: The year of wonders.

quotation: Ama tanquam osurus. Oderis tanquam amaturus.
translation: Love as though you might hate. Hate as though you might love.
notes: Be prepared in either case for a change of circumstances; and neither make your friend acquainted with your failings and weak points, nor make it impossible that your enemy can ever become reconciled to you. Cicero, with considerable reason, dissents from the first part of this adage. See Amicum ita, &c.

quotation: Ante barbam doces senes.
translation: Before you have got a beard you are for teaching the aged.

quotation: Ante diem clauso componet Vesper Olympo.
translation: The evening star will first shut the gates of heaven upon the day.

quotation: Ante mare, et tellus, et quod tegit omnia coelum, Unus erat toto naturae vultus in orbe, Quem dixere Chaos; rudis indigestaque moles.
translation: At first the sea, the earth, and the heaven which covers all things, were the only face of nature through the whole universe, which men have named Chaos; a rude and undigested mass.

quotation: Ante meridiem.
translation: "Before noon," or "mid-day,"
notes: generally denoted by the initials A. M.

quotation: Amantium irae amoris integratio est.
translation: The quarrels of lovers are the renewal of love.
notes: So our old proverb, "Old pottage is sooner heated than new made."

quotation: Amare et sapere vix deo conceditur.
translation: It is hardly granted to a god to be in love and to act wisely.

quotation: Amare juveni fructus est, crimen seni.
translation: It is proper for a young man to be in love, a crime for an old one.

quotation: Actus Dei nemini facit injuriam.
translation: The act of God does wrong to no man.
notes: The word injury is here used in its primary sense. God, who is the author of justice, cannot do that which is unjust.

quotation: Ambiguas in vulgum spargere voces.
translation: To spread ambiguous reports among the populace.

quotation: Ambiguum pactum contra venditorem interpretandum est.
translation: A doubtful agreement is to be interpreted against the vendor.

quotation: Ars est celare artem.
translation: The great object of art is to conceal art.
notes: The perfection of art is attained when no traces of the artist are to be seen.

quotation: Ars est sine arte, cujus principium est mentiri, medium laborare, et finis mendicare.
translation: The art is devoid of art, whose beginning is falsehood, its middle labour, and its end beggary.
notes: The character of the delusive science of alchemy.

quotation: Ars longa, vita brevis.
translation: Art is long, life is short.
notes: A translation of the first of Hippocrates' Aphorisms.

quotation: Actus legis nulli facit injuriam.
translation: The act of the law does wrong to no man.

quotation: Ante oculos errant domus, urbs, et forma locorum; Succeduntque suis singula facta locis.
translation: Before my eyes flit my home, the city, and each well-known spot: and then follows, in order, each thing, as it happens, in its appropriate place.

quotation: Actus me invito factus, non est meus actus.
translation: An act done by me against my will, is not my act.
notes: According to the principles of law, acts done under duress are void.

quotation: Ars mihi non tanti est.
translation: The art is not worth so great a penalty to me.

quotation: Ante senectutem curavi, ut bene viverem; in senectute, ut bene moriar.
translation: Before old age, I made it my care to live well; in old age, to die well.
notes: St. Jerome ranked Seneca among the writers of Christianity.

quotation: Actus non facit reum, nisi mens sit rea.
translation: The act does not make the crime, unless the intention is criminal.
notes: The law requires that evil intention, or malice prepense, should be reasonably proved against the person accused, before he can be pronounced guilty.

quotation: Amici probantur rebus adversis.
translation: Friends are proved by adversity.

quotation: Ante tubam trepidat.
translation: He trembles before the trumpet sounds.

quotation: Acum in meta foeni quaerere.
translation: To seek a needle in a bundle of hay.

quotation: Ars varia vulpis, ast una echino maxima.
translation: The fox has many tricks; the hedgehog only one, and that greater than all.
notes: The hedgehog effectually defends himself by rolling himself up in a ball. See Multa novit, &c.

quotation: Ante victoriam canere triumphum.
translation: To celebrate the triumph before victory.
notes: Similar in meaning to our expression, "To count our chickens before they are hatched."

quotation: Ad calamitatem quilibet rumor valet.
translation: Every rumour is believed when directed against the unfortunate.
notes: To the same purpose as the English proverb, "Give a dog a bad name and hang him."

quotation: Ante victoriam ne canas triumphum.
translation: Don't sing your triumph before you have conquered.
notes: So we say, "Don't halloo before you are out of the wood."

quotation: Ad Calendas Graecas.
translation: At the Greek Calends.
notes: As the Greeks, in their division of the months, had no calends, (which were used by the Romans only,) this phrase was used in reference to a thing that could never take place. "To-morrow come never," as we say."

quotation: Artem quaevis alit terra.
translation: Every country nurtures some art.

quotation: Ante videmus fulgurationem quam sonum audiamus.
translation: We see the lightning before we hear the thunder.

quotation: Ad captandum vulgus.
translation: To catch the mob.
notes: Said of a specious argument "for the nonce."

quotation: Artis magistra necessitas.
translation: Necessity is the mistress of the arts.

quotation: Antehac putabam te habere cornua.
translation: Till now I thought you had horns.
notes: Said to a blusterer, who, at the last moment, is found defective in courage.

quotation: Ad connectendas amicitias, tenacissimum vinculum est morum similitudo.
translation: For cementing friendship, resemblance of manners is the strongest tie.

quotation: Asinum sub fraeno currere docere.
translation: To teach an ass to obey the rein.
notes: A task which was considered by the ancients to be "labour in vain." See At si cognatos, &c.

quotation: Antequam incipias consulto, et ubi consulueris facto opus est.
translation: Before you begin, consider, and when you have considered, act.

quotation: Antiqua homo virtute ac fide.
translation: A man of the virtue and fidelity of the olden time.

quotation: Ad consilium ne accesseris, antequam voceris.
translation: Go not to the council-chamber before yon are summoned.
notes: Speak when you are spoken to, and come when you are called.

quotation: Asinus asino, et sus sui pulcher.
translation: An ass to ass is a beauty, a swine to a swine.
notes: Somewhat similar to our saying, "Every Jack has his Jill." A fortunate feature in the harmonious system of nature.

quotation: Asinus inter simias.
translation: An ass among apes.
notes: Said of a fool among ill-natured persons who make a butt of him.

quotation: Ad eundem.
translation: To the same (rank or class).
notes: Graduates of one university, when admitted to the same degree in another, but not incorporated as members, are said to be admitted ad eundem.

quotation: Asinus in unguento.
translation: An ass among perfumes.
notes: Said of a person out of his element.

quotation: Ad interim.
translation: For/during the meanwhile.
notes: A temporary substitute is appointed to act ad interim.

quotation: Asperae facetiae, ubi nimis ex vero traxere, acrem sui memoriam relinquunt.
translation: Cutting jokes, especially when based too much upon truth, leave a bitter remembrance.
notes: The truth of this is experienced by those who  prefer to have their joke, and lose their friend.

quotation: Ad libitum.
translation: At pleasure.
notes: In music this term is used to show that the passage may be played at the discretion of the performer.

quotation: Asperitas agrestis et inconcinna gravisque.
translation: A clownish roughness, churlish and ill at ease.

quotation: Ad mala quisque animum referat sua.
translation: Let each person recall to mind his own mishaps.

quotation: Asperius nihil est humili cum surgit in altum.
translation: Nothing is more unendurable than a low-bred man, when he attains an elevated station.
notes: We have a proverb to the same effect, "Set a beggar on horseback, and he will ride to the devil."

quotation: Ad mensuram aquam bibit.
translation: He drinks water by measure.

quotation: Aspice curvatos pomorum pondere ramos.
translation: Behold the branches bending beneath the weight of apples.

quotation: Antiquitas saeculi juventus mundi.
translation: Ancient time was the youth of the world.
notes: An aphorism of Lord Bacon, for which, according to Hal'am and Whewell, he is indebted to Giordano Bruno.

quotation: Ad minora me demittere non recusabo.
translation: I will not refuse to descend to the most minute details.
notes: I will sift the matter to the bottom.

quotation: Ad mores natura recurrit Damnatos, fixa et mutari nescia.
translation: Human nature ever reverts to its depraved courses, fixed and immutable.

quotation: Anus simia sero quidem.
translation: The old ape is taken at last.
notes: Of the same meaning as our saying, "The old fox is caught at last."

quotation: Ad nomen vultus sustulit illa suos.
translation: On hearing her name she raised her eyes.

quotation: Aperit praecordia Liber.
translation: Bacchus opens the heart.

quotation: Assiduo labuntur tempora motu Non secus ac flumen. Neque enim consistere flumen, Nec levis hora potest.
translation: Time glides on with a constant progress, no otherwise than as a flowing stream. For neither can the stream nor the fleeting hour stop in its course.

quotation: Amici vitium ni feras, prodis tuum.
translation: Unless you can put up with the faults of your friend, you betray your own.
notes: You show that either the ties of friendship are easily relaxed, or that you are put out of temper by trifles.

quotation: Ad nullum consurgit opus, cum corpore languet.
translation: The mind cannot grapple with any task when the body is languid.

quotation: Aperte mala cum est mulier, tum demum est bona.
translation: When a woman is openly bad, then she is good.
notes: This paradoxical expression implies that less injury results to the world from open dissoluteness, than from the hypocrisy of those who conceal profligacy under the guise of sanctity and virtue.

quotation: Amicitia semper prodest, amor et nocet.
translation: Friendship is always productive of advantage, and love of injury.
notes: This dictum seems to be stated in rather too general terms.

quotation: Aperto vivere voto.
translation: To live with every wish revealed.
notes: The motto of the Earl of Aylesford.

quotation: Amicorum, magis quam tuam ipsius laudem, praedica.
translation: Enlarge upon the praises of your friends rather than on your own.

quotation: Assumpsit.
translation: He engaged to pay.
notes: An action of assumpsit lies on the promise to pay, which the law implies on the part of every man who buys of another.

quotation: Apio opus est.
translation: There is need of parsley.
notes: Said when a sick person was past all hope of recovery. The Grecians sowed the graves of the dead with this herb.

quotation: Ast alii sex Et plures, uno conclamant ore.
translation: Six others, ay more, with one voice assent.

quotation: Apparatus belli.
translation: The matériel of war.

quotation: Astra regunt homines, sed regit astra Deus.
translation: The stars govern man, but God governs the stars.
notes: The belief of the astrologers.

quotation: Amicos res opimae pariunt, adversae probant.
translation: Prosperity begets friends, adversity proves them.

quotation: Apparent rari nantes in gurgite vasto.
translation: A few are seen here and there, swimming in the boundless ocean.
notes: Virgil here describes the shipwrecked sailors of the Trojan fleet.

quotation: Astutior coccyge.
translation: More crafty than the cuckoo.
notes: who lays her eggs in the nest of another bird.

quotation: At daemon homini quum struit aliquid malum, Pervertit illi primitus mentem suam.
translation: But the daemon, when he devises any mischief against a man, first perverts his mind.
notes: See Quem Deus, &c, and Quem Jupiter, &c.

quotation: Appetitus rationi pareat.
translation: Let your passions be obedient to reason.
notes: Employed as the motto or Earl Fitzwilliam.

quotation: At haec etiam servis semper libera fuerunt, timerent, gauderent, dolerent, suo potius quam alterius arbitrio.
translation: Slaves, even, have always been at liberty to fear, to rejoice, to grieve, at their own pleasure, and not at the will of another.
notes: The body may be "cribb'd, cabin' d, and confin'd, but the mind cannot be chained."

quotation: At jam non domus accipiet te laeta; neque uxor Optima, nec dulces occurrent oscula nati
At pulchrum est digito monstrari et dicier, Hic est.
translation: It is a gratifying thing to be pointed at with the finger, and to have it said, That is he.
notes: Of course this applies to a man who has become famous, not notorious.

quotation: Aquam perdo.
translation: I lose my time.
notes: Time was measured by the ancients by means of water running in the clepsydra, as in more modern days by sand. A certain portion of time was allotted to each orator to plead his cause; whence the present expression, which literally means, "I am losing the water."

quotation: At reditus jam quisque suos amat, et sibi quid sit Utile, solicitis supputat articulis.
translation: Now-a-days every one loves his own interests, and reckons, on his anxious fingers, what may turn out useful

quotation: Aquam plorat cum lavat fundere.
translation: He weeps at throwing away the water in which he was washed.
notes: Said of a miser.

quotation: Aquila non capit muscas.
translation: The eagle does not stoop to catch flies.

quotation: Aquilae senecta.
translation: The old age of an eagle.
notes: Applied to aged topers — as the eagle was supposed, in its latter years, to live by suction only.

quotation: At scio, quo vos soleatis pacto perplexarier; Pactum non pactum est; non pactum pactum est, quod vobis lubet.
translation: But I understand the fashion in which you are wont to

quotation: Aquilam volare doces.
translation: You are for teaching an eagle how to fly.
notes: You are teaching your grandam," &c.

quotation: At si cognatos, nullo natura labore Quos tibi dat, retinere velis, servareque amicos, Infelix operam perdas, ut si quis asellum In campo doceat parentem currere fraenis.
translation: If you think to retain and preserve as friends the relatives whom nature gives you, without taking any pains, wretched man! you lose your pains just as much as if a person were to train an ass to be obedient to the rein, run along the plain.
notes: See Asinum sub, &c.

quotation: Auro contra cedo modestum amatorem.
translation: Find me a reasonable lover against his weight in gold.

quotation: Aquosus languor.
translation: The watery weakness.
notes: The dropsy.

quotation: At vindicta bonum vita jucundius ipsa, Nempe hoc indocti.
translation: But revenge is a blessing more sweet than life itself. Yes, fools think so.

quotation: Auro loquente nihil pollet quaevis ratio.
translation: When gold speaks, no reason is of the slightest avail.

quotation: Aranearum telas texere.
translation: To weave a spider's web.
notes: Meaning, to support an argument by fine-spun sophistry, or to engage in a frivolous pursuit.Meaning, to support an argument by fine-spun sophistry, or to engage in a frivolous pursuit.

quotation: Atque deos atque astra vocat crudelia mater.
translation: Both gods and stars his mother charges with cruelty.
notes: A description of the grief of Daphnis on hearing of the death of her son.

quotation: At que utinam his potius nugis tota illa dedisset Tempora saevitiae.
translation: And would that he had devoted to such trifles as these all those days of cruelty.
notes: Said of Domitian.

quotation: Auro pulsa fides, auro venalia jura, Aurum lex sequitur, mox sine lege pudor.
translation: By gold good faith is banished, the laws are put up to sale for gold, the law follows gold, and before long will modesty lose the protection of the laws.

quotation: Atqui vultus erat multa et praeclara minantis.
translation: But you had the look of one that threatened many and excellent things.

quotation: Aurum e stercore.
translation: Gold from a dunghill.
notes: said of a thing which lies concealed where least expected.

quotation: Atria regum hominibus plena sunt, amicis vacua.
translation: The halls of kings are full of men, empty of friends.
notes: Kings have many followers, but few real friends.

quotation: Aurum in fortuna invenitur, natura ingenium bonum.
translation: Gold is met with by luck, a good disposition is found by nature.

quotation: Audacem fecerat ipse timor.
translation: Fear itself had made her bold.

quotation: Aurum omnes, victa jam pietate, volunt.
translation: All men now long for gold, piety being overcome.
notes: in other words, "Money now only makes the man."

quotation: Aurum per medios ire satellites Et perrumpere amat saxa, potentius Ictu fulmineo.
translation: Gold delights to make its way through the midst of guards, and to break through stone walls, more powerful than the thunderbolt.
notes: The poet alludes to the story of Jupiter and Danae.

quotation: Aut amat, aut odit mulier; nil est tertium.
translation: A woman either loves or hates; there is no third part.

quotation: Aut bibat, aut abeat.
translation: Let each one drink or begone.
notes: The man who passes the bottle without helping himself may possibly take advantage of the unguarded expression of those who are drinking more freely.

quotation: Aut Caesar aut nullus.
translation: Either Caesar or nobody.
notes: I will attain supreme eminence, or perish in the attempt. A saying of Julius Caesar.

quotation: Auctor pretiosa facit.
translation: The giver enhances the value of the gift.
notes: See Acceptissima, &c.

quotation: Aut hoc quod produxi testium satis est, aut nihil satis.
translation: Either this testimony which I have brought is sufficient, or nothing will suffice.

quotation: Audaces fortuna juvat timidosque repellit.
translation: Fortune favours the bold, and repels the timid.

quotation: Aut insanit homo, aut versus facit.
translation: Either the man is mad, or is making verses.

quotation: Audax ad omnia faemina, quae vel amat vel odit.
translation: A woman, when inflamed by love or by hatred, will dare everything.

quotation: Aut non tentaris, aut perfice.
translation: Either try not, or persevere.
notes: "Fain would I climb, but that I fear to fall," were the words written by Sir W. Raleigh on a pane of glass: "If thy heart fails thee, why then climb at all?" was Queen Elizabeth's rejoinder.

quotation: Audax omnia perpeti gens humana ruit per vetitum et nefas.
translation: Bold to perpetrate every species of crime, mankind rushes into everything that is wicked and forbidden.
notes: These words may be appropriately applied to vice and refined dissoluteness, but they were used by Horace as a censure upon what we should now call "the march of progress."

quotation: Aut petis, aut urges ruiturum Sisyphe, saxum.
translation: You Sisyphus, either pursue or push forward the stone that is destined to fall back again.

quotation: Aude aliquid brevibus Gyaris et carcere dignum Si vis esse aliquis. Probitas laudatur et alget.
translation: Dare to commit some act worthy of the little Gyara or the gaol, if you wish to be somebody. Virtue is praised and shivers with cold.
notes: The Romans used the island of Gyara in the Aegean Sea as a place of transportation for criminals.

quotation: Aut potentior te, aut imbecillior laesit : si imbecillior parca illi; si potentior tibi.
translation: He who injured thee was either stronger or weaker: if weaker, spare him; if stronger, spare thyself.

quotation: Aut prodesse volunt aut delectare poetae, Aut simul et jucunda et idonea dicere vitae.
translation: It is the wish of poets either to instruct or to amuse at the same time to inculcate what is agreeable and what is conducive to living well.

quotation: Arbiter bibendi.
translation: The arbitrator of drinking.
notes: The master of the feast among the ancients gave directions when to fill the cups. See the Stichus of Plautus, A. iv. sc. 4.

quotation: Audendo magnus tegitur timor.
translation: Great fear is concealed under a show of courage.

quotation: Aut regem aut fatuum nasci oportuit.
translation: A man ought to be born a king or a fool.
notes: Idiots were in former times, and still are, in the East, held in the highest respect. The fools, or jesters, of kings and nobles, both in ancient times and the middle ages, were allowed the utmost licence; and it was a common saying, that "Fools are fortunate." Idiots were in former times, and still are, in the East, held in the highest respect. The fools, or jesters, of kings and nobles, both in ancient times and the middle ages, were allowed the utmost licence; and it was a common saying, that "Fools are fortunate."

quotation: Audendum est, ut illustrata veritas pateat multique a perjurio liberentur.
translation: We must make the attempt to set forth the truth, that it may be seen, and so

quotation: Arbiter elegantiarum.
translation: The arbitrator of politeness.
notes: Commonly used in reference to the person whose duty it is to decide on any matter of taste or form; a master of the ceremonies.

quotation: Aut virtus nomen inane est, Aut decus et pretium recte petit experiens vir.
translation: Either virtue is an empty name, or the wise man rightly seeks it as his glory and reward.

quotation: Audentem Forsque Venusque juvant.
translation: Fortune and Venus befriend the bold.

quotation: Autumnus Libitinae questus acerbae.
translation: Autumn — the harvest of the direful Libitina.
notes: Autumn was in ancient times, as now, accounted a sickly season, and Libitina was the patron goddess of the pollinctores, or undertakers.

quotation: Audentes fortuna juvat.
translation: Fortune favours the brave.

quotation: Auxilia humilia firma consensus facit.
translation: Concord gives strength to humble aids.
notes: Union imparts strength.

quotation: Arbiter hic sumtus de lite jocosa.
translation: He was chosen umpire in this sportive contest.
notes: Said of Tiresias, who was chosen umpire in the contest between Jupiter and Juno.

quotation: Avarus, nisi cum moritur, nil recte facit.
translation: A miser, until he dies, does nothing right.
notes: His heir, at all events, is apt to think, that his dying was the best action of his life.

quotation: Avia Pieridum peragro loca, nullius ante Trita solo, juvat integros accedere fonteis Atque haurire.
translation: I wander through the retired retreats of the Muses, untrodden before by another foot; I delight to approach their untouched fountain, and to drink thereof.

quotation: Avida est periculi Virtus, et quo tendat non quid passura sit cogitat.
translation: Virtue courts danger, and considers what it may accomplish, not what it may suffer.

quotation: Arbore dejecta qui vult ligna colligit.
translation: When the tree is thrown down, every one who pleases gathers the wood.
notes: The meanest may, and often do, triumph over fallen majesty. See the fable of "The aged Lion and the Ass," in Phaedrus, B. i. F. 21.

quotation: Avidis natura parum est.
translation: The bounty of nature is too little for the greedy man.

quotation: Audi alteram partem.
translation: Hear the other side.
notes: Listen to what each party has to allege, before you give your decision.

quotation: Arbores magnae diu crescunt, una hora extirpantur.
translation: Great trees are long in growing, but are rooted up in a single hour.

quotation: Avidus apto cum lare fundus.
translation: A farm inherited from my ancestors, with a suitable

quotation: Audi, Nulla unquam de morte hominis cunctatio longa est.
translation: Listen! when a man's life is at stake no delay can be too long.

quotation: Balnea, vina, Venus corrumpunt corpora nostra; Sed vitam faciunt balnea, vina, Venus.
translation: Baths, wine, and Venus cause our bodies to decay: but baths, wine, and Venus make up the sum of life.
notes: Wine, women, warmth, against our lives combine, But what were life without warmth, women, wine?

quotation: Audi, vide, tace, si vis vivere in pace.
translation: Listen, look on, and hold your tongue, if you would live in peace.
notes: A Leonine line of the middle ages.

quotation: Barbae tenus sapientes.
translation: Philosophers as far as beard.
notes: Ironically said of persons who, by assuming grave manners, wish to pass themselves off for men of learning.

quotation: Audiet pugnas, vitio parentum, Rara juventus.
translation: Our youth, thinned by the vices of their fathers, shall hear of these battles.

quotation: Bastardus nullius est filius, aut filius populi.
translation: A bastard is the son of no man, in other words, the son of the public.
notes: A bastard, not being born in wedlock, his father is not recognised as such by the law; but, as nn individual, the public laws protect his life and property.

quotation: Audire, atque togam jubeo componere quisquis Ambitione mala, aut argenti pallet amore, Quisquis luxuria.
translation: Whoever is pale through foul ambition, or the love of

quotation: Beati immaculati in via.
translation: Blessed are the undefiled in the way.
notes: The commencing words of the 119th Psalm.

quotation: Audire est operae pretium.
translation: It is worth your while to listen.

quotation: Beati monoculi in regione cacorum.
translation: Happy are the one-eyed in the country of the blind.
notes: All things ought to be judged of comparatively; and, whatever may be the extent of our misfortunes, there will still be found something for consolation.

quotation: Beatissimus is est, qui est aptus ex sese, quique in se uno sua ponit omnia.
translation: He is the most happy who is self-prepared, and who centres all his resources in himself.

quotation: Beatus ille qui procul negotiis, Ut prisca gens mortalium, Paterna rura bobus exercet suis. Solutus omni foenore.
translation: Happy the man who, remote from business, after the manner of the ancient race of mortals, cultivates his paternal lands with his own oxen, disengaged from all usury.

quotation: Beatus qui est, non intelligo quid requirat ut sit beatior.
translation: I do not see why he who is already happy, neads seek to be happier.

quotation: Bella! horrida bella!
translation: War! horrid war!

quotation: Ad omnem libidinem projectus homo.
translation: A man disposed to every species of dissipation.

quotation: Bella matribus detestata.
translation: War, so detested by mothers.

quotation: Audita querela.
translation: The complaint of the defendant having been heard.
notes: The name of a writ by which a defendant appealed against a judgment given against him.

quotation: Bella — nullos habitura triumphos.
translation: Wars which leave no cause for triumph.
notes: Most truly said of civil war.

quotation: Auditque vocatus Apollo.
translation: And Apollo hears when invoked.

quotation: Bella suscipienda sunt ob eam causam, ut sine injuria in pace vivatur.
translation: Wars are to be undertaken in order that we may live in peace without suffering wrong.

quotation: Auferimur cultu.
translation: We are captivated by dress.

quotation: Belle narras.
translation: You tell a very pretty story.
notes: Said ironically.

quotation: Arbores serit diligens agricola, quarum aspiciet nunquam ipse baccam.
translation: The industrious husbandman plants trees, of which he himself will never see a berry.
notes: In imitation of him, we must not confine ourselves to good works, the fruit of which is to be immediately gathered.

quotation: Bellua multorum capitum.
translation: The many-headed monster.
notes: The mob.

quotation: Bellum ita suscipiatur, ut nihil aliud nisi pax quaesita videatur.
translation: War should be so engaged in, that nothing but peace should appear to be aimed at.

quotation: Arcades ambo Et cantare pares, et respondere parati.
translation: Both Arcadians, equally skilled in the song and ready for the response.

quotation: Auguriis patrum et prisca formidine sacrum.
translation: (A grove) hallowed by the auguries of our forefathers, and by ancient awe.
notes: Like a fly in clouded amber, this hexameter lies concealed in the prose of the historian. It is probably a quotation from some Latin poet, but has been overlooked as such.

quotation: Bellum nec timendum nec provocandum.
translation: War ought neither to be dreaded, nor provoked.

quotation: Bene dormit, qui non sentit quam male dormiat.
translation: He sleeps well who does not perceive how badly he has slept.
notes: Bene est cui Deus obtulit Parca quod satis est manu. Hor. — "Happy for him, to whom God has given enough with a sparing hand."

quotation: Ad perditam securim manubrium adjicere.
translation: To throw the helve after the lost hatchet.
notes: To give way to despair.

quotation: Bene ferre magnam Disce fortunam.
translation: Learn to support your good fortune with moderation.

quotation: Augurium ratio est, et conjectura futuri: Hac divinavi, notitiamque tuli.
translation: Reason is my augury, and my estimate of the future; from it have I made my prediction and derived my knowledge.

quotation: Aula regis.
translation: The court of the king.
notes: A court which, in the middle ages, accompanied the king wherever he went, and in which originated the present Court of King's Bench.

quotation: Aura popularis.
translation: The breeze of popularity.
notes: A man who has the populace upon his side, is for the moment wafted on by the aura popularis. See Virtus repulsae, &c.

quotation: Bene merenti bene profuerit, male merenti par erit.
translation: To the well-deserving God will show favour, to the ill-deserving will he give like for like.

quotation: Aurea ne credas quaecunque nitescere cernis.
translation: Think not that everything that shines is gold.
notes: All is not gold that glitters." Trust not to outside appearances.

quotation: Bene nummatum decorat Suadela Venusque.
translation: Love and compliance favour the wealthy suitor.
notes: Suadela, or Suada, the goddess of persuasion.

quotation: Aurea nunc vere sunt saecula, plurimus auro Venit honos: auro conciliatur amor.
translation: Truly this is the golden age: the chief honours accrue through gold; with gold love is purchased.

quotation: Bene si amico feceris, ne pigeat fecisse, Ut potius pudeat si non feceris.
translation: If you have conferred a favour upon your friend, repent not of having done so; rather feel that you would have been ashamed had you not done so.

quotation: Aurea prima sata est aetas, quae vindice nullo, Sponte sua, sine lege, fidem rectumque colebat. Poena metusque aberant.
translation: The golden age was first founded, which without any avenger, of its own accord, and without laws, practised faith and rectitude. Punishment, and the fear of it, did not yet exist.

quotation: Aureo piscari hamo.
translation: To fish with a golden hook.
notes: To spare no sum however large in obtaining the object of our pursuit. A saying much used by Augustus Caesar.

quotation: Benefacta male locata, malefacta arbitror.
translation: Favours injudiciously conferred I consider injuries.
notes: Nothing is more injurious to the common good, than indiscriminate charity, or profuse indulgence.

quotation: Auri sacra fames.
translation: The cursed greed of gold.
notes: See Quid non mortalia, &c.

quotation: Ad perniciem solet agi sinceritas.
translation: Sincerity is frequently impelled to its own destruction.

quotation: Beneficia dare qui nescit injuste petit.
translation: He who knows not how to bestow a benefit, is unreasonable if he expects one.

quotation: Beneficia plura recipit qui scit reddere.
translation: He receives most favours, who knows how to make a proper return.

quotation: Beneficia usque eo laeta sunt dum videntur exsolvi posse; ubi multum antevenere, pro gratia odium redditur.
translation: Benefits are only acceptable so long as we think we may requite them; but when they exceed the possibility of so doing, hatred is returned instead of gratitude.
notes: This maxim, it is to be hoped, is not of general acceptation, but applies to the exception, and not the rule. If universally acted on, the world would soon be a dreary wilderness. See AEs debitorem, &c.

quotation: Beneficium accipere libertatem vendere est.
translation: To accept an obligation is to barter your liberty.

quotation: Bonus judex secundum asquum et bonum judicat, et aequitatem strictae legi praefert.
translation: A good judge gives judgment according to what is equitable and right, and prefers an equitable construction to the strict letter of the law.

quotation: Bos alienus subinde prospectat foras.
translation: The strange ox repeatedly looks to the door.
notes: Significant of that love of home which pervades the animated creation.

quotation: Beneficium dignis ubi des, omnes obliges.
translation: Where you confer a benefit, worthy of it, the obligation is extended to all.

quotation: Beneficium invito non datur.
translation: A benefit conferred on a churl is no benefit.
notes: The phrase may also mean that a benefit conferred with an ill grace is no benefit.

quotation: Bos fortius fatigatus figit pedem.
translation: The wearied ox treads the surest.

quotation: Beneficium meminisse debet is, in quem collocata sunt; non commemorare qui contulit.
translation: He ought to remember benefits on whom they are conferred; he who confers them ought not to mention them.

quotation: Bos in lingua.
translation: An ox on his tongue.
notes: Said of a man who had been bribed, as the Athenians had money stamped with the figure of an ox.

quotation: Beneficium non in eo quod fit aut datur constitit, sed in ipso facientis aut dantis animo: animus est enim qui beneficiis dat pretium.
translation: A benefit consists not in that which is done or given, but in the spirit in which it is done or given; for it is the spirit which gives all the value to the benefit.

quotation: Breve tempus aetatis satis est longum ad bene honesteque vivendum.
translation: A short life is long enough for us to live well and honestly.

quotation: Brevi manu.
translation: With a short hand.
notes: Off-hand, in a summary manner.

quotation: Brevis esse laboro, Obscurus fio.
translation: While I endeavour to be brief, I become obscure.
notes: Said of authors who, aiming at conciseness, give their readers credit for knowing too much. The exclamation of Thomas Warton, on accidentally snuffing out a candle.

quotation: Beneficium saepe dare, docere est reddere.
translation: Often to confer a benefit is to teach how to make a return.
notes: In giving to others, we teach them to be charitable.

quotation: Brevis ipsa vita est, sed malis sit longior.
translation: Life itself is short, but it may last longer than your misfortunes.
notes: Somewhat similar to our proverb, "It is a long lane that has no turning."

quotation: Beneficus est qui non sui, sed alterius causa benigne facit.
translation: He is beneficent who acts kindly, not for his own sake, but to serve another.
notes: Disinterestedness is the soul of benevolence.

quotation: Ad poenitendum properat, cito qui judicat.
translation: He hastens to repentance, who judges hastily.

quotation: Brevis voluptas mox doloris est parens.
translation: Short-lived pleasure is the parent of speedy sorrow.

quotation: Bona nemini hora est, ut non alicui sit mala.
translation: There is no hour good for one man but that it is bad for another.
notes: One man's loss is another man's gain.

quotation: Brutum fulmen.
translation: A harmless thunderbolt.
notes: Big words; the groans of the mountains when they were delivered of the mouse.

quotation: Bona notabilia.
translation: Known goods.
notes: Goods beyond the value of five pounds left by a person deceased, in any other diocese than that in which he died.

quotation: Ad populum phaleras, ego te intus et in cute novi.
translation: Display thy trappings to the vulgar, I know thee inside and out.

quotation: Cacoethes.
translation: A bad habit.
notes: This is a Greek word Latinized, which has been adopted in other languages.

quotation: Ad praesens ova cras pullis sunt meliora.
translation: Eggs today are better than chickens tomorrow.
notes: in defective verse, similar to ours — "A bird in the hand," etc."

quotation: Cacoethes carpendi.
translation: An itch for finding fault
notes: or "carping at."

quotation: Ad quaestionem juris respondeant judices, ad quaestionem facti respondeant juratores.
translation: It is the duty of the judge to decide as to the point of law, of the jurors to decide as to the matter of fact.

quotation: Cacoethes scribendi.
translation: An itch for scribbling.

quotation: Ad quod damnum.
translation: To what damage.
notes: A writ issued to inquire into the damage that may be sustained before the grant of certain liberties.

quotation: Cadit quaestio.
translation: There is an end on the question.
notes: The matter requires no further investigation. See Casus quaestionis.

quotation: Caeca invidia est, nec quidquam aliud scit quam detractare virtutes.
translation: Envy is blind, and knows not how to do aught but detract from the virtues of others.

quotation: Caeci sunt oculi, cum animus res alias agit.
translation: The eyes are blind, when the mind is intent upon somethinig else.

quotation: Caecus non judicat de colore.
translation: A blind man is no judge of colours.

quotation: Caesarem portas, et fortunas ejus.
translation: Thou carriest Caesar and his fortune.
notes: Said by Caesar to the pilot in the tempest.

quotation: Caetera desunt.
translation: The rest is wanting.

quotation: Caetera quis nescit?
translation: The rest who knows not?

quotation: Calamitas querula est et superba felicitas.
translation: Adversity is complaining, and prosperity proud.

quotation: Calamitosus est animus futuri anxius.
translation: The mind that is anxious about future events, is miserable.

quotation: Campos ubi Troja fuit.
translation: The fields where Troy once stood.

quotation: Callidos eos appello, quorum tanquam manus opere sic animus usu concalluit.
translation: I call those experienced, whose minds become strengthened just as the hands are hardened by labour.

quotation: Calumniare fortiter, aliquid adhaerebit.
translation: Slander stoutly; some of it will stick.

quotation: Calumniari si quis autem voluerit, Quod arbores loquantur, non tantum ferae; Fictis jocari nos meminerit fabulis.
translation: But if any one shall think fit to cavil, because not only wild beasts, but even trees speak, let him remember that we are disporting in the language of fable.
notes:
'Tis clear that birds were always able 
To hold discourse, at least in fable." Cowper.

quotation: Camelus desiderans cornua etiam aures perdidit.
translation: The camel begging for horns lost its ears as well.
notes: We should be thankful for the faculties with which Providence

quotation: Camelus saltat.
translation: The camel is dancing.
notes: Said of a person doing something quite repugnant to his ordinary habits.

quotation: Candida me capiet, capiet me flava puella.
translation: The blonde will charm me, the brunette will charm me too.

quotation: Auribus teneo lupum.
translation: I hold a wolf by the ears.
notes: If I leave go he will destroy me, yet I shall not be able long to retain him. Somewhat similar to our English phrase of "catching a Tartar." An Irish soldier, under Prince Eugene, called out to his comrade, in a battle against the Turks, that he had caught a Tartar. "Bring him along then," said the other. "He won't come," was the reply. "Then come yourself." "But he won't let me," was the answer.

quotation: Ad referendum.
translation: To be referred OR to await further consideration.

quotation: Candida pax homines, trux decet ira feras.
translation: Fair peace becomes human beings, savage fury wild beasts.

quotation: Candida, perpetuo reside, concordia, lecto, Jamque pari semper sit Venus aequa jugo: Diligat illa senem quondam; sed et ipsa marito, Tunc quoque cum fuerit, non videatur anus.
translation: Pair concord, ever attend their bed, and may Venus ever prove auspicious to the well-matched pair; may she at a future day love her old man; and may she, even when she is so, not appear to her husband to be aged.

quotation: Candidus in nauta turpis color: aequoris unda Debet et a radiis sideris esse niger.
translation: A fair complexion is unbecoming in a sailor; he ought to be swarthy, from the spray of the sea and the rays of the sun.

quotation: Candor dat viribus alas.
translation: Candour imparts wings to strength.

quotation: Bonae leges malis ex moribus procreantur.
translation: Good laws grow out of evil acts.

quotation: Canes socium in culina nullum amant.
translation: Dogs love no companion in the kitchen.
notes: See Figulus, &c, and Unus(?) domus, &c.

quotation: Bonarum rerum consuetudo pessima est.
translation: The constant enjoyment of good things is most hurtful.
notes: Habitual indulgence in luxuries is prejudicial; by constant repetition the taste becomes cloyed, and all sense of enjoyment lost.

quotation: Canes timidi vehementius latrant quam mordent.
translation: With cowardly dogs, the bark is worse than the bite.

quotation: Boni nullo emolumento impelluntur in fraudem, improbi saepe parvo.
translation: Good men are never induced to commit fraud by any gain whatsoever; the bad often by a very little.

quotation: Ad respondendum quaestioni.
translation: To answer the question
notes: Students at the university of Cambridge, who are about to be examined for their degree in Arts, or in other words, admitted ad respondendum quaestioni, are thence called questionists.

quotation: Canina facundia.
translation: Dog eloquence.
notes: Mentioned by Quintilian as that kind of eloquence which distinguished itself in snarling at others. See Littera canina.

quotation: Boni pastoris est tondere pecus non deglubere.
translation: It is the duty of a good shepherd to shear his sheep, not to flay them.
notes: A saying of Tiberius Caesar, in reference to excessive taxation.

quotation: Canis festinans caecos parit catulos.
translation: The bitch, in making too much naste, brings forth her whelps blind.
notes: Said of persons who are in too great a hurry to put the

quotation: Boni venatoris est plures feras capere non omnes.
translation: It is the business of a good sportsman to take much game, not all.
notes: From Notes to Horace, by Nannius.

quotation: Cantabit vacuus coram latrone viator.
translation: The traveller with empty pockets, will sing in presence of the robber.
notes: He who has nothing to lose is in no fear of being robbed.

quotation: Ad suum quemque aequum est quaestum esse callidum.
translation: It is only right that every one should be alive to his own advantage.

quotation: Cantantes licet usque (minus via laedet) eamus.
translation: Let us sing as we travel on, the journey will be all the less tedious.

quotation: Ad tristem partem strenua suspicio.
translation: The minds of men who have been unfortunate are prone to suspicion.
notes: Much to the same purpose as our proverb, "A burnt child dreads the fire."

quotation: Boni viri omnes aequitatem ipsam amant.
translation: All good men love justice for its own sake.

quotation: Cantat, et ad nautas ebria verba jacit.
translation: He sings aloud and cracks his drunken jokes upon the sailors.

quotation: Ad turpia virum bonum nulla spes invitat.
translation: No expectation can allure a good man to the commission of evil.

quotation: Cantat vinctus quoque compede fossor, Indocili numero cum grave mollit opus. Cantat et innitens limosae pronus arenae, Adverso tardam qui trahit amne ratem.
translation: The miner, chained with the fetter, sings as he lightens his heavy labours with his untaught numbers; and the man sings, who strives as he bends forward on the oozy sand, while he drags the slow barge against the tide.

quotation: Ad unum corpus humanum supplicia plura quam membra.
translation: One human body is liable to more pains than the members of which it is composed.

quotation: Ad utrumque paratus.
translation: Prepared for either alternative.

quotation: Ad valorem.
translation: According to the value.
notes: Duties are imposed on certain articles of merchandise, ad valorem, or according to their value.

quotation: Cantate Domino.
translation: O sing unto the Lord (a new song).
notes: Beginning of the 98th Psalm.

quotation: Ad vivum.
translation: To the life.
