quotation: Detur aliquando otium quiesque fessis.
translation: Rest and repose should sometimes be granted to the weary.
notes: The bow must be sometimes unstrung.

quotation: Dictum de dicto.
translation: A report founded on hearsay.

quotation: Dolorem aut extimescere venientem, aut non ferre praesentem, turpe est.
translation: To be terrified at an approaching evil, or not to be able to bear up against it when present, is disgraceful.

quotation: Detur pulchriori.
translation: Let it be given to the most beautiful.
notes: The inscription on the golden apple, by adjudging which to the goddess Venus, Paris offended Juno and Minerva, and ultimately caused the Trojan war.

quotation: Dolus an virtus, quis in hosie requirat?
translation: Who inquires in an enemy whether it was stratagem or valour?

quotation: Deum namque ire per omnes Terrasque, tractusque maris, coelumque profundum.
translation: For God, they say, pervades all lands, the tracts of sea, and the heaven profound.
notes: In these lines Virgil gives a broad outline of the Pantheistic philosophy.

quotation: Dolus versatur in generalibus.
translation: Fraud employs generalities.

quotation: Deus det.
translation: May God grant.
notes: In the middle ages, grace at meat was so called, from the commencing words.

quotation: Domi manere convenit felicibus.
translation: Those who are happy at home ought to remain there.

quotation: Domi mansit, lanam fecit.
translation: She stayed at home and spun her wool.
notes: An epitaph upon an exemplary wife.

quotation: Domi puer ea sola discere potest quae ipsi praecipientur: in schola etiam quae aliis.
translation: A boy can only learn at home those things which are taught him individually; at school, he can learn by what is taught to others.

quotation: Domine, exaudi.
translation: Lord, listen to my prayer.

quotation: Dictum sapienti sat est.
translation: A word to the wise is enough.
notes: A hint is enough for a sensible man.

quotation: Dominium a possessione coepisse dicitur.
translation: Right is said to have had its beginning in possession.
notes: Length of possession is sufficient to give a legal title.

quotation: Dominus vobiscum.
translation: The Lord be with you.

quotation: Dictus eram cuidam subito venisse puellae; Turbida perversas induit illa comas.
translation: I was unexpectedly announced as having paid a visit to a certain lady; in her confusion she put on her wig the wrong side before.

quotation: Domitae naturae.
translation: Of a tame nature.
notes: See Ferae naturae.

quotation: Diem perdidi!
translation: I have lost a day!
notes: The exclamation of the Emperor Titus, on finding at night that he had done nothing worthy of recollection during the day.

quotation: Domus amica domus optima.
translation: The house of a friend is the best of houses.

quotation: Dies adimit aegritudinem.
translation: Time removes afflictions.

quotation: Domus procerum.
translation: The house of peers.
notes: Often written Dom. proc.

quotation: Dies datus.
translation: A day given.
notes: The day appointed for appearing.

quotation: Deus est mortali juvare mortalem, et haec ad aeternam gloriam via.
translation: For man to assist man is to be a god; this is the path that leads to everlasting glory.

quotation: Domus sua est unicuique tutissimum refugium.
translation: Every man's house is his safest refuge.
notes: Every man's house is his castle.

quotation: Dies dolorem minuit.
translation: Time alleviates grief.

quotation: Dona praesentis cape laetus horae, et Linque severa.
translation: With cheerfulness enjoy the blessings of the present hour, and banish sad thoughts.

quotation: Dies Dominicus non est juridicus.
translation: Sunday is not a day in law.

quotation: Donatio mortis causa.
translation: A gift made in apprehension of death.
notes: A death-bed disposition of property, when a person delivers his personal goods to another to keep, in case of his decease.

quotation: Dies faustus.
translation: A lucky day.

quotation: Deus est summum bonum.
translation: God is the supreme good.

quotation: Dies infaustus.
translation: An unlucky day.

quotation: Donec eras simplex, animum cum corpore amavi; Nunc mentis vitio laesa figura tua est.
translation: So long as you were disinterested I loved both your mind and your person; now, to me, your appearance is affected by this blemish on your disposition.

quotation: Deus haec fortasse benigna Reducet in sedem vice.
translation: God will, perhaps, by some propitious change, restore these matters to their former state.

quotation: Dies irae, dies illa, Saeclum solvet in favilla Teste David cum Sibylla.
translation: The day of wrath, that dreadful day, The world in ashes all shall lay — This David and the Sibyl say.
notes: These are the commencing lines of the Sequence used by the Romish Church in the Office of the Dead. The authorship of this hymn, which is of considerable beauty, does not seem to be positively known. It has been attributed to Thomas de Celano, a Minorite friar of the fourteenth century, but, more generally, to Frangipani, Cardinal Malabrancia.

quotation: Donec eris felix multos numerabis amicos; Tempora si fuerint nubila, solus eris.
translation: So long as you are prosperous you will reckon many friends; if the times become cloudy, you will be alone.

quotation: Dies, ni fallor, adest, quem semper acerbum, Semper honoratum, sic Di voluistis, habebo.
translation: The day, if I mistake not, is at hand, which I shall always account a day of sorrow, always a day to be honoured, such, ye gods, has been your will.

quotation: Donum exitiale Minervae.
translation: The fatal gift of Minerva.
notes: The wooden horse, by means of which the Greeks gained possession of Troy.

quotation: Deus id vult.
translation: It is the will of God.
notes: The cry of the Crusaders at the siege of Jerusalem.

quotation: Dies non (juridicus).
translation: No legal day.
notes: A day on which the courts are closed, and no law proceedings are going on, which is therefore called "no day." Such days were by the Romans called "nefasti." Sunday is a dies non in law. See Dies Dominicus, &c.

quotation: Dormiunt aliquando leges, nunquam moriuntur.
translation: The law sometimes sleeps, it never dies.
notes: It is not so much the law that sleeps, as those who ought to put it in force; often from a sense of the impolicy of asserting their legal  rights to the very letter.

quotation: Deus misereatur nobis.
translation: God be merciful unto us.
notes: The beginning of the 67th Psalm.

quotation: Dies si in obligationibus non ponitur, praesente die debetur.
translation: If a day for payment is not stated in a bond, the money is due on the day on which it is executed.

quotation: Dos est magna parentum Virtus.
translation: The virtue of one's parents is a great dowry.

quotation: Deus nobis haec otia fecit.
translation: God has granted unto us this repose.

quotation: Dies solemnes.
translation: Holidays

quotation: Deus omnibus quod sat est suppeditat.
translation: God supplies enough to all.
notes: Because God alone is properly the judge of what is enough.

quotation: Duabus anchoris nititur.
translation: She is held by two anchors.
notes: So our saying, "He has two strings to his bow."

quotation: Difficile custoditur quod plures amant.
translation: That is preserved with difficulty which many covet.

quotation: Dextras dare.
translation: To give the right hands to each other.
notes: An assurance of mutual friendship, or at least of security, because two right hands, when clasped, cannot conceal any weapon.

quotation: Dubiam salutem qui dat afflictis, negat.
translation: He who gives to the afflicted a dubious support, denies it.
notes: Such support is deprived of its grace, if not of its efficacy.

quotation: Difficile est, fateor, sed tendit in ardua virtus.
translation: It is difficult, I confess; but true courage seeks obstacles.

quotation: Dextro tempore.
translation: At a propitious time.
notes: At a lucky moment.

quotation: Duc me, Parens, celsique dominator poli, Quocunque placuit; nulla parendi mora est; Adsum impiger.
translation: Conduct me, Parent of all, and ruler over the lofty heavens, wherever it pleases thee; in obeying thee I make no delay; I am ever ready at thy command.

quotation: Difficile est longum subito deponere amorem.
translation: It is difficult to relinquish on a sudden a long cherished love.

quotation: Di bene fecerunt, inopis me quodque pusilli Finxerunt animi, raro et perpauca loquentis.
translation: The gods have dealt kindly with me, since they have framed me of an humble and meek disposition, speaking but seldom and briefly.

quotation: Duces tecum.
translation: Bring with you.
notes: A writ which commands a person to appear in court on a certain day, and bring with him certain writings or evidences.

quotation: Difficile est mutare animum, et si quid est penitur insitum moribus, id subito evellere.
translation: It is difficult to alter the disposition, and, if there is anything deeply implanted in our nature, suddenly to root it out.

quotation: Ducimus autem Hos quoque felices, qui, ferre incommoda vitae, Nec jactare jugum, vita didicere magistra.
translation: We consider those men happy, who, from their experience in life, have learned to bear its inconveniences without struggling against the yoke.

quotation: Difficile est plurimum virtutem revereri, qui semper secunda fortuna sit usus.
translation: It is difficult for him to have a very high respect for virtue, who has enjoyed uninterrupted prosperity.
notes: It is doubted if the four Books on Rhetoric, dedicated to Herennius, are the composition of Cicero.

quotation: Ducis ingenium, res Adversae nudare solent, celare secundae.
translation: Disasters are wont to reveal the abilities of a general, good fortune to conceal them.
notes: Hence the most consummate abilities of a general are shown in a masterly retreat.

quotation: Di bene vertant, tene crumenam.
translation: May the gods send luck — take the purse.

quotation: Difficile est satiram non scribere.
translation: It is hard to avoid writing satire.
notes: This was especially true in reference to the corrupt age in which Juvenal lived.

quotation: Di immortales, obsecro, aurum quid valet.
translation: Immortal gods, I do beseech you, how powerful is gold!

quotation: Ducunt volentem fata, nolentem trahunt.
translation: Fate leads the willing, and the unwilling drags.
notes: From the Greek of Cleanthes, in Seneca, Epistle 107.

quotation: Difficile est temperare felicitati, qua te non putes diu usurum.
translation: It is difficult to enjoy with moderation the happiness, which we suppose we shall not long enjoy.

quotation: Di laneos pedes habent.
translation: The gods have feet made of wool.
notes: The judgments of Providence overtake us silently, and when we least expect them.

quotation: Dulce domum.
translation: Sweet home.
notes: A Latin song is thus called, which is sung at Winchester College, on the evening preceding the Whitsun holidays.

quotation: Difficilem oportet aurem habere ad crimina.
translation: One should be slow in giving ear to accusations.

quotation: Dulce est desipere in loco.
translation: It is pleasant to play the fool on the proper occasion.
notes: As there is "a time for everything," there is a time for merriment and relaxation.

quotation: Difficilia quae pulchra.
translation: The best things are worst to come by.

quotation: Dulce est miseris socios habuisse doloris.
translation: It is a comfort for the wretched to have companions in their sorrow.

quotation: Difficilis, facilis, jucundus, acerbus es idem; Nee tecum possum vivere, nec sine te.
translation: Crabbed but kind, pleasant and sour together, I can neither live with you nor yet without you.

quotation: Dulce et decorum est pro patria mori.
translation: It is sweet and glorious to die for one's country.

quotation: Difficilis, querulus, laudator temporis acti.
translation: Peevish, complaining, the praiser of by-gone times.
notes: A natural and not unamiable feature, if not carried to an extreme.

quotation: Dulces moriens reminiscitur Argos.
translation: And, as he dies, his thoughts revert to his dear Argos.

quotation: Difficulter continetur spiritus, Integritatis qui sincerae conscius, A noxiorum premitur insolentiis.
translation: The mind is with difficulty restrained, which, conscious of unsullied integrity, is exposed to the insults of spiteful men.

quotation: Difficulter reciduntur vitia quae nobiscum creverunt.
translation: Vices which have grown with our growth are with difficulty lopped away.

quotation: Dulcibus est verbis alliciendus amor.
translation: Love must be allured with kind words.

quotation: Diffugiunt, cadis Cum faece siccatis, amici Ferre jugum pariter dolosi.
translation: Friends too faithless to bear equally the yoke of adversity, when the casks are emptied to the very dregs, fly off in all directions.

quotation: Dulcior est fructus post multa pericula ductus.
translation: The fruit is sweetest that is gained after many perils.
notes: A Leonine proverb quoted by Rabelais, "Stolen fruit is the sweetest."

quotation: Dignior est vestro nulla puella choro.
translation: No maiden, (Muses,) is more worthy of your choir.

quotation: Dulcique animos novitate tenebo.
translation: And I will enthral your mind with the charms of novelty.

quotation: Dignum laude virum Musa vetat mori.
translation: The Muse forbids the man who is worthy of praise to die.

quotation: Dulcis amor patriae, dulce videre suos.
translation: Sweet is the love of one's country, sweet to behold one's kindred.

quotation: Dignum patella operculum.
translation: A cover worthy of the pot.
notes: What better could be expected of one coming of such a stock?

quotation: Dulcis inexpertis cultura potentis amici; Expertus metuit.
translation: Worship of the great is pleasant to those who are inexperienced in the world, but he who has gained experience dreads dependence.

quotation: Dignum sapiente, bonoque est.
translation: 'Tis worthy a wise man, and a good.

quotation: Dum Aurora fulget, moniti adolescentes, flores colligite.
translation: Take my advice, my young friends, and gather flowers while the morning shines.
notes: Employ the hours of sunshine, for "when the night cometh, no man can work."

quotation: Diis aliter visum.
translation: It has seemed otherwise to the gods.

quotation: Dum bene dives ager; dum rami pondere nutant, Afferat in calatho rustica dona puer.
translation: While the country is bountifully rich, while the branches are bending beneath their load, let the boy bring your country presents in his basket.

quotation: Diis proximus ille est Quem ratio, non ira movet, qui facta rependens Consilio punire potest.
translation: He is nearest to the gods, whom reason, not passion, influences; and who, weighing the circumstances, can inflict punishment with discretion.

quotation: Dum caput infestat, labor omnia membra molestat.
translation: While the head aches, weariness oppresses all the limbs.

quotation: Dilationes in lege sunt odiosae.
translation: Delays in the law are odious.

quotation: Dum curae ambiguae, dum spes incerta futuri.
translation: While I am immersed in doubtful care, with uncertain hopes of the future.

quotation: Diligere parentes prima naturae lex est.
translation: To love one's parents is the first law of nature.

quotation: Diligimus omnia vera, id est fidelia, simplicia, constantia; vana, falsa, fallentia odimus.
translation: We (naturally) love all qualities that are genuine, that is, that are faithful, frank, and constant; such as are vain, fickle, and deceitful, we abhor.

quotation: Diligitur nemo, nisi cui Fortuna secunda est, Quae, simul intonuit, proxima quaeque fugat.
translation: No one is beloved, but the man to whom Fortune is favourable; soon as she thunders, she chases away all that are near.

quotation: Dimidium facti, qui coepit, habet.
translation: He who has made a beginning, has half done.
notes: This is sometimes quoted "bene coepit." So our old proverb, "Well begun is half done."

quotation: Dimidium plus toto.
translation: The half is more than the whole.
notes: Meaning that the half which we have with safety, is better than the whole when only to bo obtained with danger. A translation from Hesiod.

quotation: Dum deliberamus quando incipiendum, incipere jam serum fit.
translation: While we are deliberating when to begin, it becomes too late to begin.
notes: See Deliberat, &c.

quotation: Diruit, aedificat, mutat quadrata rotundis.
translation: He pulls down, he builds up again, he changes square for round.
notes: Descriptive of a restless love of change.

quotation: Dum fata fugimus, fata stulti incurrimus.
translation: While we fly from our fate, like fools we rush on to it.

quotation: Dum fata sinunt vivite laeti.
translation: So long as the Fates permit, live in cheerfulness.

quotation: Dum flammas Jovis et sonitus imitatur Olympi.
translation: While he imitates the flames of Jove, and the lightnings of Olympus.

quotation: Dum in dubio est animus, paulo momento huc illuc impellitur.
translation: While the mind is in suspense, it is swayed by a slight impulse one way or the other.

quotation: Dum lego, assentior.
translation: Whilst I read, I assent.
notes: The exclamation of Cicero, while reading Plato's reasoning on the immortality of the soul.

quotation: Di melius, quam nos moneamus talia quenquam.
translation: May the gods forbid that I should advise any one to follow such a course.

quotation: Dum licet, in rebus jucundis vive beatus, Vive memor quam sis aevi brevis.
translation: While you have the power, live contented with happy circumstances, live mindful how short is life.
notes: See Dum vivimus, &c.

quotation: Di nobis laboribus omnia vendunt.
translation: The gods sell us everything for our labours.

quotation: Di nos quasi pilas homines habent.
translation: The gods treat us men like balls.

quotation: Di, quibus imperium est animarum, umbraeque silentes, Et Chaos, et Phlegethon, loca nocte tacentia late; Sit mihi fas audita loqui! sit numine vestro Pandere res alta terra et caligine mersas.
translation: Ye gods, to whom belongs the empire of the ghosts, and ye silent shades, and Chaos, and Phlegethon, places where silence reigns around in night! permit me to utter the secrets I have heard; may I by your divine will disclose things buried deep in the earth and darkness.

quotation: Di talem terris avertite pestem.
translation: Ye gods, avert from the earth such a scourge.

quotation: Dum loquor, hora fugit.
translation: While I am speaking, time flies.

quotation: Di tibi dent annos! a te nam caetera sumes; Sint modo virtuti tempora longa tuae.
translation: May the gods grant thee length of years! All other blessings from thyself thou wilt derive, let only time be granted for thy virtues.

quotation: Dum ne ob malefacta peream, parvi aestimo.
translation: So I do not die for my misdeeds, I care but little.

quotation: Di tibi sint faciles; et opis nullius egentem Fortunam praestent, dissimilemque meae.
translation: May the gods be propitious to thee; may they also grant thee a fate that needs the aid of no one, and quite unlike to mine.

quotation: Dic mihi, cras istud, Posthume, quando veniet?
translation: Tell, me, Posthumus, when will this to-morrow arrive?
notes: Said to a procrastinating friend.

quotation: Dic mihi, si fias tu leo, qualis eris?
translation: Tell me, if you were a lion, what sort of one would you be?
notes: No man should speak too positively as to how he would conduct himself under a total change of circumstances and position.

quotation: Dum potuit solita gemitum virtute repressit.
translation: So long as he is able, he suppresses his groans with his wonted fortitude.
notes: Said of Hercules when he has put on the fatal garment sent him by his wife.

quotation: Dicam insigne, recens adhuc Indictum ore alio.
translation: I shall record a remarkable event, which is new as yet, and untold by the lips of another.

quotation: Dum recitas incipit esse tuus.
translation: As you recite it, it begins to be your own.
notes: See Mutato nomine, &c.

quotation: Dicebam, Medicare tuos desiste capillos: Tingere quam possis, jam tibi nulla coma est.
translation: I used to say — Do leave off doctoring your Hair; and now you have no hair left for you to dye.

quotation: Dum se bene gesserit.
translation: So long as he conducts himself well.
notes: During good behaviour." The tenure upon which some official situations are held.

quotation: Dicenda, tacenda locutus.
translation: Speaking of things to be mentioned and to be kept silence upon.

quotation: Dum singuli pugnant, universi vincuntur.
translation: While each is fighting separately, the whole are conquered.
notes: The Britons, being divided among themselves by the jealousies of their petty nations, and having no centre of action, were more easily conquered by the Romans than if they had acted in concert.

quotation: Dicenda tacendaque calles?
translation: Dost thou understand when to speak, and when to hold thy tongue?

quotation: Dicere quae puduit, scribere jussit amor.
translation: What I was ashamed to say, love has commanded me to write.

quotation: Dum spiro, spero.
translation: While I breathe I hope.

quotation: Dicetur merita nox quoque naenia.
translation: The night too shall be celebrated in an appropriate lay.

quotation: Dum tacent, clamant.
translation: While silent, they cry aloud.
notes: Their silence is expressive of their smothered discontent.

quotation: Dum vires annique sinunt, tolerate labores: Jam veniet tacito curva senecta pede.
translation: While strength and years permit, endure labour; soon will bowed old age come on with silent foot.

quotation: Dum vitant stulti vitia, in contraria currunt.
translation: While fools are for avoiding one fault, they run into the opposite one.

quotation: Dum vivimus, vivamus.
translation: While we live, let us live.
notes: Let us enjoy life, for existence without enjoyment is not living. This was the maxim of the Epicureans. From an ancient inscription in Gruter, p. 609. See Dum licet, &c.

quotation: Ea sola voluptas Solamenque mali.
translation: That was his only delight, and the solace of his misfortune.

quotation: Dum vivit, hominem noveris; ubi mortuus est, quiescas.
translation: While he is alive, you may know a person; when he is dead, keep yourself quiet.

quotation: Ea sub oculis posita negligimus; proximorum incuriosi, longinqua sectamur.
translation: Those things which are placed under our eyes, we overlook; indifferent as to what is near us, we long for that which is distant.
notes: The traveller abroad overlooks the beauties of his own country. 'Tis distance lends enchantment to the view.

quotation: Dummodo morata recte veniat, dotata est satis.
translation: So long as a woman comes with good principles, she is sufficiently portioned.

quotation: Dummodo sit dives, barbarus ipse placet.
translation: If he be only rich, a very barbarian is pleasing.

quotation: Ecce homo.
translation: Behold the man.
notes: The title given to pictures of our Saviour, wearing the crown of thorns and the purple robe — when Pilate said, "Behold the man," John xix. 5.

quotation: Disce aut discede.
translation: Learn or depart.
notes: A punning motto sometimes put up in school-rooms.

quotation: Ecce iterum Crispinus!
translation: Behold! Crispinus once again!
notes: A notorious debauchee and favourite of the emperor Domitian, whom Juvenal has occasion more than once to make the object of his satire.

quotation: Disce docendus adhuc, quae censet amiculus, ut si Caecus iter monstrare velit; tamen aspice si quid Et nos quod cures proprium fecisse loquamur.
translation: Hear what are the sentiments of your humble friend, who himself still requires teaching just as much as a blind man who undertakes to show the way; however, see if even I can advance anything which you may think it worth your while to adopt as your own.

quotation: Ecquem esse dices in mari piscem meum?
translation: Of which fish in the sea can you say, 'That is mine?'

quotation: Disce, puer, virtutem ex me, verumque laborem, Fortunam ex aliis.
translation: Learn, my son, valour and real exertion from me, good fortune from others.
notes: The words of Aeneas to Iulus, when the former was about to engage Turnus in single combat.

quotation: Edepol nae hic dies pervorsus et advorsus mihi obtigit.
translation: Upon my word, this day certainly has turned out both perverse and adverse for me.

quotation: Discipulus est prioris posterior dies.
translation: The day that follows is the scholar of that which has gone before.

quotation: Edere non poteris vocem, lupus est tibi visus.
translation: You cannot utter a word, you have surely seen a wolf.
notes: It was said that the wolf, by some secret power, deprived of their voice those who beheld it. See Lupus in fabula.

quotation: Discit enim citius, meminitque libentius illud Quod quis deridet quam quod probat et veneratur.
translation: Each learns more readily, and retains more willingly, that which causes laughter than that which merits his approbation and respect.
notes: The poet here censures that love of scandal which prevails unfortunately among all grades and classes.

quotation: Edere oportet ut vivas, non vivere ut edas.
translation: You ought to eat to live, not live to eat.

quotation: Discite justitiam moniti et non temnere divos.
translation: Learn justice from my advice, and not to despise the gods.
notes: The words of one who spoke from bitter experience, and when repentance was too late.

quotation: Edvardum occidere nolite timere bonum est.
notes: The ambiguous message penned by Adam Orleton, bishop of Hereford, and sent by Queen Isabella to the gaolers of her husband, Edward II. Being written without punctuation, the words might be read two ways; with a comma after timere, they would mean, "Edward to kill fear not, the deed is good;" but, with it after nolite, the meaning would be, "Edward kill not, to fear the deed is good."

quotation: Discrepant facta cum dictis.
translation: The facts differ from the statement.

quotation: Duobus modis, id est aut fraude aut vi, fit injuria — fraus quasi vulepeculae, vis leonis videtur — utrumque ab homine alienissimum est.
translation: Injury is done by two methods, either by deceit or by violence; deceit appears to be the attribute of the fox, violence of the lion; both of them most foreign to man.

quotation: Disjecti membra poetae.
translation: The limbs of the dismembered poet.

quotation: Effodiuntur opes irritamenta malorum.
translation: Riches, the incentives of evil, are dug out of the earth.

quotation: Duos qui sequitur lepores neutrum capit.
translation: He who follows two hares catches neither.
notes: So our saying, "Between two stools," &c.

quotation: Effugit mortem quisquis contemserit, timidissimum quemque consequitur.
translation: He who despises death, escapes it; while the most cowardly it overtakes.

quotation: Effutire leves indigna tragoedia versus, Ut festis matrona moveri jussa diebus.
translation: Tragedy disdains to babble forth trivial verses, like a matron challenged to dance on festive days.

quotation: Duplex omnino est jocandi genus: unum illiberale, petulans, flagitiosum, obscoenum; alterum, elegans, urbanum, ingeniosum, facetum.
translation: There are two sorts of pleasantry: the one ungentlemanly, wanton, flagitious, obscene; the other elegant, courteous, ingenious, and facetious.

quotation: Ego apros occido, sed alter utitur pulpamento.
translation: I kill the boars, while another enjoys the flesh.
notes: I beat the bush, another catches the hare." A proverb used by the Emperor Diocletian. See Sic vos, &c.

quotation: Ego consuetudinem sermonis vocabo consensum eruditorum; sicut vivendi consensum bonorum.
translation: I shall consider the style of speaking adopted by men of education, as the model of correct language; as I do the example of good men the model of our conduct through life.

quotation: Dura Exerce imperia, et ramos compesce fluentes.
translation: Exert a rigorous sway, and check the straggling boughs.

quotation: Ego ero post principia.
translation: I will be behind the first rank.
notes: I will get out of harm's way.

quotation: Durante beneplacito.
translation: During our good pleasure.
notes: The tenure by which most official situations are held in this country.

quotation: Ego et rex meus.
translation: I and my king.
notes: An expression attributed to Cardinal Wolsey. Though apparently egotistical and haughty, correct Latin would not admit of any other form.

quotation: Disjice compositam pacem, sere crimina belli.
translation: Cast aside this patched-up peace, sow the evils of war.
notes: The address of Juno to the Fury Alecto, when prompting her to "let slip the dogs of war."

quotation: Durante vita.
translation: During life.

quotation: Ego haec mecum mussito, Bona mea inhiant; certatim dona mittunt et munera.
translation: I mutter this to myself — 'They are gaping after my property, while, vying with each other, they are thus sending me gifts and presents.'

quotation: Dissimile est, pecuniae debitis et gratiae.
translation: There is a difference between the owing of money and of gratitude.

quotation: Ego ita comperio omnia regna, civitates, nationes, usque eo prosperum imperium habuisse, dum apud eos vera consilia valuerunt.
translation: I find that all kingdoms, states, and nations have enjoyed prosperity, so long as good counsels have had influence in their affairs.

quotation: Ego nec studium sine divite vena, Nec rude quid prosit video ingenium.
translation: For my part, I can neither conceive what study can do without a rich natural vein, nor what rude genius can avail of itself.

quotation: Ego — quod te laudas, vehementer probo, Namque hoc ab alio nunquam continget tibi.
translation: I greatly approve of your bestowing praise on yourself, for it will never be your lot to receive if from another.
notes: The answer of Aesop to a wretched author, who praised himself.

quotation: Ego, si bonam famam mihi servasso, sat ero dives.
translation: If I keep a good character for myself, I shall be quite rich enough.

quotation: Ego si risi, quod ineptus Pastillos Rufillus olet, Gargonius hircum, Lividus et mordax videor tibi?
translation: If I laugh at the silly Rufillus, because he smells of perfumes, or at Gargonius, because he stinks like a he-goat, am I to be thought envious and carping?

quotation: Ego spem pretio non emo.
translation: I will not purchase hope with gold.
notes: I will not throw away what is of value upon empty hopes.

quotation: Egregii mortalem, altique silenti.
translation: Egregii mortalem, altique silenti.

quotation: Eheu! fugaces, Posthume, Posthume, Labuntur anni; nee pietas moram Rugis et instanti senectae Afferet, indomitaeque morti.
translation: Alas! Posthumus, Posthumus, our years pass away, nor can piety stay wrinkles, and approaching old age, and unconquerable death.

quotation: Dissolve frigus, ligna super foco Large reponens, atque benignius Deprome quadrimum Sabina, O Thaliarche, merum diota.
translation: Dispel the cold, by heaping logs in plenty on the hearth, and bountifully pour, Thaliarchus, the wine of four years old from the Sabine jar.

quotation: Eheu! quam brevibus pereunt ingentia causis!
translation: Alas! by what trifling causes are great states overthrown!
notes: or, as Pope says, "What mighty contests spring from trivial things!"

quotation: Eheu! quam pingui macer est mihi taurus in arvo, Idem amor exitium pecori est, pecorisque magistro.
translation: Alas! how lean is my bull amid the rich pastures! love is equally the destruction of the cattle, and of the cattle's master.

quotation: Distat opus nostrum; sed fontibus exit ab isdem; Artis et ingenuae cultor uterque sumus.
translation: Our pursuits are different; but they arise from the same source, and each of us is the cultivator of a liberal art.

quotation: Eheu! Quam temere in nosmet legem sancimus iniquam! Nam vitiis nemo sine nascitur; optimus ille est, Qui minimis urgetur.
translation: Alas! how rashly do we sanction severe rules against ourselves, for no man is born without faults; he is the best who is subject to the fewest.

quotation: Distrahit animum librorum multitudo.
translation: A multitude of books distracts the mind.
notes: A hint to dilettanti students.

quotation: Eja, age, rumpe moras, quo te spectabimus usque? Dum quid sis dubitas, jam potes esse nihil.
translation: Come then, away with this delay, how long are we to be looking at you? While you are in doubt what to be, presently it will be out of your power to be anything at all.

quotation: Districtus ensis cui semper impia Cervice pendet, non Siculae dapes Dulcem elaborabunt saporem, Non avium citharaeque cantus Somnum reducent.
translation: Sicilian dainties will not force a delicious relish for the man over whose impious neck ever hangs the naked sword; the songs of birds and of the lyre will not restore his sleep.

quotation: Elati animi comprimendi sunt.
translation: Minds which are too much elated must be humbled.

quotation: Distringas.
translation: You may distrain.
notes: A writ issued to the sheriff, commanding him to distrain.

quotation: Elegit.
translation: He has chosen.
notes: A writ of execution that lies for one who has recovered a debt, to levy from a moiety of the defendant's lands: while holding which moiety the creditor is tenant by elegit.

quotation: Diversum vitio vitium prope majus.
translation: To this vice there is an opposite vice, almost the greater of the two.

quotation: Elephantem ex musca facis.
translation: You are making an elephant of a fly.

quotation: Elephantus non capit murem.
translation: The elephant does not catch mice.
notes: Some annoyances are beneath our notice. See Aquila non, &c.

quotation: Elige eum cujus tibi placuit et vita et oratio.
translation: Make choice of him whose mode of living and whose conversation are pleasing to you.

quotation: Eligito tempus, captatum saepe, rogandi.
translation: Choose your time for asking, after having often watched for it.

quotation: Elocutio est idoneorum verborum et sententiarum ad rem inventam accommodatio.
translation: Elocution is an apt accommodation of the words and sentiments to the subject under discussion.

quotation: Dives agris, dives positis in foenore nummis.
translation: Rich in lands, rich in money placed out at interest.

quotation: Eloquentia non modo eos ornat, penes quos est, sed etium universam rempublicam.
translation: Eloquence is not only an ornament to those who possess it, but even to the whole community.

quotation: Emax foemina.
translation: A woman who is always buying.
notes: A lover of bargains.

quotation: Dives amicus Saepe decem vitiis instructior, odit et horret.
translation: Your rich friend who has many a time been initiated into ten times as many vices as you have, hates and abhors you (for yours).
notes: He sees the mote in your eye, and takes no thought of the beam in his own.

quotation: Emere malo quam rogare.
translation: Better to have to buy than to beg.
notes: Because in the former case there is no obligation.

quotation: Emitur sola virtute potestas.
translation: (True) power is purchased by virtue alone.

quotation: Dives aut iniquus est, aut iniqui haeres.
translation: A rich man is either a knave, or the heir of a knave.
notes: As illiberal as the English adage: "It is a saying, common more than civil, The son is blest, whose sire is at the devil."

quotation: Empta dolore docet experientia.
translation: Experience bought by pain teaches us a lesson.

quotation: Dives eram dudum, fecerunt me tria nudum, Alea, vina, Venus, per quae sum factus egenus.
translation: I was rich of late; three things have made me poor, gaming, wine, and women; through these have I been brought to want.
notes: Leonine rhymes of the middle ages.

quotation: Emunctae naris homo.
translation: A man of sharp nose.
notes: One of quick perception.

quotation: Dives qui fieri vult, Et cito vult fieri.
translation: The man who is anxious to become rich, is anxious to become so with all speed.

quotation: En! hie declarat, quales sitis judices.
translation: Look! This shows what sort of judges you are.

quotation: Divide et impera.
translation: Divide and rule.
notes: Not a Christian precept, but one which has been often acted upon by successful politicians.

quotation: Divisum sic breve fiet opus.
translation: Thus divided, the work will become short.
notes: All difficulties are to be surmounted by method.

quotation: Divitiae grandes homini sunt, vivere parce Aequo animo.
translation: It is great wealth to a man, to live frugally, with a contented mind.

quotation: Eo crassior aer est, quo terris propior.
translation: The air is the more dense, the nearer it is to the earth.

quotation: Divitiae virum faciunt.
translation: Money makes the man.
notes: It is fortunate that this is not universally the case, and that

quotation: Eo instanti.
translation: At that instant.

quotation: Eo magis praefulgebat quod non videbatur.
translation: He shone with all the greater lustre, because he was not seen.
notes: Said of a great man whose statue was insidiously removed from public view.

quotation: Eodem collyrio mederi omnibus.
translation: To heal all with the same ointment.
notes: To use the same argument, or adopt the same course, with persons of all ages and classes.

quotation: Divitiarum acquisitio magni laboris, possessio magni timoris, amissio magni doloris.
translation: The gaining of wealth is a work of great labour; the possession, a source of great apprehension; the loss, a cause of great grief.

quotation: Eodem modo quo quid constituitur eodem modo dissolvitur.
translation: In the same manner in which an agreement is made, it is dissolved.
notes: If made by deed, it must be dissolved by deed.

quotation: Durate, et vosmet rebus servate secundis.
translation: Persevere, and reserve yourselves for better times.

quotation: Divitiarum et formae gloria fluxa atque fragilis; virtus clara aeternaque habetur.
translation: The glory of wealth and of beauty is fleeting and unsubstantial; virtue is brilliant and everlasting.

quotation: Epicuri de grege porcum.
translation: One of the swinish herd of Epicurus.

quotation: Eques ipso melior Bellerophonte.
translation: A better horseman than Bellerophon himself.
notes: Bellerophon was master of the winged horse Pegasus.

quotation: Equo fraenato est auris in ore.
translation: The ear of a bridled horse is in his mouth.
notes: He is guided by the bit, not by words.

quotation: Equitis quoque jam migravit ab aure voluptas Omnis, ad incertos oculos, et gaudia vana.
translation: In these days, our knights have transferred all pleasure from the hearing to the eyes that may deceive, and frivolous amusements.
notes: The poet rebukes the Roman equites for their love of the shows of the Circus and the amphitheatre.

quotation: Durum et durum non faciunt murum.
translation: Hard and hard do not make a wall.
notes: A mediaeval proverb. As bricks require a soft substance to unite them, so proud men will never agree without the mediation of a mild and equable disposition.

quotation: Dixerit e multis aliquis, Quid virus in angues Adjicis? et rabidae tradis ovile lupae?
translation: One of the multitude may say, "Why add venom to the serpent ? And why deliver the sheepfold to the ravening wolf?"

quotation: Dixero quid si forte jocosius, hoc mihi juris Cum venia dabis.
translation: If perchance I shall speak a little jocosely, you will kindly allow me that privilege.

quotation: Durum! Sed levius fit patientia Quicquid corrigere est nefas.
translation: 'Tis hard! But that which it is not allowed us to amend, is rendered more light by patience.

quotation: Equus Seianus.
translation: The horse of Seius.
notes: Cneius Seius, a Roman citizen, possessed a horse of singular size and beauty, and supposed to be sprung from those of Diomedes, king of Thrace. Seius was put to death by Antony, and the horse was bought for a large price by Cornelius Dolabella. He in his turn was conquered by Cassius, and fell in battle; upon which the horse came into the hands of Cassius. He slaying himself on being defeated by Antony, the horse came into Antony's possession; who was afterwards defeated by Augustus, and put himself to death. The possession of this horse was considered so disastrous to its owner, that "The horse of Seius" became a proverbial expression for a thing that was supposed to bring ill luck.

quotation: Dociles imitandis Turpibus et pravis omnes sumus.
translation: We are all apt scholars in learning that which is base and depraved.

quotation: Durum telum necessitas.
translation: Necessity is a sharp weapon.

quotation: Erant in officio, sed tamen qui mallent imperantium mandata interpretari, quam exsequi.
translation: They attended to their duties, but still as preferring rather to cavil at the commands of their rulers, than to obey them.
notes: Quoted by Lord Bacon in his Essays.

quotation: Docti non solum vivi atque praesentes studiosos dicendi erudiunt, atque docent; sed hoc etiam post mortem monimentis literarum assequuntur.
translation: Learned men not only teach and instruct others desirous to learn during their life, and while they are still with us, but, even after death, they do the same by the records of literature which they leave behind them.

quotation: Dux foemina facti.
translation: A woman the leader in the deed.
notes: Said in reference to the valour and enterprise of Queen Dido.

quotation: Erant quibus appetentior famae videretur, quando sapientibus cupldo gloriae novissima exuitur.
translation: There were some to whom he seemed too greedy of fame, at a time when the desire of glory, that last of all desires, is by the wise laid aside.
notes: Milton was probably indebted to this passage for his line on ambition, "That last infirmity of noble minds."

quotation: Docti rationem artis intelligunt, indocti voluptatem.
translation: Learned men understand the principles of art, the unlearned have a perception of the pleasure only.

quotation: E contra.
translation: On the other hand.

quotation: Doctrina est ingenii naturale quoddam pabulum.
translation: Learning is as it were the natural food of the mind.

quotation: E debito justitiae.
notes: See Debito justitiae.

quotation: E flamma cibum petere.
translation: To seek one's food in the very flames.
notes: Only the most abject and wretched would pick from out of the flames of the funeral pile the articles of food, which, in conformity with the Roman usage, were thrown there.

quotation: Ergo haud difficile est perituram arcessere summam, Lancibus oppositis, vel matris imagine fracta.
translation: Therefore there is no scruple in borrowing a sum, soon to be squandered, by pawning their plate, or the battered likeness of their mother.

quotation: E multis paleis, paulum fructus collegi.
translation: From much straw I have gathered but little fruit.
notes: "Much straw, but little grain." With much labour I have obtained but little profit.

quotation: Eripe te morae.
translation: Away with all delay.

quotation: Eripe turpi Colla jugo. Liber, liber sum, dic age.
translation: Rescue your neck from this vile yoke; come, say, I am free, I am free.

quotation: Eripite isti gladium, qui sui est impos animi.
translation: Take away the sword from him who is not in possesion of his senses.

quotation: E se finxit velut araneus.
translation: He spun from himself like a spider.
notes: He depended solely on his own resources.

quotation: Eripit interdum, modo dat medicina salutem.
translation: Medicine sometimes takes away health, sometimes bestows it.

quotation: E tardigradis asinis equus non prodiit.
translation: The horse does not spring from the slow-paced ass.
notes: Worthy children cannot be expected to spring from degenerate parents.

quotation: Eripuit coelo fulmen, sceptrumque tyrannis.
translation: He snatched the lightning from heaven, and the sceptre from tyrants.
notes: This line, an adaptation of one from Manilius, was inscribed by the French minister Turgot on a medal struck in honour of Benjamin Franklin. The allusion is to his discovery that lightning is produced by electricity, and to the support which he gave to his country in the assertion of its independence of the British crown. See Solvitque animis, &c.

quotation: Erramus si ullam terrarum partem immunem a periculo credimus.
translation: We are mistaken if we believe that there is any part of the world free from danger.

quotation: E tenui casa saepe vir magnus exit.
translation: From an humble cottage a hero often springs.

quotation: Errantem in viam reducito.
translation: Bring back him who has strayed, into the right way.
notes: The duty of the pastor of the flock.

quotation: E terrae cavernis ferrum elicimus, rem ad colendos agros necessarium.
translation: We draw forth iron from the depths of the earth, a thing necessary for cultivating the flelds.

quotation: Errat, et illinc Huc venit, hinc illuc, et quoslibet occupat artus Spiritus; eque feris humana in corpora transit, Inque feras noster.
translation: The soul wanders about and comes from that spot to this, from this to that, and takes possession of any limbs it may; it both passes from the beasts into human bodies, and from us into the beasts.
notes: The Pythagorean doctrine of the transmigration of the soul.

quotation: Est animus tibi Rerumque prudens, et secundis Temporibus dubiisque rectus.
translation: You have a mind endowed with prudence in the affairs of life, and upright, as well in prosperity as in adversity.

quotation: Ea animi elatio quae cernitur in periculis, si justitia vacat, pugnatque pro suis commodis, in vitio est.
translation: That elevation of mind which is to be seen in moments of peril, if it is uncontrolled by justice, and strives only for its own advantages, becomes a crime.

quotation: Est aviditas dives, et pauper pudor.
translation: Covetousness is rich, while modesty starves.

quotation: Ea fama vagatur.
translation: That report is in circulation.
notes: There is a report to that effect.

quotation: Est bonus ut melior vir Non alius quisquam.
translation: He is so good a man, that no one can be better.

quotation: Esse bonum facile est, ubi quod vetet esse remotum est.
translation: It is easy to be good, when that which would forbid it is afar off.
notes: It is easy to be virtuous when we are not exposed to temptation.

quotation: Ea quoniam nemini obtrudi potest, Itur ad me.
translation: Because she cannot be pushed off on any one else, they come to me.

quotation: Est brevitas opus, ut currat sententia.
translation: There is need of conciseness that the sentence may run agreeably.

quotation: Esse quam videri malim.
translation: I would rather be, than seem to be.

quotation: Est demum vera felicitas, felicitate dignum videri.
translation: The truest happiness, in fine, consists in the consciousness that you are deserving of happiness.

quotation: Esse quoque in Fatis reminiscitur affore tempus Quo mare, quo tellus, correptaque regia coeli Ardeat; et mundi moles operosa laboret.
translation: He remembers too that it was in the decrees of fate, that a time should come when the sea, the earth, and the palace of heaven, seized by the flames, should be burnt; and the laboriously-wrought fabric of the universe should be in danger of perishing.
notes: So we read in Scripture, "But the day of the Lord will come as a thief in the night; in which the heavens shall pass away with a great noise, and the elements shall melt with fervent heat, the earth also, and the works that are therein, shall be burnt up." 2 Pet. iii.

quotation: Est egentissimus in sua re.
translation: He is much straitened in circumstances.

quotation: Est etiam miseris pietas, et in hoste probatur.
translation: Towards the wretched there is a duty, and even in an enemy it is praised.

quotation: Esse solent magno damna minora bono.
translation: Trivial losses are often of great benefit.

quotation: Est etiam, ubi profecto damnum praestet facere, quam lucrum.
translation: There are occasions when it is undoubtedly better to make loss than gain.

quotation: Est amicus socius mensae, et non permanebit in die necessitatis.
translation: Some friend is a companion at the table, and will not continue in the day of thy affliction.
notes: Ecclus. vi. 10. This, however, is only said of the class of so-called friends.

quotation: Est hic, Est ubi vis, animus si te non deficit aequus.
translation: [Happiness] is to be found here, it is everywhere, if you possess a well-regulated mind.

quotation: Est animus lucis contemptor!
translation: My soul is a contemner of the light!

quotation: Est in aqua dulci non invidiosa voluptas.
translation: In pure water there is a pleasure begrudged by none.

quotation: Etenim omnes artes quae ad humanitatem pertinent, habent quoddam commune vinculum, et quasi cognatione quadan inter se continentur.
translation: All the arts appertaining civilized life, are united by a kind of common bond, and are connected, as it were, by a certain relationship.

quotation: Etiam capillus unus habet umbram suam.
translation: Even a single hair has its shadow.
notes: The most trivial thing has its utility and importance.

quotation: Est ipsi res angusta domi.
translation: His means are but very limited.

quotation: Etiam celeritas in desiderio, mora est.
translation: In desire, even swiftness itself is delay.

quotation: Adaequarunt judices.
translation: The judges were equally divided.

quotation: Etiam fera animalia, si clausa teneas, virtutis obliviscuntur.
translation: Savage animals even, if you keep them in confinement, forget their ferocious disposition.

quotation: Est mihi, sitque, precor, nostris diuturnior annis, Filia; qua felix sospite semper ero.
translation: I have a daughter, and long, I pray, may she survive my years; so long as she is in comfort I shall ever be happy.

quotation: Exigite ut mores teneros ceu pollice ducat, Ut si quis cera vultum facit.
translation: Require him, with his thumb, as it were, to press into shape their unformed morals, just as one forms a face from wax.
notes: Said with reference to the importance of good training in tender years. The poet alludes to the Roman mode of taking portraits in wax.

quotation: Etiam fortes viros subitis terreri.
translation: The minds of resolute men even may be alarmed by sudden events.
notes: And on the other hand, weak men are then found resolute.

quotation: Est miserorum, ut malevolentes sint atque invideant bonis.
translation: 'Tis the nature of the wretched to be ill-disposed, and to envy the fortunate.

quotation: Exigua est virtus, praestare silentia rebus; At contra, gravis est culpa, tacenda loqui.
translation: 'Tis a small merit to hold silence upon a matter; on the other hand, it is a serious fault to speak of things on which we ought to be silent.

quotation: Est modus in rebus; sunt certi denique fines, Quos ultra citraque nequit consistere rectum.
translation: There is a medium in all things; there are, in fact, certain bounds, on either side of which rectitude cannot exist.
notes: The evils which have been produced by fanaticism prompted by motives really good, are almost equal to those which have sprung from confirmed vice. The poet wisely commends the golden mean.

quotation: Exigui numero, sed bello vivida virtus.
translation: Few in number, but valiant in spirit.

quotation: Est multi fabula plena joci.
translation: It is a short story, but full of fun.

quotation: Exiguum est ad legem bonum esse.
translation: It is but a slight matter to be good to the letter of the law only.

quotation: Est natura hominum novitatis avida.
translation: Man is by nature fond of novelty.

quotation: Exilis domus est, ubi non et multa supersunt, Et dominum fallunt, et prosunt furibus.
translation: It is a poor house indeed, in which there are not many superfluities, which escape the master's notice, and fall a prey to thieves.

quotation: Estne Dei sedes nisi terra, et pontus, et aer, Et coelum, et virtus? Superos quid quaerimus ultra? Jupiter est, quodcunque vides, quocunque moveris.
translation: Has God any other seat than the earth, and the sea and the air, and the heavens, and virtue? Beyond these why do we seek God? Whatever you see, he is in it wherever you move, he is there.
notes: The doctrine of Pantheism.

quotation: Exitio est avidis mare nautis.
translation: The sea is the destruction of avaricious sailors.
notes: Few will think this an apposite maxim at the present day.

quotation: Est nitidus, vitroque magis perlucidus omni Fons.
translation: The fountain is limpid and clearer than any glass.

quotation: Exitus in dubio est: audebimus ultima, dixit; Viderit, audentes forsne Deusne juvet.
translation: 'The result is doubtful, we will dare the utmost,' said he, 'Be it chance or be it a Providence that aids the bold, let him see to it.'

quotation: Est operae pretium duplicis pernoscere juris Naturam.
translation: 'Tis worth your while to know the nature of these two kinds of sauce.
notes: A good motto for a disciple of Kitchener or Soyer.

quotation: Experientia docet.
translation: Experience teaches.
notes: Or, as our proverb has it, "Experience makes fools wise."

quotation: Adde parum parvo, magnus acervus erit.
translation: Add a little to a little, and there will be a great heap.
notes: An adaptation from Ovid.

quotation: Est pater ille quem nuptiae demonstrant.
translation: He is the father whom the marriage rites point out as such.
notes: Each man must be content to father his wife's children, unless he can show a satisfactory reason to the contrary.

quotation: Experimentum crucis.
translation: Trial by the cross.
notes: Alluding, probably, to a mode of eliciting truth by torture.

quotation: Est profecto Deus, qui quae nos gerimus auditque et videt.
translation: There is undoubtedly a God who both hears and sees the things which we do.

quotation: Experto crede.
translation: Believe one who speaks from experience.

quotation: Adde, quod injustum rigido jus dicitur ense, Dantur et in medio vulnera saepe foro.
translation: Besides, iniquitous retaliation is dealt with the cruel sword, and wounds are often inflicted in the midst of the court of justice.

quotation: Est proprium stultitiae aliorum cernere vitia, oblivisci suorum.
translation: It is the province of folly to discover the faults of others, and forget its own.

quotation: Experto crede Roberto.
translation: Believe Robert, who speaks from experience.
notes: A proverb commonly used in the middle ages; but its origin does not appear to be known. Burton uses it in the Introduction to his Anatomy of Melancholy.

quotation: Est quaedam flere voluptas; Expletur lachrymis, egeriturque dolor.
translation: There is, in weeping, a certain luxury; grief is soothed and alleviated by tears.

quotation: Expertus metuit.
translation: He who has experienced it, dreads it.

quotation: Est quiddam gestus edendi.
translation: One's mode of eating is of some importance.

quotation: Etiam in secundissimis rebus maxime est utendum consilio amicorum.
translation: Even in our greatest prosperity, we ought by all means to take the advice of our friends.

quotation: Expetuntur divitiae ad perficiendas voluptates.
translation: Riches are sought to minister to our pleasures.

quotation: Est quoddam prodire tenus, si non datur ultra.
translation: 'Tis something to have advanced thus far, even though it be not granted to go farther.
notes: Failure in a laudable attempt is far from being a thing to be ashamed of.

quotation: Explorant adversa viros; perque aspera duro Nititur ad laudem virtus interrita clivo.
translation: Adversity proves men; and virtue, undaunted, struggles through difficulties, and up the steep height, to gain the reward of fame.

quotation: Adeo in teneris consuescere multum est.
translation: Of such importance is it to be well trained in youth.
notes: Train up a child in the way he should go," says Solomon, Prov. xxii. 6.

quotation: Etiam innocentes cogit mentiri dolor.
translation: Pain makes even the innocent liars.

quotation: Est quoque cunctarum novitas carissima rerum.
translation: Novelty is, of all things, the most sought after.

quotation: Adeone hominem immutari Ex amore, ut non cognoscas eundem esse?
translation: Is it possible that a man can be so hanged by love, that you could not recognise him to be the same?

quotation: Etiam oblivisci quod scis, interdum expedit.
translation: It is sometimes as well to forget what you know.

quotation: Est rosa flos Veneris; quo dulcia furta laterent, Harpocrati matris dona dicavit Amor. Inde rosam mensis hospes suspendit amicis, Convivae ut sub ea dicta tacenda sciant.
translation: The rose is the flower of Venus; in order that his sweet thefts might be concealed, Love dedicated this gift of his mother to Harpocrates. Hence it is that the host hangs it up over his friendly board, that the guests may know how to keep silence upon what is said beneath it.
notes: Harpocrates was the god of silence. Hence our expression, "It was said under the rose."

quotation: Adeste, si quid mihi restat agendum.
translation: If aught remains to be done by me, despatch.
notes: The words of the emperor Severus, just before his death, according to Lord Bacon; but they are not to be found in Dio Cassius or Spartianus.

quotation: Etiam Parnassia laurus Parva sub ingenti matris se subjicit umbra.
translation: Ever, the Parnassian laurel shelters itself beneath the dense shade of its mother.
notes: Said of the suckers which shoot up from the root.

quotation: Est tempus quando nihil, est tempus quando aliquid, nullum tamen est tempus in quo dicenda sunt omnia.
translation: There is a time when nothing may be said, a time when some things may be said, but no time when all things may be said.

quotation: Adhibenda est in jocando moderatio.
translation: Moderation should be used in joking.
notes: A joke should never be carried too far.

quotation: Est via sublimis, coelo manifesta sereno, Lactea nomen habet, candore notabilis ipso.
translation: There is a way on high, easily seen in a clear sky, and which, remarkable for its very whiteness, receives the name of the Milky Way.

quotation: Etiam sanato vulnere cicatrix manet.
translation: Even when the wound is healed the scar remains.
notes: Injuries are more often forgiven than forgotten.

quotation: Adhibenda est munditia, non odiosa, neque exquisita nimis, tantum quae fugiat agrestem ac inhumanam negligentiam.
translation: We should exhibit a certain degree of neatness, not too exquisite or affected, and equally remote from rustic and unbecoming carelessness.

quotation: Esto perpetua.
translation: Be thou everlasting.
notes: The last words of Father Paul Sarpi, spoken in reference to his country, Venice.

quotation: Etiam si Cato dicat.
translation: Even if Cato were to say so.
notes: I would not believe it: Cato being a man of the most scrupulous integrity.

quotation: Adhuc sub judice lis est.
translation: The point is still in dispute before the judge.
notes: The controversy is yet undecided.

quotation: Etiam stultis acuit ingenium fames.
translation: Hunger sharpens even the wits of fools.

quotation: Esto quod es; quod sunt alii, sine quemltbet esse: Quod non es, nolis; quod potes esse, velis.
translation: Be what you really are; let any other person be what others are. Do not wish to be that which you are not, and wish to be that which you can be.

quotation: Aditus est ipsi ad omnes facilis et pervius.
translation: He has free and ready access to every one.

quotation: Etsi pervivo usque ad summam aetatem, tamen Breve spatium est perferundi quae minitas mihi.
translation: Though I should live even to an extreme age, still, short is the time for enduring what you threaten me with.

quotation: Esto quod esse videris.
translation: Be what you seem to be.
notes: Motto of Lord Sondes.

quotation: Euge poetae.
translation: Well done, ye poets!

quotation: Esto, ut nunc multi, dives tibi, pauper amicis.
translation: Be, as many are nowadays, rich to yourself, poor to your friends.

quotation: Esurienti ne occurras.
translation: Do not encounter a starving man.
notes: An enemy reduced to desperation is likely to prove formidable.

quotation: Eum ausculta, cui quatuor sunt aures.
translation: Listen to him who has four ears.
notes: Attend to persons who show themselves more ready to hear than to speak.

quotation: Adjuro numquam eam me deserturum, Non si capiendos mihi sciam esse inimicos omnes homines; Hanc mihi expetivi, contingit; conveniunt mores; valeant Qui inter nos discidium volunt; hanc, nisi mors, mi adimet nemo.
translation: I swear that I will never desert her, even though I were sure that I should make all men my enemies. Her have I desired above all things, her have I obtained. Our humours agree; farewell to those who would set us at variance. Nothing but death shall deprive me of her.

quotation: Et caetera.
translation: And the rest.
notes: Denoted by — &c.

quotation: Eventus stultorum magister est.
translation: Experience is the master of fools.
notes: Fools are only to be taught by experience.

quotation: Et credis cineres curare sepultos?
translation: And do you suppose that the ashes of the dead care for what passes on earth?

quotation: Eversis omnibus rebus, quum consilio profici nihil possit, una ratio videtur; quidquid evenerit, ferre moderate.
translation: When we are utterly ruined, and when no counsel can profit us, there seems to be one way open to us; whatever may happen, to bear it with moderation.

quotation: Adolescentem verecundum esse decet.
translation: A young man ought to be modest.

quotation: Evolare rus ex urbe tanquam ex vinculis.
translation: To fly from the town into the country, as though from chains.

quotation: Et dicam, Mea sunt; injiciamque manus.
translation: And I will say, 'They are mine,' and will lay hands on them.

quotation: Expressa nocent, non expressa non nocent.
translation: What is expressed may be injurious, what is not expressed is not so.
notes: Said in reference to written contracts.

quotation: Adornare verbis benefacta.
translation: To enhance the value of a favour by kind expressions.
notes: The best of actions is liable to be undervalued, if done with a bad grace.

quotation: Ex abundanti cautela.
translation: From excess of precaution.

quotation: Et dubitamus adhuc virtutem extendere factis?
translation: And do we hesitate to extend our glory by our deeds?

quotation: Expressio unius est exclusio alterius.
translation: The naming of one man implies the exclusion of another.

quotation: Adscriptus glebae.
translation: Belonging to the soil.
notes: Attached to the soil, like the serfs and neifs in England so late as the reign of Edward VI., and the greater part of the peasantry of the Russian empire at the present day.

quotation: Et errat longe mea quidem sententia, Qui imperium credit gravius esse aut stabilius Vi quod fit, quam illud, quod amicitia adjungitur.
translation: He is very much mistaken, in my opinion, at all events, who thinks that an authority is more firm, or more lasting, which is established by force, than that which is founded on affection.

quotation: Ex abusu non arguitur ad usum.
translation: We must not argue, from the abuse of a thing, against the use of it.

quotation: Adsit Regula, peccatis quae poenas irroget aequas.
translation: Let a law be made which shall inflict punishment commensurate with the crime.

quotation: Et facere et pati fortia Romanum est.
translation: To act bravely and to suffer bravely is the part of a Roman.

quotation: Ex abusu non argumentum ad desuetudinem.
translation: The abuse of a thing is no argument for its discontinuance.

quotation: Adulandi gens prudentissima laudat Sermonem indocti, faciem deformis, amici.
translation: The crafty race of flatterers praise the conversation of an unlearned, the features of an ugly friend.
notes: See the Fable of the Fox and the Crow, in Aesop.

quotation: Et fert suspensos, corde micante, gradus.
translation: And with palpitating heart he advances on tiptoe.

quotation: Ex aequo et bono judicare.
translation: To judge in fairness and equity.

quotation: Adversus solem ne loquitor.
translation: Speak not against the sun.
notes: Do not argue against that which is as clear as the sun at mid-day.

quotation: Et genus et formam regina pecunia donat.
translation: Money, that queen, bestows both birth and beauty.
notes: Money becomes the substitute for high lineage and good looks.

quotation: Ex arena funiculum nectis.
translation: You are for making a rope of sand.
notes: You are attempting an impossibility.

quotation: Aeacus in poenas ingeniosus erit.
translation: Aeacus shall refine in devising tortures for you.

quotation: Et genus et proavos, et quae non fecimus ipsi, Vix ea nostra voco.
translation: High lineage and ancestors, and such advantages as we have not made ourselves, all these I scarcely call our own.

quotation: Extinctus amabitur idem.
translation: The same man will be beloved when dead.
notes: Men, in general, meet with more justice from their fellow-men, when dead, than when alive.

quotation: Ex auribus cognoscitur asinus.
translation: An ass is known by his ears.

quotation: Et genus et virtus, nisi cum re, vilior alga est.
translation: Virtue and high birth, unless accompanied by wealth, are deemed more worthless than sea-weed.
notes: That is, by the unthinking part of the community.

quotation: Aedificare in tuo proprio solo non licet quod alteri noceat.
translation: You may not build on your own land that which may injure another.
notes: See the same principle in Sic utere, &c.

quotation: Extra lutum pedes habes.
translation: You have got your feet out of the mud.
notes: You are well out of that difficulty.

quotation: Ex cathedra.
translation: From the chair (or pulpit).
notes: Coming from high authority, and therefore to be relied on.

quotation: Et lateat vitium proximitate boni.
translation: And let each fault lie concealed under the name of the good quality to which it is the nearest akin.
notes: See Et mala, &c.

quotation: Aegrescitque medendo.
translation: He destroys his health by his very anxiety to preserve it.

quotation: Extra telorum jactum.
translation: Beyond bow-shot.
notes: Out of harm's way. See Ego post, &c.

quotation: Ex concesso.
translation: From what has been conceded.
notes: An argument ex concesso, or from what the opponent has admitted.

quotation: Et latro, et cautus praecingitur ense viator; Ille sed insidias, hic sibi portat opem.
translation: Both the cut-throat and the wary traveller is girded with the sword; but the one carries it for the purposes of crime, the other as a means of defence.

quotation: Extrema gaudii luctus occupat.
translation: Grief borders on the extremes of gladness.
notes: If you laugh to-day, you may cry to-morrow," is an old saying.

quotation: Ex contractu.
translation: From contract.

quotation: Extrema manus nondum operibus ejus imposita est.
translation: The finishing hand has not yet been put to his work.

quotation: Ex curia.
translation: Out of court.

quotation: Extremis digitis attingere.
translation: To touch with the finger ends.
notes: To handle a matter lightly.

quotation: Et magis adducto pomum decerpere ramo, Quam de coelata sumere lance juvat.
translation: It is more gratifying too, to pull down a branch and pluck an apple, than to take one from a graven dish.

quotation: Extremis malis extrema remedia.
translation: Extreme evils require extreme remedies.
notes: Desperate maladies require desperate remedies."

quotation: Aegri somnia vana.
translation: The delusive dreams of the sick man.

quotation: Exuerint sylvestrem animum, cultuque frequenti, In quascunque voces artes, haud tarda sequentur.
translation: They lay aside their rustic nature, and by repeated instruction will advance apace in any arts into which you may initiate them.

quotation: Aegritudinem laudare, unam rem maxime detestabilem, quorum est tandem philosophorum?
translation: What kind of philosophy is it, pray, to extol melancholy, a thing the most detestable of all?

quotation: Exul, inops erres, alienaque limina lustres; Exiguumque petas ore tremente cibum.
translation: An exile, and in need, mayst thou wander, and mayst thou survey the thresholds of others, and beg with tremulous lips a morsel of food.

quotation: Aegrotat daemon, monachus tunc esse volebat; Daemon convaluit, daemon ut ante fuit.
translation: The devil was sick, the devil a monk would be; The devil got well, the devil a monk was he.
notes: Lines composed in the middle ages.

quotation: F. C.
notes: See Fieri curavit.

quotation: Aegrotationes animi, qualis est avaritia, ex eo quod magni aestimetur ea res, ex qua animus aegrotat, oriuntur.
translation: Diseases of the mind, such as avarice, spring from too high a value set upon the things by which the mind becomes corrupted.

quotation: Fabas indulcet fames.
translation: Hunger sweetens beans.
notes: Hunger is the best sauce.

quotation: Aegroto dum anima est, spes est.
translation: So long as the sick man has life, there is hope.
notes: A common saying with us, "While there is life there is hope."

quotation: Faber compedes quas fecit ipse Gestet.
translation: Let the blacksmith wear the fetters which he himself has forged.
notes: See Tute hoc, &c.

quotation: Faber quisque fortunae suae.
translation: Every man is the architect of his own fortune.

quotation: Aemulatio aemulatiorem parit.
translation: Emulation begets emulation.
notes: A spirit of emulation excites others to similar exertions.

quotation: Fabricando fabri fimus.
translation: By working we become workmen.
notes: Practice makes perfect.

quotation: Aemulus studiorum et laborum.
translation: The rival of his pursuits and of his labours.

quotation: Fabula, nec sentis, tota jactaris in urbe.
translation: You are the talk, and yet you do not perceive it, of the whole city.

quotation: Aequa lege necessitas sortitur insignes et imos.
translation: Fate, by an impartial law, is allotted both to the conspicuous and the obscure.

quotation: Fac simile.
translation: Do the like.
notes: Read as one word, it means an exact imitation or copy of anything.

quotation: Aequam memento rebus in arduis Servare mentem, non secus in bonis Ab insolenti temperatam Laetitia.
translation: In arduous circumstances remember to preserve equanimity, and equally in prosperous moments restrain excessive joy

quotation: Et mala sunt vicina bonis; errore sub illo Pro vitio virtus crimina saepe dedit.
translation: There are bad qualities too near akin to good ones: by confounding the one for the other, a virtue has often borne the blame for a vice.
notes: See Et lateat, &c.

quotation: Fac totum.
translation: Do everything.
notes: Hence our word factotum, meaning a "handy man."

quotation: Et male tornatos incudi reddere versus.
translation: And to return ill-polished verses to the anvil.

quotation: Facetiarum apud praepotentes in longum memoria est.
translation: Men in power do not readily forget a joke.

quotation: Et mea cymba semel vasta percussa procella Illum, quo laesa est, horret adire locum.
translation: My bark too, once struck by the overwhelming storm, dreads to approach the spot on which it has been shattered.

quotation: Faciam ut hujus loci semper memineris.
translation: I will make you always remember this place.

quotation: Et meae, (si quid loquar audiendum), Vocis accedet bona pars.
translation: Then, if I can offer anything worth hearing, my voice shall readily join in the general acclamation.

quotation: Facies non omnibus una, Nec diversa tamen, qualis decet esse sororum.
translation: The features are not the same in all, nor yet very different; they are such as those of sisters ought to be.
notes: A description of "a family likeness."

quotation: Et mihi, Propositum perfice, dixit, opus.
translation: And said to me, Complete the work that you design.

quotation: Facies tua computat annos.
translation: Your face reckons your years;
notes: or, "Your face tells your age."

quotation: Et mihi res, non me rebus, submittere conor.
translation: I endeavour to conquer circumstances, not to submit to them.

quotation: Ex debito justitiae.
translation: From what is due to justice.

quotation: Aequa tellus Pauperi recluditur, Regumque pueris.
translation: The impartial earth is opened alike for the pauper and the children of kings.

quotation: Facile est imperium in bonis.
translation: The sway is easy over the good.

quotation: Aequitas enim lucet ipsa per se.
translation: Equity shines by her own light.

quotation: Et minimae vires frangere quassa valent.
translation: A very little violence is able to break a thing once cracked.
notes: If we give way to dejection, we shall be unable to struggle against the caprice of fortune.

quotation: Facile est inventis addere.
translation: It is easy to improve what has been already invented.

quotation: Aequitas est correctio legis generaliter latae qua parte deficit.
translation: Equity is the correction of the law laid down in general terms, in those parts in which it is deficient.
notes: It modifies the rigour of the law, and takes into consideration the circumstances of the case.

quotation: Et monere, et moneri, proprium est verae amicitiae.
translation: To advise, and be advised, is the duty of true friendship.

quotation: Facile improbi malitia sua aspergunt probos.
translation: Wicked men with their malice easily asperse the characters of the good.

quotation: Aequo animo paratoque moriar.
translation: May I meet death with a mind prepared and calm.

quotation: Facile invenies et pejorem, et pejus moratam, Meliorem neque tu reperies, neque sol videt.
translation: You may easily find a worse woman, and one of worse manners; a better one you will not find, nor does the sun behold such.

quotation: Aequum est Peccatis veniam poscentem reddere rursus.
translation: It is fair that he who expects forgiveness should, in his turn, extend it to others.
notes: We are also taught by a higher sanction, that, as we forgive them that trespass against us, so may we hope to be forgiven.

quotation: Facile omnes cum valenus recta consilia Aegrotis damus. Tu, si hic sis, aliter senties.
translation: When we are in health, we are all able to give good advice to the sick. You, if you were in my place, would think otherwise.

quotation: Facile princeps.
translation: The acknowledged chief.
notes: The one who stands first, beyond a doubt.

quotation: Et moveant primos publica verba sonos.
translation: And let the topics of the day lead to the first words.

quotation: Et nati natorum, et qui nascentur ab illis.
translation: The children of our children, and those who shall be born of them.
notes: Our latest posterity.

quotation: Et neque jam color est misto candore rubori; Nec vigor, et vires, et quae modo visa placebant; Nec corpus remanet.
translation: And now, no longer is his complexion of white mixed with red; neither his vigour nor his strength, nor the points which charmed when seen so lately, nor even his body, now remains.

quotation: Et nova fictaque nuper habebunt verba fidem, si Graeco fonte cadunt parce detorta.
translation: And new and lately invented terms will have authority, if they are derived from Greek sources, with but little deviation.

quotation: Facllis descensus Averni, Sed revocare gradum, superasque evadere ad auras, Hic labor, hoc opus est.
translation: Easy the descent to hell; but to retrace your steps and to regain the upper world, that is the difficulty, that the labour.
notes: The poet alludes to the descent of Aeneas to the Infernal regions; but the figure may be applied to the readiness with which we may fall into evil courses, and the difficulty of retracing our steps.

quotation: Et nulli cessura fides, sine crimine mores, Nudaque simplicitas, purpureusque pudor.
translation: A fidelity that will yield to none, manners above reproach, ingenuousness without guile, and blushing modesty.

quotation: Facilius crescit quam inchoatur dignitas.
translation: Increase of dignity is more easily gained than the first step.

quotation: Et nunc omnis ager, nunc omnis parturit arbos; Nunc frondent sylvae, nunc formosissimus annus.
translation: And now every field, now every tree, is budding forth; now the woods look green; now most beauteous is the year.
notes: A description of Spring.

quotation: Facilius sit Nili caput invenire.
translation: It would be easier to discover the sources of the Nile.

quotation: Et peccare nefas, aut pretium est mori.
translation: It is forbidden to sin, or the reward is death.
notes: The sin to which the poet alludes, is that of adultery, as punished by the Scythians. So in Scripture, "The wages of sin is death." Rom. vi. 23.

quotation: Facinus audax incipit, Qui cum opulento pauper homine coepit rem habere aut negotium.
translation: A pooir man who commences to have business or dealings with an opulent one, commences upon a rash undertaking.

quotation: Et Phoebo digna locuti, Quique sui memores alios fecere merendo; Omnibus his nivea cinguntur tempora vitta.
translation: Those who have uttered things worthy of Phoebus, and those who have made others mindful of them by their merits, all these have their temples bound with the snow-white fillet.
notes: In his description of the rewards of Elysium, the poet classes his brethren, the disciples of Phoebus, with the benefactors of mankind.

quotation: Facinus majoris abollae.
translation: The crime of a more dignified garb.
notes: A crime committed by a philosopher of more dignified character. The abolla was the cloak worn by philosophers.

quotation: Facinus quos inquinat aequat.
translation: Those whom guilt defiles, it places on a level.
notes: The highest and the lowest are equally degraded by guilt; but, if anything, the former is the most culpable.

quotation: Et pudet, et metuo, semperque eademque precari, Ne subeant animo taedia justa tuo.
translation: I am both ashamed and I dread to be always making the same entreaties, lest a justifiable disgust should take possession of your feelings.

quotation: Facit gratum fortuna, quam nemo videt.
translation: The good fortune which no one sees, makes a man grateful for it.
notes: Because he is not the object of envy.

quotation: Facito aliquid operis, ut semper te diabolus inveniat occupatum.
translation: Be busy about something; so that the devil may always find you occupied.

quotation: Et quae sibi quisque timebat, Unius in miseri exitium conversa tulere.
translation: And what each man dreaded for himself, they bore lightly, when centred in the destruction of one wretched creature.
notes: A picture of the readiness with which man makes a scapegoat of his fellow-man.

quotation: Et quando uberior vitiorum copia? Quando Major avaritiae patuit sinus? Alea quando Hos animos?
translation: And when was vice ever in greater force? When was there ever a greater scope for avarice? When did the dice more thoroughly enthral the minds of men?

quotation: Felices ter et amplius Quos irrupta tenet copula, nec, malis Divulsus quaerimoniis, Suprema citius solvet amor die.
translation: Thrice happy they, and more, whom an indissoluble union binds together, and whom love, unimpaired by evil complainings, does not separate before the last day.
notes: Applicable to the delights of connubial happiness.

quotation: Faciunt nae intelligendo, ut nihil intelligant?
translation: By being thus knowing, do they not show that they know nothing at all?

quotation: Et qui aliis nocent, ut in alios liberales sint, in eadem sunt injustitia, ut si in suam rem aliena convertant.
