translation: And those who injure one party to benefit another, are quite as unjust, as if they converted the property of others to their own benefit.

quotation: Facta canam; sed erunt qui me finxisse loquantur.
translation: I shall sing of facts; but there will be some to say that I have invented fictions.

quotation: Felicitas multos habet amicos.
translation: Prosperity has many friends.
notes: Fair-weather followers, and sun-shine friends.

quotation: Et qui nolunt occidere quenquam Posse volunt.
translation: Even those who have no wish to slay another, are wishful to have the power.
notes: In allusion to the ambitious thirst for power.

quotation: Factis ignoscite nostris, Si scelus ingenio scitis abesse meo.
translation: Forgive my deeds, inasmuch as ye know that impiety was far from my intention.

quotation: Et quiescenti agendum est, et agenti quiescendum est.
translation: He who is indolent should labour, and he who labours should take repose.

quotation: Facto pius et sceleratus eodem.
translation: A father, affectionate and unnatural in the self-same act.
notes: Said of Agenor, when he dismissed his son Cadmus to roam over the world in search of his daughter Europa.

quotation: Factum abiit; monumenta manent.
translation: The occurrence has passed away; the memorial of it still remains.
notes: The motto of the London Numismatic Society.

quotation: Et rident stolidi verba Latina.
translation: And the fools laugh at Latin words.

quotation: Et sanguis et spiritus pecunia mortalibus.
translation: Money is both blood and life to men.

quotation: Factum est illud; fieri infectum non potest.
translation: The thing is done, it cannot be undone.

quotation: Faex populi.
translation: The dregs of the people.
notes: The scum of the population.

quotation: Et sequentia.
translation: And what follows.
notes: Generally written in short, et seq.

quotation: Fallacia alia aliam trudit.
translation: One deception makes way for another.
notes: One lie is supported by another.

quotation: Et si non aliqua nocuisses, mortuus esses.
translation: And if you could not have hurt him some way or other, you would have died (of spite).

quotation: Fallentis semita vitae.
translation: The path of a life that passes unnoticed.

quotation: Et sic de similibus.
translation: And so of the like.

quotation: Fallit enim vitium, specie virtutis et umbra, Cum sit triste habitu, vultuque et veste severum.
translation: For vice deceives us, under the form and guise of virtue, when serious in manner and reserved in countenance and dress.
notes: A rebuke of sanctified hypocrisy.

quotation: Et tenuit nostras numerosus Horatius aures.
translation: Horace too, with his varied numbers, charmed my ears.

quotation: Fallitur egregio quisquis sub principe credit Servitium. Nunquam libertas gratior extat Quam sub rege pio.
translation: He is mistaken who considers it slavery to be ruled by a virtuous prince. Never has liberty more charms, than under a pious king.

quotation: Et veniam pro laude peto; laudatus abunde, Non fastiditus si tibi, lector, ero.
translation: Pardon too, in place of praise, do I crave; abundantly, reader, shall I be praised, if I do not cause thee disgust.

quotation: Fallor? An arma sonant? Non fallimur, arma sonabant; Mars venit, et veniens bellica signa dabat.
translation: Am I mistaken? Or is that the clash of arms? I am not mistaken, it was the clash of arms: Mars approaches; and, as he comes, he sounds the note of war.

quotation: Et vitam impendere vero.
translation: And in the cause of truth to lay down life.

quotation: Falsa grammatica non vitiat concessionem.
translation: Bad grammar does not vitiate a grant.
notes: See Mala Grammatica, &c.

quotation: Felicitas nutrix est iracundiae.
translation: Prosperity is the nurse of anger.
notes: Men who have been successful are apt to forget themselves.

quotation: Feliciter is sapit, qui periculo alieno sapit.
translation: He is happy in his wisdom, who is wise at the expense of another.
notes: From the interpolated Scene in the Mercator of Plautus, supposed to have been written by Hermolaüs Barbarus.

quotation: Falso damnati crimine mortis.
translation: On a false charge condemned to die.

quotation: Felix est cui quantulumcunque temporis contigit, bene collocatum est.
translation: Happy is he who has well employed his time, however short it may have been.

quotation: Falsus honor juvat, et mendax infamia terret, Quem nisi mendosum et mendacem?
translation: Whom, but the vicious and the liar, does misplaced praise delight, or lying slanders alarm?

quotation: Felix quem faciunt aliena pericula cautum.
translation: Happy is he whom the perils of others put on his guard.

quotation: Fama, malum quo non aliud velocius ullum, Mobilitate viget, viresque acquirit eundo.
translation: Rumour, than which no pest is more swift, increases by motion, and gains strength as she goes.

quotation: Fama nihil est celerius.
translation: Nothing travels more swiftly than scandal.

quotation: Felix quem faciunt aliorum cornua cautum.
translation: Happy the man whom the horns of others make wary.

quotation: Famae damna majora sunt, quam quae aestimdri possint.
translation: The loss of reputation is greater than can be possibly conceived.

quotation: Felix qui nihil debet.
translation: Happy is he who owes nothing.

quotation: Felix qui potuit rerum cognoscere causas.
translation: Happy is he who can trace the causes of things.
notes: A compliment to the philosopher, who centres his pleasure in that which is for the benefit or instruction of mankind.

quotation: Formosa facies muta commendatio est.
translation: A handsome face is a silent recommendation.

quotation: Felix quicunque dolore Alterius disces posse carere tuo.
translation: Happy you, who can, by the pain of another, learn to avoid it yourself.

quotation: Famae laboranti non facile succurritur.
translation: It is not easy to repair a character when falling.
notes: It is not easy to recover a lost character.

quotation: Formosos saepe inveni pessimos, Et turpi facie multos cognovi optimos.
translation: I have often found the good-looking to be very knaves, and I have known many with ugly features most worthy men.

quotation: Famam extendere factis.
translation: To extend our fame by our deeds.
notes: The motto of Linnaeus.

quotation: Felo de se.
translation: A felon of himself.
notes: One who, being, in legal estimation, of sound mind, slays himself. One who commits felony by suicide.

quotation: Fames est optimus coquus.
translation: Hunger is the best cook.

quotation: Ferae naturae.
translation: Of a wild nature.
notes: This term is applied to animals of a savage nature, in contradistinction to those, which are under the control of man, and are called domitae naturae, "of a tame nature."

quotation: Fames et mora bilem in nasum conciunt.
translation: Hunger and delay summon the bile to the nostrils,
notes: i.e. "excite our wrath."

quotation: Feras, non culpes, quod mutari non potest.
translation: You must endure, not blame, that which cannot be altered.
notes: What cannot be cured must be endured.

quotation: Forsan et haec olim meminisse juvabit; Durate, et vosmet rebus servate secundis.
translation: Perhaps it may one day be a pleasure to remember these sufferings; bear up against them, and reserve yourselves for more prosperous fortunes.

quotation: Fames optimum condimentum.
translation: Hunger is the best sauce.

quotation: Feras quod laedit, ut id quod prodest perferas.
translation: You must bear that which hurts, that you may gain that which profits.

quotation: Forsan miseros meliora sequentur.
translation: Perhaps better fortunes await us wretched men.

quotation: Fere libenter homines id quod volunt credunt.
translation: Men generally are willing to believe what they wish to be true.
notes: Like our saying, "The wish is father to the thought."

quotation: Forsitan hic aliquis dicat, Quae publica tangunt Carpere concessum est; hoc via juris habet.
translation: Perhaps some one here may say, 'What encroaches on the highway it is allowable to take; this right the road confers.'

quotation: Ferre pulcherrime secundam fortunam et aeque adversam.
translation: To bear with equal gracefulness good fortune or bad.

quotation: Fortem facit vicina libertas senem.
translation: The prospect of liberty makes even an old man brave.

quotation: Fames, pestis, et bellum, populi sunt pernicies.
translation: Famine, pestilence, and war, are the scourges of mankind.

quotation: Ferreus assiduo consumitur annulus usu.
translation: By continued use a ring of iron is consumed.

quotation: Fortem posce animum.
translation: Pray for strong resolve.
notes: The motto of Lord Say and Sele.

quotation: Familiare est hominibus omnia sibi ignoscere.
translation: It is usual with man to forgive all his own faults.
notes: A man is an indulgent censor to himself.

quotation: Fertilior seges est alienis semper in agris, Vicinumque pecus grandius uber habet.
translation: The crop is ever more fruitful in our neighbour's fields, and his cows have more distended udders than our own.
notes: It is the nature of man to repine at his own lot, and to envy that of another.

quotation: Farrago libelli.
translation: The medley of my book.
notes: The "something of everything" there to be found.

quotation: Fas est et ab hoste doceri.
translation: It is right to be taught by an enemy even.
notes: We may profit from the oversights of our adversaries, by learning to avoid them.

quotation: Ferto, fereris.
translation: Bear, and you shall be borne with.
notes: Learn to "give and take."

quotation: Fastidientis est stomachi multa degustare.
translation: To taste of many dishes is a sign of a delicate stomach.

quotation: Fervens difficili bile tumet jecur.
translation: My inflamed liver swells with bile, difficult to be repressed.

quotation: Fervet avaritia miseroque cupidine pectus?
translation: Does your heart burn with avarice, and the direful greed for gain?

quotation: Fervet olla, vivit amicitia.
translation: While the pot boils, friendship endures.

quotation: Fortem posce animum, mortis terrore carentem, Qui spatium vitae extremum inter munera ponat, Naturae.
translation: Pray for strong resolve, void of the fear of death, that reckons the closing hour of life among the boons of nature.

quotation: Festina lente.
translation: Hasten slowly.
notes: Be on your guard against impetuosity. A favourite saying of the emperors Augustus and Titus. It forms the punning motto of tho Onslow family.

quotation: Fortes creantur fortibus et bonis; Est in juvencis, est in equis patrum Virtus, nee imbellem feroces Progenerant aquilae columbam.
translation: The brave are generated by the brave and good: there is in steers and in horses the virtue of their sires, nor does the warlike eagle beget the peaceful dove.

quotation: Fortes fortuna adjuvat.
translation: Fortune favours the bold.
notes: These words were quoted by the elder Pliny shortly before he perished, in the eruption of Mount Vesuvius, a victim to his thirst for knowledge.

quotation: Festinare nocet, nocet et cunctatio saepe; Tempore quaeque suo qui facit, ille sapit.
translation: It is bad to be in a hurry, and delay is often as bad; he is wise who does everything at its proper time.

quotation: Festinat decurrere velox Flosculus, angustae, miseraeque brevissima vitae Portio; dum bibimus, dum serta, unguenta, puellas Poscimus, obrepit non intellecta senectus.
translation: The short-lived flower, the limited span of our fleeting and wretched existence, hastens to decay; whilst we are drinking, calling for garlands, perfumes, and women, old age steals upon us unperceived.
notes: We learn from Ovid that wine and women, unguents and garlands, all played their part in the feasts of the sensualists of Rome.

quotation: Fortior et potentior est dispositio legis quam hominis.
translation: The control of the law is stronger and more powerful than that of man.

quotation: Fortis cadere, cedere non potest.
translation: The brave may fall, but will never yield.
notes: A play upon the resemblance of the words cadere and cedere.

quotation: Festinatio tarda est.
translation: Haste is slow.
notes: Real despatch is insured by prudence and caution: for a thing is done "sat cito si sat bene," "quick enough if well enough."

quotation: Fortis et constantis animi est, non perturbari in rebus asperis.
translation: It is the proof of a brave and resolute spirit, not to be daunted in adversity.

quotation: Festo die si quid prodegeris Profesto egere liceat, nisi peperceris.
translation: If you are guilty of any extravagance on a feast day, you may be wanting on a common day, unless you are frugal.

quotation: Fortissimus ille est Qui promptus metuenda pati, si cominus instent.
translation: He is the bravest, who is prepared to encounter danger on the instant.

quotation: Fortiter ferendo vincitur malum quod evitari non potest.
translation: By bravely enduring it, an evil which cannot be avoided is overcome.

quotation: Fiat.
translation: Let it be done.
notes: So be it." An order or assent given by one in authority.

quotation: Fortitudo in laboribus periculisque cernitur: temperantia in praetermittendis voluptatibus: prudentia in delectu bonorum et malorum: justitia in suo cuique tribuendo.
translation: Fortitude is to be seen in the endurance of toils and dangers; temperance, in a self-denial of luxuries; prudence, in a choice between good and evil; justice, in rendering to every one his due.

quotation: Fiat experimentum in corpore vili.
translation: Let the experiment be made on a worthless body.

quotation: Fortius e multis mater desiderat unum; Quam quae flens clamat, Tu mihi solus eras.
translation: With greater fortitude does a mother bewail one out of many, than she who, weeping, exclaims, 'Thou wast my only one.'

quotation: Fiat justitia, ruat coelum.
translation: Let justice be done, though heaven should fall.
notes: Said of a decision formed at all hazards.

quotation: Fortuna favet fatuis.
translation: Fortune favours fools.

quotation: Fiat lux.
translation: Let there be light.
notes: Gen. i. 3.

quotation: Fortuna humana fingit artatque ut lubet.
translation: Fortune moulds and fashions human affairs just as she pleases.

quotation: Fiat mixtura secundum artem.
translation: Let the mixture be made according to the rules of art.
notes: Often placed at the end of medical prescriptions.

quotation: Fortuna magna magna domino est servitus.
translation: A great fortune is a great slavery to its owner.
notes: He who has immense wealth, is troubled with cares unknown to others.

quotation: Ficos dividere.
translation: To split figs.
notes: Said of persons who would, as we say, "flay a flint."

quotation: Fortuna multis dat nimium, nulli satis.
translation: Fortune gives to many too much, to none enough.

quotation: Ficta voluptatis causa sit proxima veris.
translation: Let whatever is devised for the sake of entertainment have as much resemblance as possible to truth.

quotation: Fortuna nimium quem fovet, stultum facit.
translation: Fortune makes a fool of the man whom she favours too much.

quotation: Fictis meminerit nos jocari fabulis.
translation: Let it be remembered that we are amusing you with tales of fiction.

quotation: Fortuna non mutat genus.
translation: Fortune does not change our nature.
notes: What's bred in the bone won't out of the flesh.

quotation: Ficum cupit.
translation: He wants some figs.
notes: He is paying me so much attention to suit his own purposes." The Athenian fashionables were in the habit of visiting the cottages of the peasants, on the approach of the fig season, and treating them with great courtesy, that they might obtain the choicest of the fruit when it came to maturity.

quotation: Fortuna obesse nulli contenta est semel.
translation: Fortune is not content to do a man but one ill turn.
notes: Misfortunes never come single.

quotation: Fortuna opes auferre, non animum potest.
translation: Fortune may deprive us of wealth, but not of courage.
notes: "I care not, Fortune, what you me deny; Of fancy, reason, virtue nought can me bereave." Thomson.

quotation: Ficus ficus, ligonem ligonem vocat.
translation: He calls a fig a fig, a spade a spade.
notes: He is a plain, straightforward man, one who speaks his mind.

quotation: Fortuna parvis momentis magnas rerum commutationes efficit.
translation: Fortune, in a short moment, effects vast changes in worldly affairs.
notes: The fate of a kingdom often depends upon the act of a moment.

quotation: Fortuna saevo laeta negotio, et Ludum insolentem ludere pertinax, Transmutat incertos honores, Nunc mihi, nunc alii benigna.
translation: Fortune, delighting in her cruel pursuit, and persisting in playing her insolent game, shifts her uncertain honours, indulgent now to me, now to another.

quotation: Fide abrogata, omnis humana societas tollitur.
translation: Good faith abolished, all human society is destroyed.

quotation: Fortuna vitrea est, tum cum splendet frangitur.
translation: Fortune is like glass — while she shines she breaks.
notes: She has its splendour with its brittleness.

quotation: Fidelius rident tuguria.
translation: The laughter of the cottage is the most hearty.
notes: Because the laughers are free from care.

quotation: Fortunae caetera mando.
translation: I confide the rest to fortune.
notes: I have taken all measures to ensure success, the rest remains in the hand of God.

quotation: Fastus inest pulchris, sequiturque superbia formam; Irrisum vultu despicit illa suo.
translation: Cold disdain is innate in the fair, and haughtiness accompanies beauty. By her looks she despises and she scorns him.

quotation: Fidem qui perdit perdere ultra nil potest.
translation: He who loses his good faith has nothing else to lose.
notes: Integrity and honour are the most valuable inheritance.

quotation: Fortunae filius.
translation: A son of fortune.
notes: A favourite child of fortune; one of a number that are very often spoiled.

quotation: Fata obstant.
translation: The Fates are opposed.
notes: It is not his destiny.

quotation: Fortunae majoris honos, erectus et acer.
translation: An honour to his elevated station, upright and brave.

quotation: Fata volentem ducunt, nolentem trahunt.
translation: The Fates lead him who is willing, and drag him who is unwilling.
notes: A maxim of the believers in predestination, that it is as well to be resigned to our fate.

quotation: Fortunae verba dedique meae.
translation: And I have deceived my destiny.

quotation: Fatetur facinus is qui judicium fugit.
translation: He who flies from trial confesses his guilt.
notes: At all events, his conduct is prima facie evidence against him.

quotation: Fortunam reverenter habe, quicunque repente Dives ab exili progrediere loco.
translation: Behave with all respect to fortune, you who have suddenly risen to wealth from narrow circumstances.

quotation: Fortunato omne solum patria est.
translation: To him who is fortunate every land is his country.

quotation: Fidem qui perdit, quo se servat in reliquum?
translation: He who has lost his credit, with what shall he sustain himself in future?

quotation: Fortunatus et ille deos qui novit agrestes.
translation: Happy the man who makes acquaintance with the rural gods.
notes: Such a man knows the health and pleasures of a country life.

quotation: Fatigatis humus cubile est.
translation: To the weary the earth is a bed.

quotation: Fides servanda est.
translation: Faith must be kept.

quotation: Fragili quaerens illidere dentem Offendet solido.
translation: Trying to fix her tooth in some tender part, Envy will strike it against the solid.
notes: In allusion to the Fable of the Serpent and the File.

quotation: Fatis accede Deisque, Et cole felices, miseros fuge. Sidera coelo Ut distant, flamma mari, sic utile recto.
translation: Welcome the Fates and the Gods, caress the fortunate, and shun the wretched. As much as the stars are distant in the heavens, as much as flame differs from the sea, so much does the expedient differ from the right.

quotation: Fides sit penes auctorem.
translation: Let due faith be given to the author.
notes: A phrase used by a writer when quoting from a doubtful authority.

quotation: Frangas, non flectes.
translation: You may break, you shall not bend, me.
notes: Motto of the Duke of Sutherland and Earl Granville.

quotation: Favete linguis.
translation: Favour by your tongues,
notes: or, "Be propitious in your language." This was an usual injunction with the Romans at their sacrifices, as a word of ill-omen spoken during their celebration was considered to have an evil influence.

quotation: Fieri curavit.
translation: Caused this to be done.
notes: Often represented in monumental inscriptions by the initial letters F. C.

quotation: Frange, miser, calamos, vigilataque praelia dele, Qui facis in parva sublimia carmina cella, Ut dignus venias hederis, et imagine macra.
translation: Break your pens, poor wretch! Blot out your battles that have kept you watching, you that write sublime poetry in your narrow room, that you may come forth worthy of an ivy crown and a meagre statue.

quotation: Fecundi calices quem non fecere disertum?
translation: Whom have not flowing cups made eloquent?

quotation: Fieri facias.
translation: Cause it to be done.
notes: A writ by which the sheriff is commanded to levy the debt, or damages, on the defendant's goods. Sometimes called, for brevity, a fi fa.

quotation: Fraudare eos qui sciunt et consentiunt nemo videtur.
translation: It is not deemed that a fraud is committed upon those who are aware of the act and consent to it.

quotation: Felices errore sito.
translation: Happy in their error.
notes: Where ignorance is bliss, 'tis folly to be wise." Gray.

quotation: Figulus figulo invidet, faber fabro.
translation: The potter envies the potter, the blacksmith the blacksmith.
notes: So we say, "Two of a trade never agree."

quotation: Fraus est celare fraudem.
translation: It is a fraud to conceal fraud.
notes: By doing so a person becomes in the eye of the law an accomplice.

quotation: Filli non plus possessionum quam morborum haeredes sumus.
translation: As sons we are heirs, no less to diseases than to possessions.

quotation: Frigidam aquam effundere.
translation: To throw cold water on a matter.
notes: To discourage an undertaking, by damping the enthusiasm of the projector. To poo-pooh a thing as impracticable or unprofitable.

quotation: Filius nullius.
translation: The son of no man.
notes: A bastard is so called, for he has no legal rights as a son, in respect to the inheritance of property.

quotation: Frigora mitescunt Zephyris; ver proterit aestas Interitura, simul Pomifer autumnus fruges effuderit; et mox Bruma recurrit iners.
translation: The colds are mitigated by the Zephyrs; the summer follows close upon the spring; shortly to die itself, as soon as the fruit-bearing autumn shall have poured forth her fruits; and then anon sluggish winter returns again.

quotation: Filum aquae.
translation: The thread of the stream.
notes: An imaginary line in the middle of a river, which is supposed to be the boundary of the lordships or manors on either side.

quotation: Frons, oculi, vultus persaepe mentiuntur: oratio vero saepissime.
translation: The forehead, eyes, and features often deceive; still oftener the speech.
notes: It is a maxim of Machiavellian policy that "the use of speech is to conceal the thoughts."

quotation: Fronti nulla fides.
translation: There is no trusting the features.
notes: Judge not from outward appearances.

quotation: Fructu non foliis arborem aestima.
translation: Judge of a tree from its fruit, not from its leaves.

quotation: Finge datos currus; quid agas?
translation: Suppose the chariot were given to you; what would you do?
notes: The question put by Apollo, when Phaëton asks him for the loan of the chariot of the Sun. The same question may be asked of one who aspires to an office which he is unfit to fill.

quotation: Furor loquendi.
notes: or scribendi. See Cacoethes, &c.

quotation: Fingebat tremula rustica liba manu.
translation: She made her rustic cakes with trembling hand.

quotation: Futura expectans presentibus angor.
translation: While awaiting the future I am tormented by the present.
notes: The situation of a man in present difficulties, but with good prospects.

quotation: Fingit equum tenera docilem cervice magister Ire viam quam monstrat eques.
translation: The trainer teaches the docile horse to turn, with tractable neck, whichever way the rider directs it.

quotation: Galeatum sero duelli Poenitet.
translation: Having put on your helmet, it is late to repent of becoming a warrior.
notes: Good advice to a soldier before he takes the fatal shilling. See Gladiator, &c.

quotation: Fruges consumere nati.
translation: Born only to consume the fruits of the earth.
notes: Alluding to persons who pass their lives in eating and drinking, but are comparatively useless to society.

quotation: Finis coronat opus.
translation: The end crowns the work.
notes: A work cannot be appreciated until it is completed. The words are also capable of meaning the same as our saying, "The end sanctifies the means."

quotation: Gallus in suo sterquilinio plurimum potest.
translation: Every cock is master of his own dunghill.

quotation: Garrit aniles Ex re fabellas.
translation: He relates old women's tales very much to the purpose.

quotation: Fistula dulce canit volucres dum decipit auceps; Impia sub dulci melle venena latent.
translation: The pipe sounds sweetly, while the fowler is decoying the birds; beneath the sweet honey deadly poisons lie concealed.

quotation: Gaude, Maria Virgo.
translation: Rejoice, Virgin Mary.
notes: The beginning of an anthem chaunted by the monks of the Romish Church at nightfall; from which that particular period of time obtained the name of the Godemarre.

quotation: Fit cito per multas praeda petita manus.
translation: The prey that is sought by many hands speedily accumulates.

quotation: Frustra fit per plura, quod fieri potest per pauciora.
translation: It is useless to do by many, that which may be done by a few.
notes: The chances are that they will be in each other's way. "Too many cooks spoil the broth."

quotation: Gaudent praenomine molles Auriculae.
translation: Delicate ears are tickled with a title.

quotation: Frustra Herculi.
translation: It is in vain you speak against Hercules.
notes: Applied to those who speak ill of persons really above reproach.

quotation: Gaudet equis, canibusque, et aprici gramine campi.
translation: He delights in horses, and dogs, and the grass of the sunuy plain.

quotation: Frustra laborat qui omnibus placere studet.
translation: He labours in vain who tries to please everybody.
notes: The Fable of the Old Man and the Ass teaches the same lesson.

quotation: Gaudetque viam fecisse ruina.
translation: He rejoices at having made his way by ruin.
notes: Said by Lucan of Julius Caesar, against whom he manifests a most bitter prejudice.

quotation: Fit erranti medicina confessio.
translation: Confession is as medicine to him who has erred.
notes: Confess your faults one to another," says the apostle, James v. 16.

quotation: Frustra retinacula tendens Fertur equis auriga, neque audit currus habenas.
translation: In vain as he pulls the reins, is the charioteer borne along by the steeds; they no longer heed his control.

quotation: Genius loci.
translation: The Genius
notes: or "presiding spirit, of the place."

quotation: Fit fabricando faber.
translation: To become a blacksmith you must work at the forge.

quotation: Frustra vitium vitaveris illud, Si te alio pravus detorseris.
translation: In vain do you avoid one vice, if in your depravity you plunge into another.

quotation: Genus humanum multo fuit illud in arvis Durius.
translation: The human race was then far more hardy in the fields.

quotation: Fit in dominatu servitus, in servitute dominatus.
translation: He who should be the master, sometimes becomes the servant, he who should be the servant, the master.

quotation: Fucum facere.
translation: To give a false colour to a thing.

quotation: Genus immortale manet, multosque per annos Stat fortuna domus, et avi numerantur avorum.
translation: The race continues immortal; throughout many years, the fortunes of the house still flourish, and grandsires of grandsires are to be numbered.
notes: A picture of a thriving community.

quotation: Fugam fecit.
translation: He has taken to flight.
notes: Said of a person who has fled from trial.

quotation: Genus irritabile vatum.
translation: The sensitive race of poets.
notes: Who are peculiarly tenacious of their literary fame.

quotation: Fuge magna; licet sub paupere tecto Reges et regum vita praecurrere amicos.
translation: Avoid an elevated station; under a poor roof one may surpass even kings and the friends of kings in what is really life.

quotation: Gladiator in arena consilium capit.
translation: The gladiator, having entered the lists, is taking advice.
notes: Said of a man taking counsel at a moment at which it is probably too late to use it. See Galeatum, &c.

quotation: Gloria est consentiens laus bonorum, incorrupta vox bene judicantium de excellenti virtute.
translation: Glory is the unanimous praise of the good, the unbought voice of those who can well discriminate as to surpassing virtue.

quotation: Gloria Patri.
translation: Glory be to the Father.

quotation: Gloria virtutem tanquam umbra sequitur.
translation: Glory follows virtue, as though it were its shadow.

quotation: Gloriae et famae jactura facienda est, publicae utilitatis causa.
translation: A sacrifice must be made of glory and fame for the public advantage.

quotation: Fugere est triumphus.
translation: Flight is a triumph.
notes: Said in the case of flight from temptation.

quotation: Gnatum pariter uti his decuit, aut etiam amplius, Quod illa aetas magis ad haec utenda idonea est.
translation: Your son ought to have enjoyed these good things equally with you, or even more so, because his age is better suited for such enjoyments.

quotation: Graecia capta ferum victorem cepit, et artes Intulit agresti Latio.
translation: Greece, subdued, captivated her uncivilized conqueror, and imported her arts into unpolished Latium.

quotation: Graecorum animi servitute ac miseria fracti sunt.
translation: The minds of the Greeks are broken down by slavery and wretchedness.
notes: The historian speaks of the time when Greece had succumbed to the Roman arms.

quotation: Graeculus esuriens ad coelum jusseris ibit.
translation: The hungry wretch of a Greek would attempt heaven even, were you to bid him.
notes: So the English line, "Bid him go to hell, to hell he goes." Said of the wretched sycophants who, in its degenerate days, left Greece, the country of their birth, to fawn on the great men of Rome.

quotation: Grammatici certant, et adhuc sub judice lis est.
translation: The grammarians disagree, and the matter in dispute is still undetermined.

quotation: Gram. loquitur; Dia. vera docet; Rhe. verba colorat; Mu. canit; Ar. numerat; Geo. ponderat; As. docet astra.
translation: Grammar speaks correctly; Dialectics (Logic) teach us truth; Rhetoric gives colouring to our speech; Music sings; Arithmetic reckons; Geometry measures; Astronomy teaches us the stars.
notes: Two Latin hexameters, composed to assist the memory in conveying to it some correct information.

quotation: Grata superveniet quae non sperabitur hora.
translation: The hour of happiness will be the more welcome, the less it is expected.
notes: Unexpected blessings are doubly acceptable.

quotation: Gratia ab officio quod mora tardat abest.
translation: Thanks are lost for a service tardily performed.

quotation: Gratia gratiam parit.
translation: Kindness produces kindness.

quotation: Gratia, Musa tibi. Nam tu solatia praebes; Tu curae requies, tu medicina mali.
translation: Thanks to thee, my Muse. For it is thou that dost afford me solace; thou art a rest from care, a solace for my woes.

quotation: Gratia placendi.
translation: The delight of pleasing.
notes: The happiness we ought to feel in making others happy.

quotation: Gratia pro rebus merito debetur inemtis.
translation: Thanks are justly due for things obtained without purchase.

quotation: Gratiae expectativae.
translation: Anticipated benefits.
notes: Advantages in perspective.

quotation: Gratior et pulchro veniens in corpore virtus.
translation: Even virtue appears more lovely, when it inhabits a beautiful form.

quotation: Gratis anhelans, multa agendo nihil agens.
translation: Out of breath about nothing, with much ado doing nothing.
notes: The poet's picture of the busy-bodies of Rome.

quotation: Gratis asseritur.
translation: It is asserted, but not proved.

quotation: Gratis dictum.
translation: Said to no purpose.
notes: Irrelevant to the present question.

quotation: Gratis poenitet esse probum.
translation: A man is sorry to be honest for nothing.

quotation: Gratulor quod eum quem necesse erat diligere, qualiscunque esset, talem habiemus, ut libenter quoque diligamus.
translation: I rejoice that he, whom, whatever his character might have been, I was bound to love, should prove himself such, that I can feel a pleasure in bestowing my affections on him.
notes: A compliment paid by a son or a subject, who finds the object of his duteous respect equally that of his admiration.

quotation: Gratum est quod patriae civem populoque dedisti, Si facis ut patriae sit idoneus, utilis agris; Utilis et bellorum et pacis rebus agendis.
translation: It deserves our gratitude that you have presented a citizen to your country and people, if you take care that he prove useful to the state, and of service to her lands; useful in transacting the affairs both of war and peace.

quotation: Gratum hominem semper beneficium delectat; ingratum semel.
translation: A benefit received is always delightful to a grateful man; to an ungrateful man, only at the time.
notes: That is, at the moment when it is bestowed.

quotation: Grave nihil est homini quod fert necessitas.
translation: Nothing is really heavy to a man, which necessity brings upon him.

quotation: Grave paupertas malum est, et intolerabile, quae magnum domat populum.
translation: The poverty which weighs down a great people is a grievous and intolerable evil.

quotation: Grave pondus illum, magna nobilitas premit.
translation: A grievous burden, his exalted rank weighs heavy on him.

quotation: Grave senectus est hominibus pondus.
translation: Old age is a heavy burden to man.

quotation: Grave virus Munditiae pepulere.
translation: Refinement expelled this offensive style.
notes: Horace alludes to the coarse and rugged lines of the early Roman authors, which became improved by their communication with the Greeks.

quotation: Graviora quaedam sunt remedia periculis.
translation: Some remedies are worse than the disease.
notes: This can be only said with reference to so-called remedies administered by quacks.

quotation: Gravis ira regum semper.
translation: The anger of kings is always heavy.
notes: Because they have the means of showing their displeasure.

quotation: Gravissimum est imperium consuetudinis.
translation: The empire of custom is most mighty.
notes: The tyranny of fashion is a penalty inflicted on us in conjunction with the blessings of civilization. See Usus tyrannus est.

quotation: Grex totus in agris Unius scabie cadit, et porrigine porci.
translation: The entire flock dies in the fields of the disease introduced by one, and the swine of the measles.

quotation: Grex venalium.
translation: A venal throng.
notes: An assembly whose votes are put up for sale.

quotation: Gustatus est sensus ex omnibus maxime voluptarius.
translation: The sense of taste is the most exquisite of all.
notes: Edere oportet ut vivas, &c.

quotation: Gutta cavat lapidem, consumitur annulus usu, Et teritur pressa vomer aduncus humo.
translation: The drop hollows out the stone, the ring is worn by use, and the curved ploughshare is rubbed away by the pressure of the earth.

quotation: Gutta cavat lapidem non vi sed saepe cadendo.
translation: Dripping water hollows the stone not by force, but by continually falling.

quotation: Gutta fortunae prae dolio sapientiae.
translation: A drop of fortune is worth a cask of wisdom.

quotation: Habeas corpus.
translation: You are to bring up the body.
notes: The English subject's writ of right. Where a person has been imprisoned, having offered sufficient bail, which has been refused though the case is a bailable one, the judges of the court of Chancery or the Queen's Bench may award this writ, for the discharge of the prisoner, on receiving bail.

quotation: Habeas corpus ad prosequendum.
translation: You are to bring up the body for the purpose of prosecuting.
notes: A writ for the removal of a person for trial in the proper county.

quotation: Habeas corpus ad respondendum.
translation: You are to bring up the body to make answer.
notes: A writ to remove a prisoner from the jurisdiction of a lower court to that of a higher one.

quotation: Fit sonus; inclamat comites, et lumina poscit.
translation: An uproar is the consequence; she summons her attendants, and calls for lights.

quotation: Habeas corpus ad satisfaciendum.
translation: You are to bring up the body to satisfy.
notes: A writ against a person in a lower court, where judgment has heen pronounced against him, to remove him to a superior court, that he may be charged with process of execution.

quotation: Flagrante bello.
translation: While the war was raging.

quotation: Habemus confitentem reum.
translation: We have his own confession of his guilt.

quotation: Fugiendo in media saepe ruitur fata.
translation: By precipitate flight we often rush into the very midst of destruction.
notes: Beware of desperate steps. The darkest day (Live till to-morrow) will have pass'd away." Cowper.

quotation: Flagranti delicto.Flagranti delicto.
translation: In the commission of the offence.
notes: In the very act.

quotation: Habemus luxuriam atque avaritiam, publice egestatem, privatim opulentiam.
translation: We have luxury and avarice, public want, private opulence.
notes: Cato's description of Rome in the latter days of the republic.

quotation: Habent insidias hominis blanditiae mali.
translation: The fair words of a wicked man are fraught with treachery.

quotation: Flamma fumo est proxima.
translation: Flame is near akin to smoke.
notes: So our proverb, "Where there's smoke there's fire." No rumour is without some foundation.

quotation: Fugit hora.
translation: Time flies.
notes: Lost moments can never be recovered.

quotation: Habeo senectuti magnam gratiam, quae mihi sermonis aviditatem auxit, potionis et cibi sustulit.
translation: I owe many thanks to old age, which has increased my eagerness for conversation, and has diminished my hunger and thirst.

quotation: Fugit improbus, ac me Sub cultro linquit.
translation: The rogue runs away, and leaves me under the knife.
notes: He deserts me in my danger, and leaves me to be sacrificed.

quotation: Flamma per incensas citius sedetur aristas.
translation: Sooner might the flames be extinguished among the standing corn as it burns.

quotation: Habere derelictui rem suam.
translation: To abandon one's affairs to ruin.

quotation: Fugit irreparabile tempus.
translation: Time flies, never to be regained.

quotation: Flare simul et sorbere haud facile est.
translation: It is not easy to drink and whistle at the same moment.
notes: We must not try to do two things at once.

quotation: Fuit Ilium.
translation: Ilium was.
notes: So said in reference to the former greatness of Ilium, or Troy, and the complete destruction which had befallen it. Commonly said of a thing long past. The expression may be appropriately applied to a man who is "a wreck of his former self."

quotation: Fuit ista quondam in hac republica virtus, ut viri fortes acerioribus suppliciis, civem perniciosum, quam hostem acerbissimum coercerent.
translation: Virtue once prevailed so far in this republic, that our stern rulers would subject a vicious citizen to a more severe punishment than even the most inveterate enemy.

quotation: Fulgente trahit constrictos gloria curru, Non minus ignotos generosis.
translation: Glory drags along chained to her glittering car, the humble no less than those of noble birth.

quotation: Flebile ludibrium.
translation: A deplorable mockery.
notes: Such, for instance, as a woman of seventy marrying a boy of fourteen. [See an instance in the Gentleman's Magazine, vol. i. p. 177.]

quotation: Habere facias possessionem.
translation: You are to put in possession.
notes: A writ commanding the sheriff to give seisin of land recovered in ejectment.

quotation: Flebit, et insignis tota cantabitur urbe.
translation: He shall lament it, and his name shall be sung the whole city through.
notes: The poet threatens his foes with this punishment.

quotation: Habet aliquid ex iniquo omne magnum exemplum, quod contra singulos, utilitate publica, rependitur.
translation: Every great example [of punishment] has in it some injustice, but, though it affects individuals, it is balanced by the promotion of the public good.

quotation: Flectere si nequeo superos, Acheronta movebo.
translation: If I cannot influence the gods of heaven, I will stir up Acheron itself.
notes: I will avail myself of every possible resource to accomplish my purpose. Words which are only likely to proceed from the mouth of a vindictive and unscrupulous opponent.

quotation: Fumos vendere.
translation: To sell smoke.
notes: To barter for money that which is worth nothing. A favourite of the emperor Alexander Severus was in the habit of selling his pretended interest at court, as "smoke." The emperor, on hearing of it, had him smoked to death, and proclamation made to the effect that "the seller of smoke was punished by smoke."

quotation: Habet et musca splenem.
translation: A fly even has its anger.
notes: A warning that no enemy is to be despised, however weak and insignificant. See Inest et, &c.

quotation: Fumum et opes, strepitumque Romae.
translation: The smoke, the show, the rattle of the town.

quotation: Habet iracundia hoc mali, non vult regi.
translation: Anger has this evil, that it will not be governed.

quotation: Flet victus, victor interiit.
translation: The conquered mourns, the conqueror is undone.
notes: A not uncommon result, both in war and law. This saying took its rise from the battle of Chaeronea, which caused the destruction of both the Theban and the Athenian power.

quotation: Habet natura, ut aliarum omnium rerum, sic vivendi modum; senectus autem peractio aetatis est tanquam fabulae, cujus defatigationem fugere debemus, praesertim adjuncta satietate.
translation: As in all other things, so in living, nature has prescribed to us a mean; but old age, like the last act of a play, is the closing of the scene, in which we ought to avoid too much fatigue, especially if we indulge to satiety.

quotation: Floriferis ut apes in saltibus omnia libant.
translation: As bees sip of every juice in the flowery meads.
notes: Every one who makes selections tries to do this, the man of taste alone succeeds.

quotation: Habet salem.
translation: He has wit.
notes: He is a wag.

quotation: Functus officio.
translation: Having discharged his duties.
notes: Said of one who no longer holds his former office.

quotation: Flumina jam lactis, jam flumina nectaris ibant.
translation: Now rivers of milk, rivers of nectar, were flowing.
notes: A description of the happy state of man in the Golden Age.

quotation: Habet suum venenum blanda oratio.
translation: A soft speech has its poison.

quotation: Flumina libant Summa leves.
translation: They lightly skim the surface of the rivers.

quotation: Habitus corporis quiescenti quam defuncto similior.
translation: The appearance of the body was more that of a person asleep than dead.
notes: His description of the appearance of the body of his uncle, the Elder Pliny, after his death.

quotation: Fluvius cum mari certas.
translation: You, a river, are contending with the ocean.
notes: Said to a person of small means trying to imitate the affluent.

quotation: Foedius hoc aliquid quandoque audebis.
translation: Ere long you will dare to commit some crime more base than this.

quotation: Hac jacet in tumba rosa mundi non rosa munda.
translation: In this tomb lies a rose of the world, but no chaste rose.
notes: A punning epitaph placed by the monks on the tomb of fair Rosamond, in reference to her name and lax morals.

quotation: Foedum inceptu, foedum exitu.
translation: A bad beginning leads to a bad ending.

quotation: Hac sunt in fossa Bedae venerabilis ossa.
translation: In this grave lie the bones of venerable Bede.
notes: Inscription on the tomb of Beda in Durham cathedral.

quotation: Hactenus invidiae respondimus.
translation: Thus far do I give an answer to envy.

quotation: Hae nugae seria ducent In mala, derisum semel, exceptumque sinistre.
translation: These trifles will lead to mischiefs of serious consequence, when once made an object of ridicule, and used in a sinister manner.

quotation: Fundamentum est justitiae fides.
translation: The foundation of justice is good faith.

quotation: Foenum habet in cornu, longe fuge, dummodo risum Excutiat sibi, non hic cuiquam parcit amico.
translation: He has hay upon his horn, fly afar from him, for so long as he can excite a laugh, he spares no friend.
notes: The ancients used to fasten a wisp of hay to the horns of a vicious bull. The poet speaks of an unscrupulous man, ready to say anything of another, to gratify his own vanity.

quotation: Ex delicto.
translation: From the crime.

quotation: Funem abrumpere nimium tendendo.
translation: To break the cord by stretching it too tight.
notes: In allusion to the mind, which becomes enfeebled if kept intensely applied too long.

quotation: Funera plango, fulgura frango, Sabbata pango, Excito lentos, dissipo ventos, paco cruentos.
translation: I bewail deaths, I disperse lightnings, I announce the Sabbath, I arouse the slow, I dispel the winds, I appease

quotation: Fungar inani Munere.
translation: I will discharge an unavailing duty.

quotation: Hae tibi erunt artes, pacisque imponere morem, Parcere subjectis et debellare superbos.
translation: These shall be thy arts, to prescribe the conditions of peace, to spare the conquered, and to subdue the proud.
notes: The destinies of Rome.

quotation: Fungar vice cotis, acutum Reddere quae ferrum valet, exsors ipsa secandi.
translation: I will act the part of a whetstone, which can give an edge to iron, while incapable of cutting itself.
notes: Literary critics, like whetstones, often give to others an edge.

quotation: Ex desuetudine amittuntur privilegia.
translation: Rights are forfeited by non-user.

quotation: Haec amat obscurum; volet haec sub luce videri, Judicis argutum quae non formidat acumen; Haec placuit semel; hac decies repetita placebit.
translation: The one courts the shade; another, who is not afraid of the critic's caustic acumen, chooses to be seen in the light; the one has pleased once, the other will give pleasure if ten times repeated.

quotation: Fons omnium viventium.
translation: The fountain of all living things.
notes: The Deity.

quotation: Ex diuturnitate temporis omnia praesumuntur esse solemniter acta.
translation: From length of time everything is presumed to have been solemnly done.

quotation: Haec a te non multum abludit imago.
translation: This picture bears no slight resemblance to you.

quotation: Fontes ipsi sitiunt.
translation: Even the fountains are athirst.
notes: Said ironically of wealthy men who are covetous.

quotation: Haec brevis est nostrorum summa malorum.
translation: This is the short sum of our evils.

quotation: Ex eodem ore calidum et frigidum efflare.
translation: To blow hot and cold with the same mouth.
notes: This adage is founded on the Fable of the Satyr and the Traveller.

quotation: Haec ego mecum Compressis agito labris; ubi quid datur oti, Illudo chartis.
translation: These things I revolve by myself in silence. When I have any leisure I amuse myself with my papers.

quotation: Ex factis non ex dictis amici pensandi.
translation: Friends are to be estimated from their deeds, not their words.

quotation: Forma bonum fragile est.
translation: Beauty is a frail advantage.

quotation: Ex facto jus oritur.
translation: The law arises from the fact.
notes: Until the nature of the crime is known, the law cannot be put in force.

quotation: Forma pauperis.
translation: In form of a poor man.
notes: See In forma, &c.

quotation: Ex habitu homines metientes.
translation: Estimators of men from their outward appearances.

quotation: Forma viros neglecta decet.
translation: A neglect of personal appearance becomes men.

quotation: Ex humili magna ad fastigia rerum Extollit, quoties voluit fortuna jocari.
translation: As oft as fortune is in sportive mood, she raises men from an humble station to the highest pinnacle of power.

quotation: Haec facil, ut vivat vinctus quoque compede fossor; Liberaque a ferro crura futura putet.
translation: Hope it is that makes even the miner, bound with the fetter, to live on, and to trust that his legs will be liberated from the iron.

quotation: Formam quidem ipsam, Marce fili, et tanquam faciem honesti vides; quae si oculis cerneretur, mirabiles amores excitaret sapientiae.
translation: You see, my son Marcus, the very figure and features, as it were, of virtue; and, if it could only be beheld by our eyes, it would excite a marvellous love for wisdom.

quotation: Format enim natura prius nos intus ad omnem Fortunarum habitum; juvat, aut impellit ad iram, Aut ad humum moerore gravi deducit et angit; Post effert animi motus interprete lingua.
translation: For nature forms us first within to every modification of circumstances; she delights us, impels us to anger, or depresses us to the earth, and afflicts us with heavy sorrow; and then expresses these emotions of the mind by the tongue, its interpreter.

quotation: Ex inimico cogita posse fieri amicum.
translation: Think that you may possibly make of an enemy a friend.
notes: Avoid extremes in enmities. See Amicum, &c.

quotation: Formidabilior cervorum exercitus, duce leone, quam leonum cervo.
translation: An army of stags would be more formidable under the command of a lion, than one of lions under the command of a stag.
notes: Everything depends upon generalship.

quotation: Ex magna coena stomacho fit maxima poena, Ut sis nocte levis, sit tibi coena brevis.
translation: From a heavy supper great uneasiness to the stomach is produced; that you may enjoy a good night's rest, let your supper be moderate.
notes: A Leonine or rhyming couplet, not improbably issued by the School of Health at Salerno.

quotation: Ex malis moribus bonae leges natae sunt.
translation: From bad manners good laws have sprung.

quotation: Fungino genere est, capite se totum tegit.
translation: He is of the mushroom kind — he covers all his body with his head.
notes: Said of a man having a petasus, or broad-brimmed hat.

quotation: Ex mero motu.
translation: From a mere motion;
notes: of one's own free will.

quotation: Haec perinde sunt, ut illius animus, qui ea possidet, Qui uti scit, ei bona, illi qui non utitur recte, mala.
translation: These blessings are just according to the disposition of him who possesses them. To him who knows how to use them, they are blessings; to him who does not use them aright, they are evils.

quotation: Ex necessitate rei.
translation: From the urgency of the case.

quotation: Haec prima lex in amicitia sanciatur, ut neque rogemus res turpes, nec faciamus rogati.
translation: This is the first law to be established in friendship, that we neither ask of others that which is dishonourable, nor ourselves do it when asked.

quotation: Fungino genere est, subito crevit de nihilo.
translation: He is of the mushroom genus, he has suddenly sprung up from nothing.

quotation: Haec, pro amicitia nostra, non occultavi.
translation: These things, in consideration of our friendship, I have not concealed from you.
notes: Said by Tiberius to his unworthy favourite, Sejanus.

quotation: Funiculis ligatum vel puer verberaret.
translation: A man bound with cords even a child can beat.

quotation: Ex nihilo nihil fit.
translation: From nothing nothing is made.
notes: Nothing can come of nothing.

quotation: Ex officio.
translation: By virtue of his office.

quotation: Ex otio plus negotii quam ex negotio habemus.
translation: From our leisure we get more to do, than from our business.
notes: Especially when it gives us the opportunity of falling into mischief.

quotation: Ex parte.
translation: On one part.
notes: Evidence given on one side only is called ex parte.

quotation: Ex pede Herculem.
translation: You may judge of Hercules from his foot.
notes: Pythagoras ascertained the length of the foot of Hercules by taking the length of the Olympic stadium or course, which was six hundred feet, originally measured by the foot of the hero. He thence came to the conclusion that his height was six feet seven inches. From this circumstance was formed the proverb, meaning that we may judge of the whole from the part.

quotation: Ex post facto.
translation: Done after another thing.
notes: A law enacted purposely to take cognizance of an offence already committed, is, so far as that individual offence is concerned, an ex post facto law.

quotation: Hirundines aestivo tempore praesto sunt: frigore pulsae recedunt. Ita falsi amici.
translation: The swallows in summer are among us; in cold weather they are driven away. So it is with false friends.
notes: Such friends may justly be called fair-weather friends.

quotation: Ex quovis ligno non fit Mercurius.
translation: A Mercury is not to be made out of every log.
notes: Mercury being a graceful god, it was not out of every piece of wood that his statue could be made.

quotation: Haec scripsi non otii abundantia, sed amoris erga te.
translation: I have written this, not from having an abundance of leisure, but of love for you.

quotation: Ex tempore.
translation: Off-hand.
notes: On the spur of the moment, or, without preparation.

quotation: Haec studia adolescentiam alunt, senectutem oblectant, secundas res ornant, adversis solatium ac perfugium praebent, delectant domi, non impediunt foris, pernoctant nobiscum, peregrinantur, rusticantur.
translation: These studies are as food, to us in our youth, they are the solace of our old age, the ornament of our prosperity, the comfort and refuge of our adversity; they amuse us at home, they are no encumbrance abroad, they pass the night with us, accompany us on our travels, and share our rural retirement.
notes: So true it is, that books are the best, the most truthful, and the most constant of friends.

quotation: Ex umbra in solem.
translation: Out of the shade into the sunshine.
notes: You have rendered clear what was obscure before.

quotation: His lachrymis vitam damus, et miserescimus ultro.
translation: To these tears we concede his life, and willingly show mercy.

quotation: Hac sunt jucundi causa cibusque mali.
translation: These things are at once the cause and the nutriment of the delightful malady.

quotation: His legibus solutis respublica stare non potest.
translation: These laws once repealed, the republic cannot last.

quotation: Ex ungue leonem.
translation: You can tell the lion by his claw.
notes: The master's hand may be known in the specimen.

quotation: His nunc praemium est, qui recta prava faciunt.
translation: In these days they are rewarded who make right appear wrong.

quotation: Ex uno disce omnes.
translation: From one learn all.
notes: From one example you may judge of all. What has been said of one may be said of the rest. See Crimine ab uno, &c.

quotation: Furari litoris arenas.
translation: To steal the sands of the sea-shore.
notes: Said of those who prize things of no value to any one else.

quotation: Haec sunt quae nostra liceat te voce moneri. Vade age.
translation: These are all the points on which I am allowed to offer you advice. Begone then.

quotation: Ex factis non ex dictis amici pensandi.
translation: Friends are to be estimated from their deeds, not their words.

quotation: Haec vivendi ratio mihi non convenit.
translation: This mode of living does not suit me.

quotation: Ex facto jus oritur.
translation: The law arises from the fact.
notes: Until the nature of the crime is known, the law cannot be put in force.

quotation: Haeredem Deus facit, non homo.
translation: It is God that makes the heir, not man.
notes: Because no man is the heir of another who is alive. See Nemo est haeres. &c.

quotation: Furiosus absentis loco est.
translation: A madman is looked upon as absent.
notes: Because of the absence of reason.

quotation: Haeridis fletus sub persona risus est.
translation: The tears of an heir are laughter beneath a mask.
notes: It is to be hoped that this saying has more wit than truth in it.

quotation: Haeredum appellatione veniunt haeredes haeredum in infinitum.
translation: Under the appellation of heirs come the heirs of heirs for everlasting.
notes: Haeres haeredem, &c. See Perpetuus nulli, &c.

quotation: Furiosus furore sua punitur.
translation: A madman is punished by his own madness.
notes: The affliction of madness is quite sufficient, without the sufferer being made responsible for his acts. The sentence may also be made to mean that a furious man causes suffering and repentance to himself by giving way to passion.

quotation: Ex habitu homines metientes.
translation: Estimators of men from their outward appearances.

quotation: Haeres jure repraesentationis.
translation: An heir by right of representation.
notes: Thus, a grandson inherits from his grandfather, as representing his father.

quotation: Furor arma ministrat.
translation: Their rage supplies them with arms.
notes: Said of the desperation manifested in a popular insurrection, or in a captured city, when each uses as a weapon whatever comes to hand. Thus Abimelech and Pyrrhus were slain by missiles thrown by women, on the capture of a city.

quotation: Haeres legitimus est quem nuptiae demonstrant.
translation: He is the legitimate heir, whom the marriage ceremony points out as such.
notes: To be an heir, a person must be born, though he may not have been procreated, in wedlock.

quotation: Furor est post omnia perdere naulum.
translation: It is sheer madness, when everything else is gone, to lose one's passage-money too.
notes: It is unwise to cut off every hope.

quotation: Haeret lateri lethalis arundo.
translation: The fatal shaft remains fixed in her side.
notes: Words emblematical of the deep-seated wounds of love, envv, or remorse.

quotation: Furor fit laesa saepius patientia.
translation: Patience, when trespassed on too often, is converted into rage.

quotation: Halcyonii dies.
translation: Halcyon days.
notes: The kingfisher, or halcyon, was supposed to sit upon her nest, as it floated, for seven days in the winter, upon the sea; during which time that element was always calm; hence the expression, "Halcyon days," expressive of a time of happiness or peace.

quotation: Hanc cupit, hanc optat; sola suspirat in illa; Signaque dat nutu, solicitatque notis.
translation: Her he desires, for her he longs, for her alone he sighs; he makes signs to her by nods, and courts her by gestures.

quotation: Hanc veniam petimusque damusque vicissim.
translation: We expect this privilege, and we give it in return.

quotation: Has poenas garrula lingua dedit.
translation: This punishment has a prating tongue incurred.

quotation: Has vaticinationes eventus comprobavit.
translation: The event has verified these predictions.

quotation: His saltem accumulem donis, et fungar inani Munere.
translation: These offerings at least I would bestow upon him, and discharge this unavailing duty.
notes: A quotation often used with reference to distinguished men when deceased.

quotation: Haud aequum facit, Qui quod didicit, id dediscit.
translation: He does not do right who unlearns what he has learnt.

quotation: Haud facile emergunt quorum virtutibus obstat Res angusta domi.
translation: Those persons do not easily rise, whose talents are impeded by limited means.

quotation: Hoc age.
translation: Do this.
notes: Or "attend to this."

quotation: Haud ignara ac non incauta futuri.
translation: Neither ignorant, nor regardless, of the future.
notes: Said of the ant.

quotation: Huc natas adjice septem, Et totidem juvenes, et mox generosque nurusque, Quaerite nunc, habeat quam nostra superbia causam.
translation: Add to this my seven daughters, and as many sons, and ere long my sons-in-law and daughters-in-law; then inquire what reason I have for being proud.
notes: The vainglorious words of the unfortunate Niobe.

quotation: Hoc decet uxores; dos est uxoria lites.
translation: This befits wives only; strife is the dowry of a wife.

quotation: Haud ignara mali miseris succurrere disco.
translation: Not unacquainted with misfortune, I have learned to succour the wretched.
notes: The words of Dido, whom misfortunes had made more kind than wise, to the shipwrecked Aeneas.

quotation: Huc propius me, Dum doceo insanire omnes, vos ordine adite.
translation: Hither, all of you, come near me in order, while I convince you that you are mad.

quotation: Haud passibus aequis.
translation: Not with equal steps.
notes: These words are sometimes applied to a person who has been distanced by another in the race of life.

quotation: Huic maxime putamus malo fuisse, nimiam opinionem ingenii atque virtutis.
translation: This we think was his especial misfortune, that he entertained too high an opinion of his own genius and valour.
notes: The character of Themistocles.

quotation: Hectora quis nosset, si felix Troja fuisset? Publica virtuti per mala facta via est.
translation: Who would have known of Hector, if Troy had been fortunate? A path is opened to virtue through the midst of misfortunes.

quotation: Huic versatile ingenium sic pariter ad omnia fuit, ut natum ad id unum diceres, quodcunque ageret.
translation: This man's genius was so versatile, so equally adapted to every pursuit, that in whatever he engaged, you would pronounce him to have been born for that very thing alone.
notes: The character of the elder Cato.

quotation: Hujus aquae tactus depellit daemonis actus.
translation: The contact of this water dispels the wiles of the devil.
notes: A mediaeval line describing the alleged virtues of holy water.

quotation: Humani nihil alienum.
translation: Nothing that concerns a man is indifferent to me.
notes: Motto of Earl Talbot.

quotation: Humanitati qui se non accommodat, Plerumque poenas oppetit superbiae.
translation: He who does not conform to courtesy, mostly pays the penalty of his superciliousness.

quotation: Humanum amare est, humanum autem ignoscere est.
translation: It is natural to love, and it is natural also to be considerate.

quotation: Humanum est errare.
translation: It is the nature of man to err.
notes: The result of his finite comprehension. "To err is human, to forgive divine." Pope.

quotation: Humanum facinus factum est. Actutum fortunae solent mutarier. Varia vita est.
translation: The common course of things has happened. Fortunes are wont to change upon the instant. Life is chequered.

quotation: Humiles laborant ubi potentes dissident.
translation: The humble are in danger, when the powerful disagree.
notes: See Quicquid delirant, &c.

quotation: Hei mihi! hei mihi! Isthaec illum perdidit assentatio.
translation: Ah me! ah me! this over-indulgence has proved his ruin.

quotation: Hunc comedendum et deridendum vobis propino.
translation: I make him over to you to eat and drink him to the very dregs.
notes: The figure is taken from the custom of tasting of a cup of wine, and then handing it to another.

quotation: Hei mihi! non magnas quod habent mea carmina vires, Nostraque sunt meritis ora minora tuis!
translation: Ah me! that these my verses have so little weight, and that my praises are so inferior to your deserts.

quotation: Hysteron proteron.
translation: The last first.
notes: The Greek hýsteron próteron, Latinized. A figure of speech in which the order of things is inverted, as in the lines of Virgil, Georg. b. iii. l. 60, and Aen. b. iii. l. 662. See also Aen. b. ii. l. 353, — Moriamur, et in media arma ruamus. — "Let us die, and rush upon their weapons."

quotation: Hei mihi, quod nostri toties pulsata sepulcri Janua, sed nullo tempore aperta fuit.
translation: Ah! wretched me! that the door of my tomb should so oft have been knocked at, but never opened!

quotation: I. E.
translation: That is.
notes: for id est.

quotation: Heu! Fortuna, quis est crudelior in nos Te Deus? Ut semper gaudes illudere rebus Humanis.
translation: Alas! O Fortune, what god is more cruel to us than thou? How much thou dost always delight in making sport of the fortunes of men!

quotation: I. H. S.
translation: It may mean, Jesus hominum Salvator, "Jesus the Saviour of men,"" or In hoc solus, ""In him is salvation."" Or for the beginning of the Greek IHESOUS, ""Jesus."""
notes: An inscription sometimes attached to the figure of the cross.

quotation: Heu melior quanto sors tua sorte mea!
translation: Alas! how much better is your fate than mine!

quotation: Hoc erat in more majorum.
translation: This was the custom of our forefathers.

quotation: I. N. R. I.
translation: Jesus of Nazareth, King of the Jews.
notes: for Jesus Nazarenus Rex Judaeorum. The inscription over the cross.

quotation: Heu pietas! Heu prisca fides!
translation: Alas! for piety — Alas! for our ancient faith!

quotation: I. Q.
translation: The same as.
notes: for idem quod.

quotation: Hoc erat in votis; modus agri non ita magnus; Hortus ubi, et tecto vicinus jugis aquae fons, Et paulum silvae super his foret.
translation: This was ever the extent of my wishes; a portion of ground not over large, in which is a garden, and a fountain with its continual stream close to my house, and a little woodland beside.

quotation: Heu! quam difficile est crimen non prodere vultu!
translation: Alas! how difficult it is not to betray guilt by our looks!

quotation: I, bone, quo virtus tua te vocat; i pede fausto, Grandia laturus meritorum praemia.
translation: Go, my brave fellow, whither your valour calls you, go with prosperous step, certain to receive the ample rewards of your merit.
notes: Words addressed to a soldier who had by his valour already won a purse of gold. To which he made answer, Ibit eo quo, &c, which see.

quotation: Heu! Quam difficilis gloriae custodia est!
translation: Alas! how difficult is the guardianship of glory!
notes: Because more is expected of him who has once distinguished himself, than of the crowd of his fellow-men.

quotation: Heu! Quam miserum est ab eo laedi, de quo non ausis queri.
translation: Alas! how grievous is it to be injured by one against whom you dare make no complaint.

quotation: I demens! et saevas curre per Alpes, Ut pueris placeas, et declamatio fias.
translation: Go, madman! run over the rugged Alps, that thou

quotation: Heu! Quanto minus est cum reliquis versari, quam tui meminisse!
translation: Alas! how little the pleasure of conversing with those who are left, compared with that of remembering thee.
notes: Shenstone's epitaph on Miss Dolman. "To live with them is far less sweet Than to remember thee." Moore.

quotation: I nunc, et veterum nobis exempla virorum, Qui forti casum mente tulere refer.
translation: Come now, and recount to me the examples of men of ancient times, who have endured evils with fortitude.

quotation: Heu quantum fati parva tabella vehit!
translation: Ah! what a weight of destiny does one slight plank carry!
notes: In allusion to a ship.

quotation: I nunc, magnificos, victor, molire triumphos, Cinge comam lauro, votaque redde Jovi.
translation: Go now, thou conqueror, acquire splendid triumphs, encircle thy brows with laurel, and pay thy vows to Jove.

quotation: Heu! totum triduum.
translation: Alas! a whole three days.
notes: The language of an impatient lover.

quotation: Ibi omnis Effusus labor.
translation: There all his labour is lost.
notes: Said of Orpheus, who lost Eurydice when bringing her back from the infernal regions.

quotation: Hi motus animarum, atque haec certamina tanta Pulveris exigui jactu compressa quiescent.
translation: These commotions of their minds, and these mighty frays, checked by the throwing of a little dust, will cease.
notes: Said of the battles of the bees. These lines have been applied to the Carnival of the Roman Church, and the season of repose which follows immediately after the ceremony of sprinkling the ashes on Ash Wednesday.

quotation: Ibis, redibis, non morieris in bello.
translation: Thou shalt go, thou shalt return, thou shalt not die in battle.
notes: This may be also read, by changing the punctuation, Ibis, redibis non, morieris in bello. "Thou shalt go, thou shalt not return, thou shalt die in battle." An ambiguous answer given by an oracle; which, as punctuation was not used in ancient times, might save the credit of the oracle either way.

quotation: Hi narrata ferunt alio; mensuraque ficti crescit; et auditis aliquid novus adjicit auctor.
translation: These carry elsewhere what has been told them; the sum of the falsehood is ever on the increase, and each fresh narrator adds something to what he has heard.

quotation: Ibit eo quo vis, qui zonam perdidit.
translation: He who has lost his girdle, will go wherever you please.
notes: Among the ancients, money, or the purse, was sometimes kept within the girdle. It is of the same meaning as our homely adage, "Hungry dogs eat dirty puddings." See Graeculus esuriens, &c.

quotation: Hiatus maxime deflendus.
translation: A deficiency very much to be deplored.
notes: Words used to mark a blank in a work, which has been rendered defective by accident or time. It is sometimes used in an ironical sense, in reference to speakers or other persons who make great promises, which they fail to perform.

quotation: Id arbitror, Adprime in vita esse utile, ne quid nimis.
translation: This I consider in life to be especially advantageous; that one do nothing to excess.
notes: See Sunt certi, &c.

quotation: Hibernicis ipsis Hibernior.
translation: More Irish than the Irish themselves.
notes: A specimen of modern dog Latin, quoted against those who are guilty of bulls or other absurdities.

quotation: Id cinerem aut manes credis curare sepultos?
translation: Do you suppose that the ashes of the dead, or the shades of the buried, care for that?
notes: The poet's less enlightened countrymen believed, however, that ghosts ate and drank at certain periods of the year, and especially at the time of the Feralia, which they celebrated in February. See Ovid's Fasti, b. ii. l. 566, et seq.

quotation: Hic coquus scite ac munditer condit cibos.
translation: This cook seasons his dishes well, and serves them up neatly.

quotation: Id commune malum, semel insanivimus omnes.
translation: It is a common ill, that we have all been mad once.
notes: Ecl. i.

quotation: Hic dies vere mihi festus atras Eximet curas.
translation: This day, to me a real festival, shall expel gloomy cares.
notes: Said originally in reference to the day on which Augustus returned to Rome from Spain.

quotation: Id demum est homini turpe, quod meruit pati.
translation: That only is really disgraceful to a man, which he has deserved to suffer.

quotation: Hic est aut nusquam quod quaerimus.
translation: What we seek is either here or nowhere.

quotation: Id ego jam nunc tibi renuncio tibi ut sis sciens.
translation: I now warn you of it, that you may be on your guard.

quotation: Hic est muero defensionis meae.
translation: This is my weapon of defence.
notes: This is the point of my argument.

quotation: Id est.
translation: That is.
notes: Commonly expressed by the initials i.e.

quotation: Hic et ubique.
translation: Here and everywhere.
notes: Words sometimes used in reference to the omnipresence of the Deity.

quotation: Id facere laus est quod decet, non quod licet.
translation: To do what is becoming, not what the law allows, is true merit.
notes: There are many moral offences, which it is impossible to bring within the strict letter of the law, but which it is our duty to avoid equally with those which are criminal.

quotation: Id genus omne.
translation: All that class.
notes: An expression which contemptuously alludes to the scum of the populace.

quotation: Id maxime quemque decet, quod est cujusque suum maxime.
translation: That thing best becomes us, which belongs to our station.
notes: See Ne sutor, &c.

quotation: Hic finis fandi.
translation: Here ends the discourse.
notes: Let our conversation end here.

quotation: Id mutavit quia me immutatum videt.
translation: Because he sees me unchanged he has changed.

quotation: Hic funis nihil attraxit.
translation: This line has taken no fish.
notes: This plan has not answered.

quotation: Hic gelidi fontes, hic mollia prata, Lycori, Hic nemus, hic toto tecum consumerer aevo.
translation: Here are cooling springs, here grassy meads; here, Lycoris, the grove; here with thee could I pass my whole life.

quotation: Id nobis maxime nocet, quod non ad rationis lumen sed ad similitudinem aliorum vivimus.
translation: This is especially detrimental to us, that we live, not according to the light of reason, but after the fashion set by others.
notes: We "follow the multitude to do evil."

quotation: Hic locus est, partes ubi se via findit in ambas.
translation: This is the spot where the road divides into two parts.

quotation: Id vero est, quod ego mihi puto palmarium, Me reperisse, quo modo adolescentulus Meretricum ingenia et mores posset noscere: Mature ut cum cognovit, perpetuo oderit.
translation: That is a thing that I really consider my crowning merit, to have found out the way by which a young man may be enabled to learn the dispositions and manners of courtesans, so that by knowing them betimes he may detest them for ever after.

quotation: Idem quod.
translation: The same as.
notes: Commonly expressed by the initials, i. q.

quotation: Hoc est quod palles? cur quis non prandeat, hoc est?
translation: Is it for this you grow pale? Is it for this that one should go without his dinner?

quotation: Hic manus, ob patriam pugnando vulnera passi, Quique pii vates, et Phoebo digna locuti: Inventas aut qui vitam excoluere per artes, Quique sui memores alios fecere merendo.
translation: Here is a band of those who have sustained wounds in fighting for their country; pious poets, who sang in strains worthy of Apollo; those who improved life by the invention of arts, and who, by their deserts, have made others mindful of them.

quotation: Hic murus aheneus esto, Nil conscire sibi, nulla pallescere culpa.
translation: Let this be as a brazen wall of defence, to be conscious of no guilt, to turn pale at no accusation.
notes: An admirable picture of the advantages of a good conscience.

quotation: Hoc est Vivere bis, vita posse priore frui.
translation: It is to live twice over, to be able to enjoy the retrospect of our past life.

quotation: Hic nigrae succus loliginis, haec est Aerugo mera.
translation: This is the invention of black envy, this is sheer cankered malice.

quotation: Hoc fonte derivata clades, In patriam, populumque fluxit.
translation: Derived from this source, perdition has overwhelmed the nation and the people.
notes: The poet says that the misfortunes of the Romans in their wars with the Parthians originated in the depravity then universally prevalent.

quotation: Hic patet ingeniis campus, certusque merenti Stat favor: ornatur propriis industria donis.
translation: Here lies a field open for talent, and certain favour awaits the deserving; industry is graced with her appropriate reward.

quotation: Hic poterit cavere recte, jura qui et leges tenet.
translation: He will he able to take all due precautions, who understands the laws and ordinances.

quotation: Hoc maxime officii est, ut quisquis maxime opus indigeat, ita ei potissimum opitulari.
translation: It is more especially our duty, to aid him in preference who stands most in need of our assistance.

quotation: Idem velle et idem nolle ea demum firma amicitia est.
translation: To have the same tastes and the same dislikes — this in fact is the basis of lasting friendship.

quotation: Hoc opus, hoc studium, parvi properemus et ampli, Si patriae volumus, si nobis vivere cari.
translation: Let us, both small and great, push forward in this work, in this pursuit; if to our country, if to ourselves, we would be dear.

quotation: Idoneus quidem mea sententia, praesertim quum et ipse eum audiverit, ut scribat de mortuo; ex quo nulla suspicio est, amicitiae causa, eum esse mentitum.
translation: In my opinion he is qualified to write (of the deceased), especially as he had been accustomed to hear him speak; for which reason there can be no ground for suspicion, that he has, for motives of friendship, stated what is false.

quotation: Hoc pretium ob stultitiam fero.
translation: This is the reward I gain for my folly.

quotation: Ignavis semper feriae sunt.
translation: With fools it is always holiday.
notes: Idle persons can always find an excuse for indolence.

quotation: Hic rogo, non furor est ne moriare mori?
translation: I ask, is it not downright madness to kill yourself, that you may not die?
notes: How! leap into the pit our life to save? To save our life leap all into the grave?" Cowper.

quotation: Hoc quoque, quam volui, plus est. Cane, Musa, receptus.
translation: Even this is more than I wished to say. My Muse, sound a retreat.

quotation: Ignavissimus quisque, et, ut res docuit, in periculo non ausurus, nimio verbis et lingua ferox.
translation: Every cowardly fellow, who, as experience tells us, will skulk in the hour of danger, is noisy and blustering with his words and language.
notes: The best pictures of a blustering coward are the two captains, Thraso, in the Eunuchus of Terence, and Pyrgopolinices, in the Miles Gloriosus of Plautus, both of whom are first-rate vapourers.

quotation: Hic secura quies, et nescia fallere vita, Dives opum variarum; hic latis otia fundis, Speluncae, vivique lacus; hic frigida Tempe, Mugitusque boum, mollesque sub arbore somni.
translation: Here is quiet free from care, and life ignorant of guile, rich in varied opulence; here are peaceful retreats in ample fields, grottoes and refreshing lakes; here are cool valleys, and the lowing kine, and soft slumbers beneath the tree.
notes: The first hic is here substituted for at.

quotation: Hoc scio pro certo, quod si cum stercore certo, Vinco seu vincor, semper ego maculor.
translation: This I know for certain, that when I contend with filth, whether I vanquish or am vanquished, I am always soiled.
notes: Leonine rhymes.

quotation: Hoc scito, nimio celerius Venire quod molestum est, quam id quod cupide petas.
translation: Know this, that that which is disagreeable comes much more speedily than that which you eagerly desire.

quotation: Hoc tibi sit argumentum, semper in promptu situm, Ne quid expectes amicos facere, quod per te queas.
translation: Let this be your rule of life, always to be acted upon, expect not your friends to do anything that you can do yourself.

quotation: Ignavum fucos pecus a praesepibus arcent.
translation: [The bees] drive from their hives the drones, a lazy race.

quotation: Hic segetes, illuc veniunt felicius uvae: Arborei foetus alibi, atque injussa virescunt Gramina.
