translation: Here grain, there grapes more abundantly grow; nurseries of trees elsewhere, and grass spontaneously spring up.

quotation: Hoc tolerabile si non Et furere incipias.
translation: This might be endurable, if you did not begin to rave.

quotation: Igne quid utilius? si quis tamen urere tecta Comparat, audaces instruit igne manus.
translation: What is there more useful than fire? and yet, if any one prepares to burn a house, it is with fire that he arms his rash hands.
notes: Every blessing may be abused.

quotation: Hic situs est Phaeton currus auriga paterni; Quem si non tenuit, magnis tamen excidit ausis.
translation: Here Phaeton lies buried, the driver of his father's car; which if he did not manage, still he miscarried in a great attempt.
notes: The epitaph on the rash son of Apollo.

quotation: Hoc volo, sic jubeo, &c.
notes: See Sic volo, &c.

quotation: Ignem ne glodio fodito.
translation: Stir not the fire with a sword.
notes: Do not irritate an angry person, — or, as we say, "add fuel to flame."

quotation: Hic transitus efficit magnum vitae compendium.
translation: This change effects a great saving of our time.

quotation: Ignis fatuus.
translation: A deceiving light.
notes: The Will o' the wisp, or Jack-a-lantern. These words are sometimes used figuratively to denote a false light, tending to lead men astray.

quotation: Hodie mihi, cras tibi.
translation: Today for myself, tomorrow for you.
notes: Inscribed over the elder Wyatt's epitaph at Ditchley.

quotation: Hic ubi nunc urbs est, tum locus urbis erat.
translation: Here, where now the city stands, was then the city's site.

quotation: Ignis sacer.
translation: St. Anthony's fire.
notes: or Erisypelas. Columella calls by the same name an incurable and contagious disease among sheep.

quotation: Hic ver assiduum, atque alienis mensibus aestas.
translation: Here is everlasting spring, and summer in months that are not her own.

quotation: Hodie nihil, cras credo.
translation: Tomorrow I will trust, not today.
notes: See Cras credimus, &c.

quotation: Hic vivimus ambitiosa Paupertate omnes.
translation: Here we all live in an ostentatious poverty.
notes: The poorest man in a company is very often found to have the best coat.

quotation: Hodie vivendum amissa praeteritorum cura.
translation: Let us live today, dismissing all care for the past.
notes: Epicurean advice, given by a boon companion.

quotation: Hilarisque tamen cum pondere virtus.
translation: Virtue may be gay, but with dignity.
notes: Be merry and wise."

quotation: Homine imperito nunquam quidquam injustius, Qui, nisi quod ipse facit, nil rectum putat.
translation: There is nothing more unreasonable than a man who wants experience, one who thinks nothing right except what he himself has done.

quotation: Ignoramus.
translation: We are ignorant.
notes: A term employed when a grand jury ignores an indictment. The word is jokingly applied to an ignorant man, a dolt.

quotation: Hominem non odi sed ejus vitia.
translation: I hate not the man, but his vices.

quotation: Ignorantia facti excusat.
translation: Ignorance of the fact excuses.
notes: A contract being falsely read or explained to an ignorant man, and executed by him under the false impression produced thereby, is void.

quotation: Hominem pagina nostra sapit.
translation: Our pages understand human nature.
notes: We write from experience.

quotation: Hinc illae lachrymae.
translation: Hence those tears.
notes: The cause of his grief is now seen.

quotation: Ignorantia juris quod quisque tenetur scire neminem excusat.
translation: Ignorance of a law which every man is bound to know is no excuse.

quotation: Homines ad deos nulla re propius accedunt quam salutem hominibus dando.
translation: In nothing do men more nearly approach the gods, than in giving health to men.

quotation: Ignorantia non excusat legem.
translation: Ignorance is no plea against the law.
notes: To the same effect as the last.

quotation: Hinc omne principium, huc refer exitum.
translation: To this refer every undertaking, to this the issue thereof.
notes: To the decrees of Providence.

quotation: Homines amplius oculis quam auribus credunt: longum iter est per praecepta, breve et efficax per exempla.
translation: Men believe their eyes rather than their ears — the road by precept is long, by example short and sure.

quotation: Homines nihil agendo discunt male agere.
translation: By having nothing to do, men learn to do evil.
notes: For Satan always mischief finds For idle hands to do." Watts.

quotation: Homines proniores sunt ad voluptatem, quam ad virtutem.
translation: Men are more prone to pleasure than to virtue.

quotation: Homines qui gestant, quique auscultant crimina, Si meo arbitratu liceat, omnes pendeant, Gestores linguis, auditores auribus.
translation: Those men who carry about, and those who listen to, accusations, should all be hanged, if I could have my way, the carriers by their tongues, the hearers by their ears.

quotation: Hinc subitae mortes atque intestata senectus.
translation: Hence arise sudden deaths, and an intestate old age.
notes: Debauchery and excesses cut short the lives of their votaries, and by a sudden death deprive them of the opportunity of making their will.

quotation: Ignoratione rerum bonarum et malarum, maxime hominum vita vexatur.
translation: Through ignorance of what is good and what is bad, the life of man is greatly troubled.

quotation: Hinc tibi copia Manabit ad plenum benigno Ruris honorum opulenta cornu.
translation: Here plenty, rich in rural honours, shall flow for you, with her generous horn full to the very brim.
notes: In allusion to the Cornucopia.

quotation: Ignorent populi, si non in morte probaris, An scires adversa pati.
translation: The people would be ignorant, if you did not prove by your death that you were capable of supporting adversity.
notes: Words addressed to Pompey, whom the poet represents as a hero, while he makes Julius Caesar little better than a demon.

quotation: Hinc totam infelix vulgatur fama per urbem.
translation: Hence the unhappy report was spread throughout the whole city.

quotation: Hinc usura vorax, avidumque in tempore foenus, Et concussa fides, et multis utile bellum.
translation: Hence devouring usury, and interest accumulating by lapse of time — hence shaken credit, and warfare profitable to the many.

quotation: Ignoscas aliis multa, nil tibi.
translation: Pardon others for many an offence, yourself for none.

quotation: Hinc venti dociles resono se carcere solvunt, Et cantum accepta pro libertate rependunt.
translation: Hence the obedient winds are loosed from their durance as they sound, and give melody in return for the liberty they have received.
notes: Words very applicable to the Aeolian harp.

quotation: Ignoscent si quid peccavero stultus amici, Inque vicem illorum patiar delicta libenter.
translation: If I, in my foolishness, commit any offence, let my friends pardon it; I, in my turn, will willingly bear with their failings.

quotation: Hirundinem sub eodem tecto ne habeas.
translation: Do not have a swallow under the same roof.
notes: Do not make friends of those who will leave you when the spring and fair weather are past.

quotation: Ignoscito saepe alteri, nunquam tibi.
translation: Pardon others often, yourself never.

quotation: Homines quo plura habent, eo ampliora cupiunt.
translation: The more men have, the more they want.

quotation: Ignoti nulla cupido.
translation: There can be no desire for that which is unknown.
notes: Our wants are very much increased by knowledge and example.

quotation: Hominis est errare, insipientis perseverare.
translation: It is the nature of man to err, of a fool to persevere in error.

quotation: Ignotis errare locis, ignota videre Flumina gaudebat, studio minuente laborem.
translation: He loved to wander over unknown spots, and to see unknown rivers, his curiosity lessening the fatigue.

quotation: Hominis frugi et temperantis functus officio.
translation: One who has acted the part of a virtuous and temperate man.

quotation: Ignotum argenti pondus et auri.
translation: An untold weight of silver and gold.

quotation: Ille fuit vitae Mario modus, omnia passo Quae pejor fortuna potest, atque omnibus uso Quae melior.
translation: Such was the course of Marius' life, who suffered all that ill fortune could inflict, and enjoyed all that good fortune could bestow.
notes: Marius experienced, perhaps, more vicissitudes than any man we read of in history. See Plutarch's Life of him.

quotation: Hominum sententia fallax.
translation: The opinions of men are fallible.

quotation: Ignotum per ignotius.
translation: A thing not understood by a thing still less understood.
notes: An attempt at illustration which only adds to the previous obscurity.

quotation: Homo ad res perspicacior Lynceo vel Argo, et oculeus totus.
translation: A man more clear-sighted than Lynceus or Argus, and eyes all over.

quotation: Homo constat ex duabus partibus, corpore et anima, quorum una est corporea, altera ab omni materiae concretione sejuncta.
translation: Man is composed of two parts, body and soul, of which the one is corporeal, the other severed from all combination with matter.

quotation: Ex humili magna ad fastigia rerum Extollit, quoties voluit fortuna jocari.
translation: As oft as fortune is in sportive mood, she raises men from an humble station to the highest pinnacle of power.

quotation: Iis qui vendunt, emunt, conducunt, locant, justitia necessaria est.
translation: Justice is necessary for those who sell, who buy, who hire, and who let on contract.

quotation: Iliacos intra muros peccatur et extra.
translation: Sin is committed as well within the walls of Troy as without.
notes: Both sides are to blame.

quotation: Illa dolet vere quae sine teste dolet.
translation: She grieves sincerely who grieves when alone.

quotation: Ille igitur nunquam direxit brachia contra Torrentem; nec civis erat qui libera posset Verba animi proferre, et vitam impendere vero.
translation: He never exerted his arms to swim against the stream, nor was he a citizen who would freely deliver the sentiments of his mind, and lay down his life for the truth.

quotation: Illa est agricolae messis iniqua suo.
translation: That is a harvest which ill repays its husbandman.

quotation: Ex inimico cogita posse fieri amicum.
translation: Think that you may possibly make of an enemy a friend.
notes: Avoid extremes in enmities. See Amicum, &c.

quotation: Ille fidem dictis addere sola potest.
translation: It is that [the intention] alone that is able to give weight to what we say.

quotation: Ille potens sui Laetusque degit, cui licet in diem Dixisse, Vixi: cras vel atra Nube polum pater occupato Vel sole puro; non tamen irritum Quodcunque retro est efficiet.
translation: The man is master of himself, and lives happy, who has it in his power to say, 'I have lived today; tomorrow let the Omnipotent invest the heavens, either with black clouds, or with clear sunshine, still, he shall not efface what is past.'

quotation: Ex magna coena stomacho fit maxima poena, Ut sis nocte levis, sit tibi coena brevis.
translation: From a heavy supper great uneasiness to the stomach is produced; that you may enjoy a good night's rest, let your supper be moderate.
notes: A Leonine or rhyming couplet, not improbably issued by the School of Health at Salerno.

quotation: Ille sinistrorsum, hic dextrorsum, abit: unus utrique Error, sed variis illudit partibus.
translation: One digresses to the right, the other to the left; they are both equally in error, but are influenced by different delusions.

quotation: Ex malis moribus bonae leges natae sunt.
translation: From bad manners good laws have sprung.

quotation: Illa laus est, magno in genere et in divitiis maximis, Liberos hominem educare, generi monumentum et sibi.
translation: 'Tis some merit for a man of noble family and of ample wealth to bring up children, memorials of his race and himself.

quotation: Ille tenet palmam; palma petenda mihi est.
translation: He holds the palm; the palm must be sought by me.

quotation: Illa placet tellus in qua res parva beatum Me facit, et tenues luxuriantur opes.
translation: That spot has its especial delights, in which small means render me happy, and moderate wealth insures abundance.

quotation: Ille terrarum mihi praeter omnes Angulus ridet.
translation: That little spot of earth has charms for me before all others.
notes: The charms of home.

quotation: Illa victoria viam ad pacem patefecit.
translation: By that victory he opened a way to peace.

quotation: Ille vir, haud magna cum re, sed plenus fidei.
translation: He is a man, not of ample means, but full of good faith.

quotation: Homo delirus, qui verborum minutiis rerum frangit pondera.
translation: A foolish man, who fritters away the weight of his subject by fine-spun trifling on words.

quotation: Illaeso lumine solem.
translation: [To look] at the sun with sight uninjured.
notes: Eagles are said to be able to do so. This is the

quotation: Illi inter sese magna vi brachia tollunt.
translation: The workmen lift their arms in turns with mighty force.
notes: Said of the Cyclopes, working at the forges of Etna. This line, when scanned, is expressive of the sound of alternate strokes on the anvil: Illin | ter se | se mag | na vi | brachia | tollunt — by the figure Onomatopoea. See a similar instance in Quadrupedante putrem, &c.

quotation: Homo extra est corpus suum cum irascitur.
translation: A man when he is angry is beside himself.

quotation: Illi mors gravis incubat, Qui, notus nimis omnibus, Ignotus moritur sibi.
translation: Death falls heavily upon him, who, too well known to all others, dies unknown to himself.

quotation: Homo fervidus et diligens ad omnia paratur. A Kempis de Imit. Christi.
translation: The man who is earnest and diligent is prepared for all things.

quotation: Illi robur et aes triplex Circa pectus erat, qui fragilem truci Commisit pelago ratem Primus.
translation: That man must have had oak and three-fold bronze around his breast, who first intrusted a frail bark to the raging seas.

quotation: Homo homini aut deus aut lupus.
translation: Man is to man either a god or a wolf.

quotation: Illam, quicquid agit, quoquo vestigia flectit, Componit furtim, subsequiturque decor.
translation: In whatever she does, wherever she turns, grace steals into her movements, and attends her steps.
notes: So Milton: "Grace was in all her steps, heaven in her eye, In every gesture dignity and love." Par. Lost, viii.

quotation: Illiberate est mentiri; ingenuum veritas decet.
translation: It is a low thing to lie; truth alone bespeaks the man of high birth.

quotation: Homo homini deus, si officium sciat.
translation: Man to man is a god, if he knows how to do his duty.

quotation: Ille crucem sceleris pretium tulit, hic diadema.
translation: This man found the cross the reward of his crime; that one, a diadem.
notes: History shows us how some men have gained a throne by the same steps which led others to the gallows.

quotation: Illic apposito narrabis multa Lyaeo.
translation: There, with the wine on the table, you will tell many a story.

quotation: Homo homini lupus.
translation: Man to man is a wolf.
notes: One man's loss is, too often, another man's gain. "Man's inhumanity to man makes countless thousands mourn." Burns.

quotation: Ille etiam caecos instare tumultus Saepe monet, fraudesque et operta tumescere bella.
translation: He often warns too that secret revolt is impending, and that treachery and pent-up warfare are ready to burst forth.
notes: The duty of a skilful statesman.

quotation: Illic et cantant quicquid didicere theatris; Et jactant faciles ad sua verba manus.
translation: There too they sing whatever snatches they have picked up at the theatres, and move their pliant arms in tune to their words.

quotation: Homo in Hispaniam natura naturam vitium visum.
translation: A woman about to sail to Spain to see the nature of vines.
notes: A Latin puzzle; the sentence, at first, seeming to have neither grammar nor meaning.

quotation: Illotis pedibus ingredi.
translation: To enter with unwashed feet.
notes: In reference to the custom of the ancients of washing the feet before entering a sacred place, or sitting down at meals. Sometimes applied to those who talk irreverently of sacred subjects.

quotation: Homo justus nil cuipiam detrahit.
translation: A just man speaks ill of no one.

quotation: Illuc est sapere, qui ubicunque opus sit, animum possis flectere.
translation: It is true wisdom to be enabled to govern the feelings whenever there is a necessity for it.

quotation: Illud amicitiae sanctum ac venerabile nomen Nunc tibi pro vili sub pedibusque jacet?
translation: Is the sacred and venerable name of friendship now held cheap by you, and trodden under foot?

quotation: Illud maxime rarum genus est eorum, qui aut excellenti ingenii magnitudine, aut praeclara eruditione atque doctrina, aut utraque re ornati, spatium deliberandi habuerunt, quem potissimum vitae cursum sequi vellent.
translation: The number is especially small of those, who, either by extraordinary genius, or by remarkable erudition and knowledge, or by being endowed with either, have enjoyed the opportunity of deciding what mode of life, in especial, they would wish to embrace.

quotation: Imberbis juvenis tandem custode remoto Gaudet equis cunibusque, et aprici gramine campi, Cereus in vitium flecti, monitoribus asper, Utilium tardus provisor, prodigus aeris, Sublimis, cupidusque, et amata relinquere pernix.
translation: The beardless youth, his tutor at length dismissed devotes himself to horses and hounds, and the sward or the sunny Campus Martius; pliable as wax in receiving bad impressions, impatient of admonition, slow to see what is really for his good, profuse of money, high-spirited and full of eagerness, and prone to abandon tin objects of his recent affection.

quotation: Immensum gloria calcar habet.
translation: Glory affords an unbounded stimulus.

quotation: In loco.
translation: In the place
notes: meaning, "in the proper place," "upon the spot." It may also mean, "instead of."

quotation: Homo multa habet instrumenta ad adipiscendam sapientiam.
translation: Man possesses numerous means of acquiring wisdom.

quotation: Immo, duas dabo, inquit ille adolescens, una si parum est, Et si duarum poenitebit, inquit, addentur duae.
translation: 'Aye, I will give you two,' says this young man, 'if one is too little; and if you are not satisfied with two,' says he, 'two more shall be added.'

quotation: In loco parentis.
translation: In the place of a parent.

quotation: Homo multarum literarum.
translation: A man of many letters.
notes: A man of extensive learning.

quotation: Immoritur studiis, et amore senescit habendi.
translation: He is dying from his very efforts, and in his eagerness to acquire wealth is becoming an old man.

quotation: In lucro quae datur hora mihi est.
translation: The hour which is granted me, is so much gained.

quotation: Immortale odium, et nunquam sanabile vulnus.
translation: An undying hatred, and a wound that can never be healed.

quotation: In magnis et voluisse sat est.
translation: In great undertakings to have even attempted is enough.

quotation: Immortalia ne speres monet annus, et almum Quae rapit hora diem.
translation: That we are not to expect permanence in things, the year, and the hour that is hurrying past this delightful day, admonish us.

quotation: In mala uxore atque inimico si quid sumas sumptus est; In bono hospite atque amico, quaestus est, quod sumitur.
translation: If you lay anything out on a bad wife or an enemy, that is an expense; but what is laid out on a deserving guest and a friend, is so much gained.

quotation: Imperare sibi maximum imperium est.
translation: To command one's self, is to exercise the greatest command.

quotation: Imperat aut servit collecta pecunia cuique.
translation: Money amassed either serves or rules us.
notes: It becomes either a slave or a tyrant, according to the way in which it is employed.

quotation: Imperia dura tolle, quid virtus erit?
translation: Remove all harsh restraints, what will become of virtue?

quotation: In malis sperare bonum, nisi innocens, nemo potest.
translation: In adversity no one but the innocent can hope for happiness.

quotation: Imperium facile iis artibus retinetur, quibus initio partum est.
translation: Empire is most easily retained by those arts by which it was originally acquired.

quotation: In manus.
translation: A mediaeval expression, meaning, "Into your hands I commend myself,"" commendo me being understood."

quotation: Imperium flagitio acquisitum nemo unquam bonis artibus exercuit.
translation: No one ever employed sovereign power acquired by guilty measures, to promote good ends.

quotation: Homo multi consilii et optimi.
translation: A man always ready to give his advice, and that the best.

quotation: In mari aquam quaerit.
translation: He is looking for water in the sea.

quotation: Imperium in imperio.
translation: One government existing within another.
notes: Said of a power assumed or set up in opposition to constituted authority.

quotation: In mea vesanas habui dispendia vires, Et valui poenas fortis in ipse meas.
translation: To my own undoing I had the strength of a madman; and for my own punishment did I stoutly exert it.

quotation: Homo qui erranti comiter monstrat viam, Quasi lumen de suo lumine accendit, facit; Nihilomunus ipsi luceat, cum illi accenderit.
translation: He who kindly shows the way to one who has gone astray, acts as though he had lighted another's lamp by his own; although it has given light to the other, it still lights him on his way.
notes: So Shakespeare says, "The quality of mercy is twice blessed."

quotation: In medias res.
translation: Into the very midst of a thing.
notes: Applicable to a person who without prelude plunges into the very midst of the matter in hand.

quotation: Homo qui in homine calamitoso est misericors, miminit sui.
translation: A man who is merciful to the afflicted, remembers what is due to himself.
notes: He remembers his duty as a man.

quotation: In medio tutissimus ibis.
translation: You will go most safely in the middle.
notes: A middle course is the safest.

quotation: Homo sine religione, sicut equus sine fraeno.
translation: A man without religion is like a horse without a bridle.

quotation: In melle sunt sitae linguae vestrae atque orationes, Corda felle sunt lita atque aceto.
translation: Your tongues and your talk savour of honey; your hearts are steeped in gall and vinegar.

quotation: Homo solus aut deus aut daemon.
translation: A man to live alone must be either a god or a daemon.

quotation: In memoriam.
translation: In memory of.

quotation: Impetrare oportet, quia aequum postulas.
translation: You ought to have your own way, as you only ask what is fair.

quotation: Homo sum; humani nihil a me alienum puto.
translation: I am a man, and nothing that concerns a man do I deem a matter of indifference to me.
notes: St. Angustin tells us that on hearing these words of the poet, the theatre resounded with applause.

quotation: In mercatura facienda multae fallaciae et quasi praestigiae exercentur.
translation: In commerce many deceptions, and, so to say, juggleries, are currently practised.

quotation: Implacabiles plerumque laesae mulieres.
translation: Women when injured are generally implacable.

quotation: Homo toties moritur, quoties amittit suos.
translation: A man dies as many times as he loses his relatives.

quotation: In monendo sapimus omnes, verum ubi Peccamus ipsi, non videmus propria.
translation: We are all wise in giving advice, but when we ourselves commit faults, we see them not.

quotation: Impletus venter non vult studere libenter.
translation: A belly well filled is not readily inclined to study.
notes: A mediaeval line.

quotation: In nocte consilium.
translation: In the night is counsel.
notes: Act not precipitately, but take time for reflection, or, as we say, "sleep on it."

quotation: Impotentia excusat legem.
translation: Inability suspends the operation of the law.
notes: Natural infirmities disqualify a man from the performance of certain duties of a citizen; as in the case of lunatics, the blind, the dumb, &c.

quotation: In nomine Domini incipit omne malum.
translation: In the Lord's name every evil begins.
notes: A mediaeval proverb, implying that the most sacred pretences are often made an excuse for the infliction of the greatest injuries.

quotation: Imprimatur.
translation: Let it be printed.
notes: The word generally used by the licenser of the press, in countries where the press is under the control of the government.

quotation: In nova fert animus mutatas dicere formas Corpora.
translation: My design leads me to speak of forms changed into new bodies.

quotation: Improbae Crescunt divitiae, tamen Curtse nescio quid semper abest rei.
translation: Iniquitous wealth increases, yet something or other is ever wanting to our still incomplete fortune.

quotation: In nubibus.
translation: In the clouds.

quotation: Improbe amor, quid non mortalia pectora cogis?
translation: Oh, cruel love! to what dost thou not impel the human breast?

quotation: Homo trium literarum.
translation: A man of three letters.
notes: FUR, "a thief."

quotation: In nuce.
translation: In a nutshell.

quotation: Improbe Neptunum accusat, qui naufragium iterum facit.
translation: He who twice suffers shipwreck unfairly throws the blame on Neptune.
notes: Let experience teach you to avoid a danger which you have once escaped.

quotation: Homo unius libri.
translation: A man of one book.
notes: To fix one's mind intently on one book, and master it, is the only way to become truly learned, at least, according to Thomas Aquinas, as quoted by Jeremy Taylor.

quotation: In nullum avarus bonus est, in se pessimus.
translation: The avaricious man is good to no one, but most hurtful to himself.

quotation: Homunculi quanti sunt! cum recogito.
translation: What poor creatures are men! when I reflect upon it.

quotation: In nullum reipublicae usum, ambitiosa loquela inclairuit.
translation: He distinguished himself by ambitious oratory, of no advantage to the state.
notes: A good description of the career of a demagogue.

quotation: Honesta mors turpi vita potior.
translation: An honourable death is better than an ignominious life.
notes: The maxim of a martyr.

quotation: In omnia paratus.
translation: Prepared for everything.

quotation: In omnibus fere minori aetati succurritur.
translation: In nearly all respects a person under age is protected by the law.
notes: A minor can be sued ouly for money due for necessaries; for the law encourages no one to supply him with luxuries.

quotation: Improbi hominis est mendacio fallere.
translation: It is the act of a bad man to deceive by falsehood.

quotation: Honesta paupertas prior quam opes malae.
translation: Poverty with honesty is better than ill-acquired wealth.

quotation: In omnibus quidem, maxime tamen in jure, aequitas est.
translation: In all things, but in law especially, equity is an ingredient.
notes: Equity tempers the asperity of the written law, and makes it pliable according to the requirements of the case.

quotation: Improbis aliena virtus semper formidolosa est.
translation: By wicked men the virtue of others is always dreaded.
notes: They are afraid that comparisons will be made to their disadvantage.

quotation: Honesta quaedam scelera successus facit.
translation: Success makes some crimes honourable.
notes: Thus rebellion and conspiracy, though based on fraud and ingratitude, are dignified, if successful, with the name of "revolution."

quotation: In pace.
translation: In peace.
notes: The in pace was a monastic punishment in the middle ages. The offender was incarcerated or immured, the parting words addressed to him or her being Vade in pace, "Go in peace," which see.

quotation: Impunitas semper ad deteriora invitat.
translation: Impunity always invites to still worse crimes.

quotation: Honestum non est semper quod licet.
translation: That is not always honourable which is lawful.
notes: If every one scrupulously insisted on his legal rights, the world would De a scene of tenfold litigation. We must "give and take."

quotation: In pace leones, in praelio cervi.
translation: Lions in peace, deer in war.
notes: The character of braggarts.

quotation: In actu.
translation: In the very act.

quotation: Honestum quod vere dicimus, etiamsi a nullo laudatur, laudabile est sua natura.
translation: That which we truly call virtuous, even though it be praised by no one, is praiseworthy in its own nature.

quotation: In partibus.
translation: In the parts (beyond sea),
notes: transmarinis being understood. In the Roman Catholic Church, titular bishops are said to be bishops in partibus.

quotation: In aequali jure melior est conditio possidentis.
translation: Where the rights are equal the condition of him who is in possession is the best.
notes: Equivalent to "Possession is nine points of the law."

quotation: Honestus rumor alterum patrimonium est.
translation: A good name is a second inheritance.

quotation: In perpetuam rei memoriam.
translation: In everlasting remembrance of the event.
notes: A motto on a memorial of any great event.

quotation: In aere piscari; in mare venari.
translation: To fish in the air; to hunt in the sea.
notes: Said of persons attempting things for which by nature or circumstances they are utterly unfitted.

quotation: In pertusum ingerimus dicta dolium.
translation: We are casting our words into a leaky cask.
notes: We are throwing away our advice.

quotation: In amore haec omnia insunt vitia; injuriae, Suspiciones, inimicitiae, induciae, Bellum, pax rursus.
translation: In love there are all these evils; wrongs, suspicions, enmities, reconcilements, war, and then peace again.

quotation: In pios usus.
translation: For pious uses.

quotation: In pleno.
translation: In full.

quotation: In pontificalibus.
translation: In pontificals
notes: or priestly robes.

quotation: Honor est praemium virtutis.
translation: Honour is the reward of virtue.

quotation: In portu navigare.
translation: To sail into harbour.
notes: To overcome difficulties with final safety. See Inveni portum, &c.

quotation: Honora medicum propter necessitatem.
translation: Make much of a physician through necessity.

quotation: In posse.
translation: In possible being.
notes: A child unborn is in posse.

quotation: Honores mutant mores.
translation: Honours change manners.

quotation: In prece totus eram.
translation: I was wholly wrapt in prayer.

quotation: Honos alit artes.
translation: Honours nurture the arts.
notes: See Quis enim, &c.

quotation: In principatu commutando saepius Nil praeter domini nomen mutant pauperes.
translation: In a change of government, the poor mostly change nothing beyond the name of their master.

quotation: Horae cedunt, et dies, et menses, et anni, nec praeteritum tempus unquam revertitur.
translation: Hours and days, and months and years, pass away, and no time that is once past ever returns.

quotation: Horae Momento cita mors venit, aut victoria laeta.
translation: In a moment of time comes sudden death, or joyous victory.
notes: The contingencies of a soldier's life.

quotation: Horrea formicae tendunt ad inania nunquam; Nullus ad amissas ibit amicus opes.
translation: Ants never hend their course to an empty granary; no friend will visit departed wealth.
notes: Said in reference to fair-weather or sunshine friends.

quotation: In propria persona.
translation: In proper person.
notes: Personal appearance, used in contradistinction to appearance by a representative.

quotation: Horresco referens.
translation: I shudder as I tell it.

quotation: In proverbium cessit, sapientiam vino obumbrari.
translation: It has passed into a proverb, that wisdom is overshadowed by wine.

quotation: Horridus miles esse debet, non coelatus auro argentoque, sed ferro et animis fretus. Virtus est militis decus.
translation: The soldier should inspire terror, and not be adorned with gold and silver, but rely upon his courage and his sword. Valour is the soldier's virtue.

quotation: In puris naturalibus.
translation: In a state of nature.
notes: Stark naked. An expression used in a jocular sense.

quotation: In quadrum redigere.
translation: To make a matter square.
notes: To reduce to order.

quotation: In re.
translation: In the matter of.

quotation: In re mala animo si bono utare, adjuvat.
translation: In adversity, if you employ fortitude, it is of service.

quotation: In rebus dubiis plurimi est audacia.
translation: In matters of doubt, boldness is of the greatest value.

quotation: Horror ubique animos, simul ipsa silentia terrent.
translation: Horror seizes their minds, and the very silence is dreadful.

quotation: In rebus prosperis superbiam magnopere, fastidium, arrogantiamque fugiamus.
translation: In prosperity, let us especially avoid pride, disdain, and arrogance.

quotation: In referenda gratia, debemus imitari agros fertiles qui plus multo afferunt quam acceperunt.
translation: In making a return for kindness, we ought to imitate fertile lands, which give back much more than they have received.

quotation: Ex mero motu.
translation: From a mere motion;
notes: of one's own free will.

quotation: Hortus siccus.
translation: Literally, "a dry garden."""
notes: A collection of dried plants for the purpose of classification. Applied figuratively to a recital of dry and uninteresting details.

quotation: In saltu uno duos apros capere.
translation: In one cover to take two boars.
notes: Similar to our proverb, "To kill two birds with one stone."

quotation: Hos ego versiculos feci, tulit alter honores; Sic vos non vobis fertis aratra boves; Sic vos non vobis mellificatis apes; Sic vos non vobis vellera fertis oves; Sic vos non vobis nidificatis aves.
translation: I wrote these lines; another has borne away the honour — Thus do ye, oxen, for others hear the yoke; thus do ye, bees, for others make honey; thus do ye, sheep, wear fleeces for others; thus do ye, birds, for others build nests.
notes: On the occasion of some shows at Rome, the weather was remarkable for tempestuous nights, with fine days. Virgil, then a young man, and unknown, wrote these lines, and fixed them in a conspicuous place: "Nocte pluit tota, redeunt spectacula mane, Divisum imperium cum Jove Caesar habet." "It rains all night, the games return with day, Caesar with Jove thus holds divided sway." The author being inquired for, a poet of the name of Bathyllus claimed the distich, and was rewarded accordingly. Virgil, indignant at this, wrote under the verses the line "Hos ego, Ac.," and the words, "Sic vos non vobis," four times. He alone proving able to complete the lines, of which these words were the beginning, the imposture of Bathyllus was detected, and he was dismissed with disgrace, while Virgil obtained the credit which was his due."

quotation: In se magna ruunt.
translation: Great interests clash with each other.
notes: Their very extent is apt to bring them into collision.

quotation: In secundis rebus nihil in quemquam superbe ac violenter consulere decet.
translation: In prosperity it becomes us to act towards no one with pride and violence.

quotation: Hospes nullus tam in amici hospitium devorti potest, Quin ubi triduum continuum fuerit, jam odiosus siet, Verum ubi triduum continuos immorabitur, Tametsi dominus non invitus patitur, servi murmurant.
translation: No guest can be hospitably entertained by a friend, but what when he has been there three days together, he must become a bore; but when he prolongs his stay for ten successive days, even should the master willingly allow it, the servants grumble.

quotation: In seipso totus, teres, atque rotundus.
translation: A man perfect in himself, polished, and round as a globe.
notes: A description of a man wholly occupied in mastering the inequalities of his own passions.

quotation: Hospitis antiqui solitas intravimus aedes.
translation: We entered the well-known abode of an old friend.

quotation: In servitute expetunt multa iniqua; Habendum et ferendum hoc onus est cum labore.
translation: In servitude many hardships befall us; in pain this burden must be borne and endured.

quotation: Hostis est uxor invita quae ad virum nuptum datur.
translation: That wife is an enemy who is given to a man in marriage against her will.

quotation: In situ.
translation: In its site
notes: or "position."

quotation: In solo Deo salus.
translation: Salvation in God alone.
notes: Motto of the Earl of Harewood.

quotation: In Anglia non est interregnum.
translation: In England there never is an interregnum.
notes: See Rex nunquam, &c.

quotation: In annulo Dei figuram ne gestato.
notes: Wear not the image of the Deity in a ring.

quotation: In solo vivendi causa palato est.
translation: The pleasures of the palate are their only reason for living.

quotation: In studio rei amplificandae apparebat, non avaritiae praedam, sed instrumentum bonitati quaeri.
translation: In his anxiety to increase his fortune, it was evident that it was not the gratification of avarice that was sought, but the means of doing good.
notes: A compliment paid by Cicero to the virtues of Rabirius Postumus.

quotation: In aqua scribis.
translation: You are writing on water.
notes: You are wasting your labour.

quotation: In arena aedificas.
translation: You are building on sand.
notes: You are raising a fabric which cannot stand.

quotation: In summa inanitate versari.
translation: To be engaged in the very height of frivolity;
notes: or, in a vain and silly pursuit.

quotation: In beato omnia beata.
translation: With him who is fortunate everything is fortunate.

quotation: In sylvam ligna ferre.
translation: To carry wood to the forest.
notes: As we say, "To carry coals to Newcastle."

quotation: In caducum parietem inclinare.
translation: To lean against a falling wall.
notes: To rely upon a false or a feeble friend.

quotation: In te, Domine, speravi.
translation: In thee, O Lord, have I put my trust.
notes: The first line of a Psalm, and the motto of the Earl of Strathmore.

quotation: In calamitoso risus etiam injuria est.
translation: Even to smile at the unfortunate is to do an injury.

quotation: Indignor quidquam reprehendi, non quia crasse Compositum, illepidumve putetur, sed quia nuper.
translation: I am annoyed that a thing should be found fault with, not because it is a heavy composition, or inelegant, but because it is modern.

quotation: In te omnis domus inclinata recumbit.
translation: In thee are centred all the hopes of thy house.
notes: The words of Amata to her son Turnus, when about to engage in combat with Aeneas.

quotation: In capite.
translation: In chief.
notes: In the middle ages, those who held lands immediately of the king, and not of a mesne tenant, were called tenants in capite.

quotation: Indignum est in ea civitate, quae legibus continetur, discedi a legibus.
translation: In a state which is governed by laws, there ought to be no departure from them.

quotation: In tenui labor at tenuis non gloria.
translation: It is labour bestowed on a trifling subject, but not trifling is the glory.
notes: Said by Virgil in reference to the Fourth Book of his Georgics, which treats of the production and habits of bees.

quotation: In capite orphani discit chirurgus.
translation: The surgeon practises on the orphan's head.
notes: A proverb of Arabian origin.

quotation: Indocilis privata loqui.
translation: Incapable of divulging secrets.

quotation: In terrorem.
translation: In terror.
notes: By way of warning. Any power of enforcing the execution of a bond, or of inflicting punishment, or of revealing a secret, may be held in terrorem against another. The rod and fool's cap are exhibited in terrorem.

quotation: In toto.
translation: In the whole.
notes: Entirely.

quotation: Indocti discant, et ament meminisse periti.
translation: Let the ignorant learn, and the learned take pleasure in remembering.
notes: A line by Henault, often attributed to Horace.

quotation: In causa facili, cuivis licet esse diserto.
translation: In an easy cause any man may be eloquent.

quotation: Industriae nil impossibile.
translation: To industry there is nothing impossible.
notes: A Latinized saying of Periander of Corinth, one of the seven wise men of Greece.

quotation: In coelo nunquam spectatam impune cometam
translation: A comet is never beheld in the sky without disastrous results.
notes: The appearance of a comet was supposed to be indicative of some calamity to mankind.

quotation: Indutus virtute ab alto.
translation: Endued with virtue from on high.

quotation: In toto et pars continetur.
translation: In the whole the part is contained.

quotation: Inerat Vitellio simplicitas ac liberalitas, quae, nisi adsit modus, in exitium vertuntur.
translation: There was in Vitellius a frankness and liberality, which, unless tempered with moderation, must lead to ruin.
notes: Virtues in excess, unless guided by prudence, are frequently productive of ultimate evil. See Insani sapiens, &c.

quotation: In transitu.
translation: On the passage.
notes: Goods are in transitu when on their passage from the owner to the consignee, so designated to free them from duties or excise in their passage through countries where they are not to remain.

quotation: In coelo quies.
translation: In heaven there is rest.
notes: A motto very commonly used on hatchments.

quotation: Inest et formicae sua bilis.
translation: Even the ant can feel anger.
notes: The humblest of beings in the animated world is influenced by passion, though it often lacks the means of showing it. See Habet et, &c.

quotation: In tuo regno es.
translation: You are in your own kingdom
notes: You are omnipotent here, or you would not have insulted me thus.

quotation: In coelum jacularis.
translation: You are aiming your dart against the heavens.
notes: Your anger cannot injure him against whom it is directed.

quotation: Inest sua gratia parvis.
translation: Trifles have their own peculiar charms.

quotation: In turbas et discordias pessimo cuique plurima vis; pax et quies bonis artibus indigent.
translation: In times of turbulence and discord, whoever is the most abandoned has the greatest power; peace and good order stand in need of repose.

quotation: In commendam.
translation: As commended
notes: or "intrusted." A commendam implies a licence to hold a living jointly with some benefice of higher rank.

quotation: In unoquoque virorum bonorum habitat Deus.
translation: God dwells within every good man.

quotation: In contingentibus et liberis tota ratio facti stat in voluntate facientis.
translation: In contingencies and on occasions where we are free to act, the reason of our doing depends on the will of the doer.

quotation: In utero.
translation: In the womb.

quotation: In corpore.
translation: In a body.

quotation: Infandum, regina, jubes renovare dolorem.
translation: You command me, O queen, to renew an unspeakable grief.
notes: Said by Aeneas, with reference to the destruction of Troy, his native city, when requested by Dido to relate the history of its downfall.

quotation: In utramvis dormire aurem.
translation: To sleep on either ear.
notes: As we sleep most soundly when lying on the side, this proverb applies to a man who has made his fortune, and may take his ease.

quotation: In curia.
translation: In court.

quotation: Infantem nudum cum te natura creavit, Paupertatis onus patienter ferre memento.
translation: As nature created you a naked infant, remember to bear with patience the burden of poverty.

quotation: In vacuo.
translation: In a vacuum.

quotation: In dubiis benigniora semper sunt praeferenda.
translation: In cases of doubt the side of mercy should always be preferred.

quotation: Infelix Dido, nulli bene juncta marito; Hoc pereunte fugis, hoc fugiente peris.
translation: Hapless Dido, wedded under no good auspices to either husband; the one dying thou didst fly, the other flying thou didst die.
notes: Sichaeus is here alluded to as her first husband, Aeneas as the second.

quotation: In verbo.
translation: In a word.

quotation: In eadem re utilitas et turpitudo esse non potest.
translation: In the same thing turpitude and advantage cannot coexist.

quotation: Infinita est velocitas temporis, quae magis apparet respicientibus.
translation: The swiftness of time is infinite, as is still more evident when we look back on the past.

quotation: In vino veritas.
translation: In wine there is truth.
notes: Reserve is laid aside when a person is under the influence of wine. See Quod in, &c.

quotation: Infra dignitatem.
translation: Below his dignity.
notes: In cant parlance called Infra dig.

quotation: Ex necessitate rei.
translation: From the urgency of the case.

quotation: Infra tuam pelliculam te contine.
translation: Content yourself with your own skin.
notes: Live as becomes your circumstances. Said to the ass who was found wearing a lion's skin, and got cudgelled to death.

quotation: In eburna vagina plumbeus gladius.
translation: A leaden sword in an ivory sheath.
notes: Said by Diogenes of a shallow, showy fop.

quotation: Ingeminant curae, rursusque resurgens Saevit amor, magnoque irarum fluctuat aestu.
translation: Her cares redouble, and love, again arising, rages in her breast, and swells with a vast tide of passion.

quotation: Ingenio facies conciliante placet.
translation: When the disposition charms, the features are pleasing.

quotation: Ingenio stat sine morte decus.
translation: The honours of genius are immortal.
notes: See Exegi monumentum, &c, and Jamque opus, &c.

quotation: In equilibrio.
translation: In equilibrium.

quotation: Ingeniorum cos aemulatio.
translation: Emulation is the whetstone of genius.

quotation: In esse.
translation: In actual being.
notes: That which exists.

quotation: Ingenium cui sit, cui mens divinior, atque os Magna sonaturum, des nominis hujus honorem.
translation: To him who possesses genius, a soul of diviner cast, and greatness of expression, to him give the honour of the name of poet.

quotation: In exornando se, multum temporis insumunt mulieres.
translation: Females spend too much time in bedecking themselves.

quotation: Ingenium ingens Inculto latet hoc sub corpore.
translation: A great intellect lies concealed beneath that uncouth exterior.

quotation: In extenso.
translation: In full
notes: or "at large." Without abridgment. Used in reference to written documents.

quotation: Ingenium mala saepe movent.
translation: Misfortunes often sharpen the genius.

quotation: In flagranti delicto.
translation: In glaring delinquency.
notes: In the very commission of the act.

quotation: Ingenium res Adversae nudare solent, celare secundae.
translation: Adversity is wont to reveal genius, prosperity to conceal it.

quotation: In flammam flammas, in mare fundis aquas.
translation: You heap flames upon flames, and pour water into the sea.

quotation: Ingens telum necessitas.
translation: Necessity is a powerful weapon.

quotation: In flammam ne manum injicito.
translation: Thrust not your hand into the fire.

quotation: Ingentem foribus domus alta superbis Mane salutantum totis vomit aedibus undam.
translation: The lofty palace, with its gorgeous portals, pours forth from every part whole torrents of courtiers, who have been paying their morning homage.

quotation: In foribus scribat, occupatum se esse.
translation: Let him write upon the door that he is busy.

quotation: Ingentes animos angusto in corpore versant.
translation: In diminutive bodies they display mighty souls.
notes: Said by Virgil of the bees, but applicable to men, like Alexander the Great, and Buonaparte, small in person, but great in spirit.

quotation: In forma pauperis.
translation: In the form of a poor man.
notes: Where any person has just cause of suit, but is so poor that he is not worth five pounds when all his debts are paid, the court, on oath made to that effect, and a certificate from counsel that he has good ground of action, will admit him to sue in forma pauperis, without paying any fees to counsel, attorney, or the court.

quotation: Ingentes dominos, et clarae nomina famae, Illustrique graves nobilitate domos Devita, et longe cautus fuge; contrahe vela, Et te littoribus cymba propinqua vehat.
translation: Shun mighty lords, and names illustrious in fame, and houses ennobled by exalted rank, and, ever on your guard, fly from them afar; take in your sails, and let your bark hug the shore as it bears you along.

quotation: Ingenuas didicisse fideliter artes Emollit mores, nec sinit esse feros.
translation: To have thoroughly learned the liberal arts refines the manners, and permits them not to be unpolished.

quotation: In foro conscientiae.
translation: At the tribunal of conscience.
notes: According to the test supplied by our own conscience.

quotation: Ingrato homine terra pejus nil creat.
translation: The earth produces nothing worse than an ungrateful man.

quotation: Ingratum est beneficium quod diu inter manus dantis haesit; at bis gratum est, quod ultro affertur.
translation: The favour that has been long delayed in the hands of the giver loses its value; but that is doubly grateful, which is offered voluntarily.
notes: See Bis dat, &c, and Inopi beneficium, &c.

quotation: Ingratum si dixeris, omnia dicis.
translation: If you say he is ungrateful, you say everything.
notes: The ungrateful man is capable of any criminality.

quotation: In fuga foeda mors est, in victoria gloriosa.
translation: Death is shameful in flight, glorious in victory.

quotation: Ingratus est qui remotis testibus agit gratiam.
translation: He is an ungrateful man who acknowledges his obligation when all witnesses are removed.
notes: A truly grateful man does not content himself with secret thanks for benefits conferred.

quotation: In furias ignemque ruunt; amor omnibus idem.
translation: They rush into fire and fury, love is the same in all.

quotation: Ingratus unus miseris omnibus nocet.
translation: One ungrateful man does an injury to all who are in distress.
notes: Many wretched but deserving persons go unrelieved, in consequence of the ingratitude of others.

quotation: In futuro.
translation: In future.
notes: At a future time.

quotation: Ingrediturque solo, et caput inter nubila condit.
translation: She roves over the earth, while her head is hid among the clouds.
notes: A description of scandal.

quotation: In hoc signo vinces.
translation: By this sign shalt thou conquer.
notes: This motto was adopted by the emperor Constantino, after his assertion that he had beheld a cross in the heavens, the fancied precursor of victory. It is the motto of the Earl of Arran, and other persons of rank.

quotation: Inimici famam non ita ut nata est ferunt.
translation: Enemies carry about reports not in the form in which they have originated.

quotation: In hora saepe ducentos, Ut magnum, versus dictabat, stans pede in uno.
translation: He would often, as a great feat, dictate two hundred

quotation: Inimicus et invidus vicinorum oculus.
translation: An enemy and an envious man is an eye over his neighbours.

quotation: In hunc scopulum cadaverosi senes ut plurimum impingunt.
translation: Old men on the verge of the grave are mostly wrecked upon this rock
notes: — that of avarice.

quotation: Iniqua nunquam regna perpetua manent.
translation: Rule unjustly gained is never of long duration.

quotation: In illo viro, tantum robur corporis et animi fuit, ut quocunque loco natus esset, fortunam sibi facturus videretur.
translation: In that man there was such great strength of body and mind, that in whatever station he had been born it seemed as though he was sure of making his fortune.
notes: Character of the elder Cato, as quoted by Lord Bacon.

quotation: Iniquissimam pacem justissimo bello antefero.
translation: I prefer the most unjust peace to the most just war.

quotation: In judicando criminosa est celeritas.
translation: In giving judgment haste is criminal.

quotation: Iniquum est aliquem rei sui esse judicem.
translation: It is unfair that any one should be judge in his own cause.

quotation: In vitium ducit culpae fuga.
translation: In flying from one vice, we are led into another.

quotation: Initia magistratuum nostrorum meliora et firma finis inclinat.
translation: The commencement of our official duties is characterized by greater vigour and alacrity, but towards the end they flag.
notes: Too often the case in new undertakings.

quotation: In vitium libertas excidit, et vim Dignam lege regi.
translation: Freedom degenerated into excess and violence that required to be regulated by law.

quotation: Injuria injuriam cohibere licet.
translation: We may escape an injury by the infliction of another.
notes: According to the law of nations, not of Christianity.

quotation: In limine.
translation: At the threshold.
notes: Preliminary.

quotation: Injuriae spretae exolescunt, si irascaris agnitae videntur.
translation: Injuries unnoticed lose their effect; if you are angry, they are seen to be acknowledged.
notes: You thereby afford a triumph to him who gave the affront.

quotation: Injuriam qui facturus est jam facit.
translation: He who is about to commit an injury, has committed it already.
notes: Whoso hateth his brother, is a murderer: and ye know that no murderer hath eternal life abiding in him." 1 John iii. 15. See also Matt. v. 28.

quotation: Injuriarum remedium est oblivio.
translation: Oblivion is the best remedy for injuries.

quotation: In vultu signa dolentis erant.
translation: On her features there were signs of grief.

quotation: Injusta ab justis impetrari non decet; Justa autem ab injustis, petere, insipientia est.
translation: From the reasonable to ask what is unreasonable is not right; from the unreasonable to ask what is reasonable is sheer folly.

quotation: Inanem inter magnates versandi gloriam pertinacissime sectari.
translation: Inveterately to hanker after the glory of associating with the great.

quotation: Innatat unda freto dulcis, leviorque marina est, Quae proprium mixto de sale pondus habet.
translation: Fresh water swims on the surface of the deep, and is lighter than that of the sea, which derives its peculiar weight from the admixture of salt.

quotation: Inanis torrens verborum.
translation: An empty torrent of words.

quotation: Inter sylvas Academi quaerere verum.
translation: Amid the woods of Academus to seek for truth.
notes: A spot near Athens where Plato lectured, and the philosophers met for discussion.

quotation: Incedimus per ignes Suppositos cineri doloso.
translation: We are walking over fires that lie concealed beneath deceitful ashes.
notes: Our prospect of success appears encouraging, but we may encounter unforeseen disasters.

quotation: Inter utrumque tene.
translation: Keep a mid course between the two extremes.
notes: See In medio, &c.

quotation: Incendit omnem feminae zelus domum.
translation: A jealous woman sets a whole house in a flame.

quotation: Innuendo.
translation: By making signs
notes: or, "By nodding at." A covert hint or intimation is so called.

quotation: Incenditque animum famae venientis amore.
translation: And fires his soul with the love of coming fame.

quotation: Inter vivos.
translation: Between or among the living.

quotation: Inopem me copia fecit.
translation: Plenty has made me poor.
notes: Narcissus says this, on finding that self-love has deprived him of a valuable treasure, the love of others. It may be applied to a writer, or speaker, whose expression is embarrassed by the copiousness of his thoughts.

quotation: Incerta haec si tu postules Ratione certa facere, nihilo plus agas, Quam si des operam ut cum ratione insanias.
translation: If you expect to render these uncertain things certain by dint of reason, you will no more effect it than if you were to endeavour to be mad with reason.

quotation: Interdictum est ne bonus cum malefico usum ullius rei consocietur.
translation: It is forbidden a good man to hold any intercourse with an evil-doer.

quotation: Inopi beneficium bis dat, qui dat celeriter.
translation: He confers a two-fold benefit on the needy man who confers it speedily.
notes: See Bis dat, &c, and Ingratum est, &c.

quotation: Incerti sunt exitus belli.
translation: The results of war are uncertain.

quotation: Interdum lacrymae pondera vocis habent.
translation: Sometimes tears have the weight of words.

quotation: Inops, potentem dum vult imitari, perit.
translation: The needy man, while affecting to imitate the powerful, comes to ruin.
notes: Witness the Fable of the Frog and the Ox.

quotation: Interdum stultus bene loquitur.
translation: Sometimes a fool speaks to the purpose.
notes: We may learn something of even a fool.

quotation: Inquinat egregios adjuncta superbia mores.
translation: If pride accompanies, it is a blemish to the best of manners.

quotation: Interdum vitia prosunt hominibus, Sed tempore ipso tamen apparet veritas.
translation: Vices are sometimes profitable to men, but still, in time, the truth transpires.

quotation: Incertum est quo te loco mors expectet; itaque in omni loco illam expecta.
translation: It is uncertain in what place death awaits you; await it therefore in every place.
notes: Live this day as if the last.

quotation: Insani sapiens nomen ferat, aequus iniqui, Ultra quod satis est virtutem si petat ipsam.
translation: Let the wise man bear the name of fool, the just of unjust, if he pursues even virtue herself beyond the proper bounds.
notes: See Inerat Vitellio, &c.

quotation: Interdum vulgus rectum videt, est ubi peccat.
translation: Sometimes the populace sees things aright; at other times it errs.

quotation: Interea dulces pendent circum oscula nati; Casta pudicitiam servat domus.
translation: Meantime his sweet children hang about his lips, and his chaste abode is the dwelling of virtue.
notes: See At jam, &c., and the corresponding lines in Gray's Elegy, Stanza vi.

quotation: Incessu patuit Dea.
translation: She stood revealed a goddess in her gait.

quotation: Insanientis dum sapientiae Consultus erro.
translation: See Parcus Deorum, &c.

quotation: Incidit in Scyllam cupiens vitare Charybdim.
translation: He falls into Scylla in endeavouring to escape Charybdis.
notes: Philip Gualtier de Lille, a poet of the 13th century. These were two whirlpools on the coast of Sicily, of which Scylla was the most dangerous. They caused the destruction of a part of the fleet of Ulysses. It is sometimes quoted "Qui vult vitare, &c." See Quo tendis, &c.

quotation: Insanire parat certa ratione modoque.
translation: He is preparing to show his madness with a certain degree of reason and method.
notes: There is "method in his madness."

quotation: Interea gustus elementa per omnia quaerunt, Nunquam animo pretiis obstantibus; interius si Attendas, magis illa juvant, quae pluris emuntur.
translation: Meantime they search for delicacies throughout all the elements, with minds regardless of expense; watch them narrowly, and you will see that those things please most which cost the highest price.

quotation: Incipere multo est, quam impetrare, facilius.
translation: It is much more easy to begin a thing than to complete it.

quotation: Insanire putas solennia me, neque rides.
translation: You think me mad like everyone else, and you do not laugh.

quotation: Intererit multum Davusne loquatur an heros.
translation: It is of considerable consequence whether (the servant) Davus is speaking, or a hero.
notes: The poet here warns dramatic writers to make their characters speak in language appropriate to their station in life.

quotation: Incitamentum amoris musica.
translation: Music is an incitement to love.

quotation: Interest reipublicae ut quisque re sua bene utatur.
translation: It is of importance to the state that every one should make a good use of his property.

quotation: Inclusio unius est exclusio alterius.
translation: The inclusion of the one implies the exclusion of the other.

quotation: Interpone tuis interdum gaudia curis.
translation: Season your cares with joys sometimes.

quotation: Incoctum generoso pectus honesto.
translation: A breast imbued with generous honour.

quotation: Intolerabilius nihil est quam foemina dives.
translation: Nothing is more unbearable than a woman with a full purse.

quotation: Insanus medio flumine quaeris aquam.
translation: You madly search for water, in the middle of a stream.
notes: Said of one who searches for what is wrong where there is nothing good to be found.

quotation: Incudi reddere.
translation: To return to the anvil.
notes: To reconsider a work, or return our performances to the anvil, to repair or repolish them.

quotation: Intonuere poli et crebris micat ignibus aether.
translation: The heavens thunder and the sky flashes with vivid lightnings.

quotation: Insanus omnis furere credit caeteros.
translation: Every madman believes that all others are mad.

quotation: Incultis asperisque regionibus diutius nives haerent, ast domita tellure dilabuntur; similiter in pectoribus ira considit; feras quidem mentes obsidet, eruditas praelabitur.
translation: In rugged and uncultivated regions the snow lies longer upon the ground, but on cultivated soil it soon disappears; in a similar manner anger affects our breasts; in those which are uncultivated it remains, but in those which are cultivated it quickly subsides.

quotation: Insequitur cumulo praeruptus aquae mons.
translation: A steep mountain of waters follows with its towering height.

quotation: Intra Fortunam debet quisque manere suam.
translation: Every one is bound to live within his means.
notes: See Crede mihi, &c.

quotation: Intus et in cute novi.
translation: I know thee inside and out.
notes: See Ad populum, &c.

quotation: Insipientis est dicere, Non putarem.
translation: It is the part of a fool to say, 'I should not have thought so.'

quotation: Insita hominibus natura violentiae resistere.
translation: It is by nature implanted in man to resist oppression.

quotation: Incurvat genu senectus.
translation: Old age bends the knee.

quotation: Insperata accidunt magis saepe quam quae speres.
translation: Things not hoped for happen more frequently than things which you do hope for.

quotation: Inspicere, tanquam in speculum, in vitas omnium Jubeo, atque ex aliis sumere exemplum sibi.
translation: I advise you to look into the lives of men, as though into a mirror, and from others to take an example for yourself.

quotation: Intus et in jecore aegro Nascuntur domini.
translation: In our own breasts, and from a morbid liver, our masters spring up.
notes: Our passions, if they are not our servants, will become our masters.

quotation: Inde datae leges ne fortior omnia posset.
translation: Laws were given that the strongest might not have it all his own way.

quotation: Intuta quae indecora.
translation: Those things which are unbecoming are unsafe.

quotation: Inde irae.
translation: Hence this resentment.

quotation: Invendibili merci oportet ultro emptorem abducere, Proba merx facile emptorem reperit, tametsi in abstruso sit.
translation: To unsaleable wares it is necessary to try to entice the buyer; good wares easily meet with a purchaser, although they may be hid in a corner.

quotation: Integer vitae scelerisque purus Non eget Mauri jaculis neque arcu.
translation: The man whose life is unblemished, and unstained by crime, needs not the javelins nor bow of the Moor.
notes: Such a man may be wounded in body, but will remain unscathed in soul.

quotation: Index expurgatorius.
translation: An "Index expurgatory"
notes: or "purifying index." A list of books denounced by the pope as improper to be read by members of the Romish Church. Since it was originally compiled this Index has been frequently modified according to circumstances.

quotation: Inveni portum, Spes et Fortuna valete; Sat me lusistis, ludite nunc alios.
translation: I've reach'd the harbour, Hope and Chance, adieu! You've play'd with me, now play with others too.
notes: Lines at the end of Le Sage's Gil Bias. Translated from the Anthologia Graeca. See Jam portum, &c. Burton ascribes this version, with some variations, to Prudentius.

quotation: Integra mens augustissima possessio.
translation: A mind unblemished is the noblest possession.

quotation: Indicium sit.
translation: Let it be unsaid.
notes: Said by way of apology.

quotation: Invenies vestri praeconia nominis illic; Invenies animi pignora multa mei.
translation: There wilt thou find the commendations of thy name; there wilt thou find full many a pledge of my esteem.

quotation: Indigna digna habenda sunt quae haeres facit.
translation: Unworthy acts must be looked upon as worthy if done by your master.
notes: See Ita servum, &c.

quotation: Inventas aut qui vitam excoluere per artes, Quique sui memores alios fecere merendo.
translation: Men who have improved life by their discoveries in art, and who have insured remembrance by their good deserts.

quotation: Intentio inservire debet legibus, non leges intentioni.
translation: The intention ought to obey the laws, not the laws the intention.
notes: The laws ought not to be wrested from their original meaning, to suit the purposes of any one.

quotation: Indigne vivit per quem non vivit alter.
translation: He by whom no one else lives, does not deserve to live.

quotation: Invidia Siculi non invenere tyranni Tormentum majus.
translation: Sicilian tyrants invented nothing that is a greater torment than envy.
notes: He alludes to the brazen bull of Perillus, made for the Sicilian tyrant Phalaris, in which his victims were roasted to death. This, as well as the cave of Dionysius of Syracuse, were productive of slight tortures compared with those produced by envy.

quotation: Inter alia.
translation: Among other things.

quotation: Invidiam ferre aut fortis aut felix potest.
translation: The brave or the fortunate are able to endure envy.

quotation: Inter amicos omnium rerum communitas.
translation: Among friends all property is common.

quotation: Invidiam placare paras, virtute relicta?
translation: Do you think of appeasing envy by forsaking virtue?

quotation: Inter arma leges silent.
translation: In the midst of arms the laws are silent.
notes: Martial law then takes the place of civic sway.

quotation: Invidus alterius macrescit rebus opimis.
translation: The envious man grows lean on seeing the prosperity of another.
notes: A description of the cankering effects of envy.

quotation: Inter cuncta leges, et percontabere doctos, Qua ratione queas traducere leniter aevum.
translation: Under every circumstance you must read and consult the learned how you may be enabled to pass your life in quiet.

quotation: Invidus, iracundus, iners, vinosus, amator, Nemo adeo ferus est, ut non mitescere possit, Si modo culturae patientem commodet aurem.
translation: The envious, the choleric, the indolent, the slave to wine, to women — none is so savage that he cannot be tamed, if he will only lend a patient ear to discipline.

quotation: Inter delicias semper aliquid saevi nos strangulat.
translation: Amid our enjoyments there is always some vexation to torment us.
notes: See Medio de fonte, &c.

quotation: Invisa nunquam imperia retinentur diu.
translation: A sway that has incurred hatred is never held long.

quotation: Invisa potentia, atque miseranda vita eorum, qui se metui quam amari malunt.
translation: The power is detested, and the existence wretched, of those who would rather be feared than loved.

quotation: Inter finitimos vetus atque antiqua simultas, Immortale odium et nunquam sanabile vulnus Ardet adhuc – Inde furor vulgo, quod numina vicinorum Odit uterque locus, cum solos credit habendos Esse deos, quos ipse colit.
translation: An ancient and inveterate enmity between neighbours, an everlasting hatred, and an ever-rankling wound, still galls them both. Hence has sprung universal rancour, because each community hates the worship of its neighbour, as it believes that those gods only which itself holds sacred ought to be esteemed as such.

quotation: Inviso semel principe seu bene, seu male, gesta premunt.
translation: A ruler ouce detested, his deeds, whether good or bad, lead to his downfall.
notes: Somewhat similar to our proverb — "Give a dog a bad name and hang him."

quotation: Invita Minerva.
translation: Minerva being unwilling.
notes: Minerva being the goddess of wisdom, it was supposed that she was the bestower of that invaluable attribute. If a work appeared to be destitute of wisdom, or genius, it was said to have been composed invita Minerva, "against the will of Minerva."

quotation: Invitat culpam qui peccatum praeterit.
translation: He who passes a crime unpunished, encourages sin.

quotation: Invitum qui servat idem facit occidenti.
translation: He who saves a man's life against his will does just the same as if he murdered him.
notes: His benevolence is as little estimated as if he were his most bitter enemy.

quotation: Involvere diem nimbi et nox humida coelum Abstulit.
translation: Clouds enwrapped the day, and humid night withdrew the heavens from our view.

quotation: Ipsa haeret scopulis, et quantum vertice ad auras Aetherias, tantum radice in Tartara tendit.
translation: [The tree] itself cleaves fast to the rocks, and as high as it shoots upwards into the aethereal regions, so deep does it descend with its roots to Tartarus below.

quotation: Ipsae rursum concedite sylvae.
translation: And you, ye woods, once more farewell!

quotation: Ipse dies agitat festos; fususque per herbam, Ignis ubi in medio, et socii cratera coronant, Te libans, Lenaee, vocat.
translation: The swain himself keeps holiday; and stretched on the grass, where there is a fire in the middle, and where his companions crown the bowl, he invokes thee, Lenaeus, as he makes the libation.

quotation: Ipse dixit.
translation: He himself said it.
notes: He said it on his ipse dixit. A mere saying or assertion without proof.

quotation: Ipse Jupiter, neque pluens omnibus placet, neque abstinens.
translation: Not even Jupiter himself can please all, whether he sends rain or whether he leaves off.

quotation: Ipse pavet; nee qua commissas flectat habenas, Nec scit qua sit iter; nec si sciat imperet illis.
translation: He becomes alarmed, nor knows which way to turn the reins intrusted to him, nor does he know the way; nor if he did know, could he control the steeds.
notes: Persons who undertake what they cannot accomplish are in the predicament of Phaeton, when he attempted to guide the horses of the Sun.

quotation: Ipse semet canit.
translation: He sings about himself.
notes: In our phrase, "He is his own trumpeter."

quotation: Ipsi laetitia voces ad sidera jactant Intonsi montes; ipsae jam carmina rupes, Ipsa sonant arbusta.
translation: The unshorn mountains themselves send forth their voices to the stars; even the rocks utter their song, the very shrubs resound.

quotation: Ipsisstma verba.
translation: The very identical words.

quotation: Ipso facto.
translation: In fact itself.
notes: Absolutely," or "actually."

quotation: Ipso jure.
translation: By the law itself.

quotation: Ira furor brevis est.
translation: Anger is a short madness.

quotation: Ira quae tegitur nocet; Professa perdunt odia vindictae locum.
translation: Resentment which is concealed is baneful; hatred avowed loses the opportunity of revenge.
notes: The object of the resentment is put upon his guard.

quotation: Iracundiam qui vincit, hostem superat maximum.
translation: He who overcomes his anger, subdues his greatest enemy.

quotation: Irarum tantos volvis sub pectore fluctus?
translation: Do you harbour such torrents of anger in your breast?

quotation: Iras et verba locant.
translation: They let out for hire their anger and their words.
notes: A satirical view of the duties of a pleader.

quotation: Iratus cum ad se redit, sibi tum irascitur.
translation: An angry man, when he returns to himself, is angry with himself.
notes: He is overwhelmed with self-reproach.

quotation: Ire tamen restat, Numa quo devenit et Ancus.
translation: It still remains for you to go where Ancus and Numa have gone before.

quotation: Irrepit in hominum mentes dissimulatio.
translation: Dissimulation creeps apace into the minds of men.

quotation: Irrigat ros herbam virentem, et calor solaris tepefacit.
translation: The dew waters the growing grass, and the sun's heat warms it.

quotation: Irritabis crabrones.
translation: You will irritate the hornets.
notes: Or, as we say, You will bring a hornet's nest about your ears.

quotation: Is cadet ante senem qui sapit ante diem.
translation: He dies before he is old, who is wise before his day.
notes: See Cito maturum. &c.

quotation: Inter indoctos etiam corydus sonat.
translation: To the unskilled the voice of the sparrow is music.
notes: A dunce even may impose on the illiterate. The corydus was a lark with an inferior note, found in the neighbourhood of Athens.

quotation: Ita servum par videtur frugi se instituere; Proinde heri ut sint, ipse item sit, vultum e vultu comparet;
translation: Thus does it seem becoming for a trusty servant to conduct himself; just as his superiors are should he be too; by their countenance he should fashion his own countenance; if his superiors are grave, let him be grave; if they rejoice, let him be merry.
notes: See Indigna digna, &c.

quotation: Is est honos homini pudico, meminisse officium suum.
translation: To be mindful of his duty is true honour to an upright man.

quotation: Inter malleum et incudem.
translation: Between the hammer and the anvil.
notes: Said of a person between the horns of a dilemma.

quotation: Is habitus animorum fuit, ut pessimum facinus auderent pauci, plures vellent, omnes paterentur.
translation: Such was the state of feeling, that a few dared to perpetrate the worst of crimes, more wished to do so, all suffered it.

quotation: Ita vertere seria ludo.
translation: Thus to turn serious matters into jest.

quotation: Inter nos.
translation: Between ourselves.
notes: Not to let it go any further.

quotation: Is maxime divitiis utitur, qui minime divitiis indiget.
translation: He uses riches to the best purpose, who stands the least in need of riches.

quotation: Is mihi demum vivere et frui anima videtur, qui aliquo negotie intentus, praeclari facinoris aut artis bonae famam quaerit.
translation: That man in fine appears to me to live and to enjoy life, who, being engaged in any business, seeks the reputation attendant upon some illustrious deed, or upon the discovery of some useful art.

quotation: Ita vita est hominum, quasi, cum ludas tesseris; Si illud quod maxime opus est jactu non cadit, lllud quod cecidit forte id arte ut corrigas.
translation: The life of man is just like playing with dice; if that which you most want to throw does not turn up, that which turns up by chance you must correct by skill.

quotation: Inter pueros senex.
translation: An old man among boys.
notes: Said of a person who by his gravity of manners affects to be wiser than he really is.

quotation: Ita voluerunt, ita factum est.
translation: So they willed it, and so it has been done.

quotation: Is mihi videtur amplissimus qui sua virtute in altiorem locum pervenit.
translation: He is, in my opinion, the greatest man, who has by his own virtues raised himself to a higher station.

quotation: Inter quadrupedes gloria prima lepus.
translation: Of quadrupeds the chief glory is the hare.
notes: The Roman gourmands seemed to esteem this animal higher than we do; for we find Horace saying, Faecundi leporis sapiens sectabitur armos. — "A man of taste will look out for the shoulders of a pregnant hare."

quotation: Iter factum corruptius imbre.
translation: The way being rendered more disagreeable by the rain.

quotation: Is minimo eget mortalis, qui minimum cupit.
translation: He of all mortals is the least in want, who desires the least.

quotation: Inter spem curamque, timores inter et iras, Omnem crede diem tibi diluxisse supremum: Grata superveniet quae non sperabitur hora.
translation: In the midst of hope and care, in the midst of fears and disquietudes, think every day that dawns upon you to be your last; the hour which shall not be expected will come upon you as a grateful boon.

quotation: Iter pigrorum quasi sepes spinarum.
translation: The way of the slothful is as a hedge of thorns.

quotation: Is ordo vitio careto, caeteris specimen esto.
translation: Let this order be free from vice, and an ensample to the others.
notes: This injunction was contained in the Twelve Tables at Rome, and was addressed to the Senatorial or Patrician order. The highest in rank should be most careful to set a good example.

quotation: Inter strepit anser olores.
translation: A goose he gabbles among the swans.

quotation: Iterum ille eam rem judicatam judicat Majoreque mulcta mulctat.
translation: He is trying a matter again that has been tried already, and is mulcting us again with a still heavier fine.

quotation: Ixion quod versari narratur rota Volubilem fortunam jactari docet.
translation: The story of Ixion whirling round upon the wheel, teaches us how changeful a thing is fortune.

quotation: Jacet ecce Tibullus, Vix manet e toto parva quod urna capit.
translation: See, here Tibullus lies; of one so great there hardly remains enough to fill a little urn.

quotation: Is sapiens qui se ad casus accommodet omnes; Stultus in adversis ire natator aquis.
translation: He is the wise man who can accommodate himself to all contingencies; the fool struggles, like a swimmer, to go against the stream.
notes: This is not the motto of the Justus et tenax propositi vir, but it is the one usually adopted by

quotation: Jacta est alea.
translation: The die is cast.
notes: The deed is done, and there is now no room for deliberation.

quotation: Istam Oro, (si quis adhuc precibus locus) exue mentem.
translation: I beseech you (if my entreaties can still have any effect) lay aside that intention.

quotation: Jactitatio.
translation: A boasting.
notes: Jactitation of marriage is a false boasting of a person that he, or she, is married to another, such not being the case. On a libel brought against the party guilty of jactitation, the ecclesiastical courts will impose silence on him or her.

quotation: Ista decens facies longis vitiabitur annis; Rugaque in antiqua fronte senilis erit.
translation: That beauteous face will be spoiled by length of years, and the wrinkle of age will be on thy antiquated brow.

quotation: Isthuc est sapere, non quod ante pedes modo est Videre, sed etiam illa quae futura sunt Prospicere.
translation: That is wisdom indeed, not to look at the present moment, but to look forward to what is to come.

quotation: Jam desuetudine longa Vix subeunt ipsi verba Latina mihi.
translation: From long disuse scarcely do Latin modes of expression recur to me.
notes: The complaint of Ovid, when in exile at Tomi in Pontus.

quotation: Ita comparatam esse hominum naturam omnium, Aliena ut melius videant et dijudicent, Quam sua!
translation: That the nature of men should be so constituted, that they can see and judge of other men's affairs better than their own!

quotation: Jam istaec insipientia est, Sic viam in promptu gerere.
translation: Why, this is sheer folly, thus to keep your wrath always bottled up in readiness.

quotation: Jam nunc minaci murmure cornuum Perstringis aures; jam litui strepunt.
translation: Even now you stun our ears with the threatening murmur of horns; now the clarions sound.
