quotation: Jam pauca aratro jugera regiae Moles relinquent.
translation: Princely palaces will soon leave but few acres to the plough.
notes: The allusion is to the vast tracts of land enclosed by the rich for purposes of ornament, and no longer available for the public benefit.

quotation: Justum et tenacem propositi virum, Non civium ardor prava jubentium, Non vultus instantis tyranni Mente quatit solida.
translation: Not the rage of the people pressing to hurtful measures, not the aspect of the threatening tyrant, can shake from his settled purpose the man who is just and determined in his resolution.

quotation: Jam portum inveni, Spes et Fortuna valete! Nil mihi vobiscum est, ludite nunc alios.
translation: I have now gained the harbour, Hope and Fortune, adieu! I have nothing to do with you, now go play with others.
notes: A translation by Sir Thomas More of an Epigram in the Greek Anthology. See Inveni portum, &c.

quotation: Ita dis est placitum, voluptatem ut moeror comes consequatur.
translation: It has so pleased the gods that Sorrow should attend as companion on Pleasure.

quotation: Juvenile vitium regere non posse impetum.
translation: It is the failing of youth, not to be able to restrain its own impetuosity.

quotation: Ita finitima sunt falsa veris, ut in praecipitem locum non debeat se sapiens committere.
translation: Falsehood borders so closely upon truth, that a wise man should not trust himself too near the precipice.
notes: A rebuke against quibbling.

quotation: Jam proterva Fronte petit Lalage maritum.
translation: Already, with unblushing face, does Lalage seek a husband.

quotation: Ita lex scripta est.
translation: To such effect is the law written.
notes: The words of a man who argues tersely, and by the letter.

quotation: Jam redit et Virgo, redeunt Saturnia regna.
translation: Now the Virgin returns, now the Saturnian age returns.
notes: The supposed reign of Astraea, the goddess of justice, in tne Golden Age.

quotation: Juxta fluvium puteum fodit.
translation: He is digging a well close by a river.
notes: Said of a person adding to a supply which is already more than sufficient.

quotation: Ita me Dii ament! ubi sim nescio.
translation: May the gods so love me, I know not where I am.
notes: I am bewildered, quite beside myself.

quotation: Kyrie eleeison.
translation: Lord, have mercy upon us.
notes: Two Latinized Greek words in common use in the responses of the Romish Church.

quotation: Jam saevus apertam In rabiem coepit verti jocus, et per honestas Ire minax impune domos.
translation: At length the bitter raillery began to be turned into open rage, and menaces with impunity to stalk through reputable houses.

quotation: Ita nobilissima Graeciae civitas, quondam vero etiam doctissma sui civis unius acutissimi monumentum ignorasset, nisi ab homine Arpinate didicisset.
translation: So the most noble city of Greece, once too the most distinguished for learning, would have remained in ignorance of the monument of her most talented citizen, had it not learned from a man of Arpinum
notes: (now Abruzzo). Cicero speaks of the city of Syracuse; he himself having found there the tomb of Archimedes, covered with weeds, and abandoned to oblivion.

quotation: LL. D.
translation: Doctor of Laws.
notes: For "Legum Doctor".

quotation: Jam satis — ohe.
translation: Hold — enough!

quotation: Jam summa procul villarum culmina fumant.
translation: Now the high tops of the villages afar send forth their smoke.

quotation: L. S.
notes: For "Locus sigilli", which see.

quotation: Jamque opus exegi, quod nec Jovis ira, nec ignis, Nec poterit ferrum, nec edax abolere vetustas.
translation: I have now completed a work which neither the anger of Jove, nor fire, nor the sword, nor consuming time, will he able to destroy.
notes: A prediction of the poet, which, thus far, has been verified, and deservedly so.

quotation: Labitur et labetur in omne volubilis aevum.
notes: See Rusticus expectat, &c.

quotation: Jamque quiescebant voces hominumque canumque; Lunaque nocturnos alta regebat equos.
translation: And now the voices of men and the baying of dogs were lulled, and the moon or high was guiding the steeds of night.

quotation: Ita oportuit intrare in gloriam suam.
translation: Thus ought he to enter upon his career of glory.

quotation: Labitur occulte, fallitque volubilis aetas.
translation: Age glides stealthily on, and beguiles us as it flies.

quotation: Janua lethi Sed patet immani, et vasto respectat hiatu.
translation: But the gate of death yawns with its wide and vast entrance.
notes: "Broad is the way that leadeth to destruction." Matt. vii. 13.

quotation: Januis clausis.
translation: With closed doors.
notes: That is, "in secrecy."

quotation: Labor omnia vincit Improbus.
translation: Incessant labour conquers everything.

quotation: Jasper fert myrrham, thus Melchior, Balthazar aurum. Haec quicum secum portet tria nomina regum, Solvitur a morbo, Domini pietate, caduco.
translation: Jasper brings myrrh, Melchior frankincense, and Balthazar gold. Whoever carries with him the names of these three kings will be exempt, by the goodness of God, from the falling sickness.
notes: A mediaeval charm. These were said to be the names of the kings of the Magi, who were led by the star to the cradle of our Saviour in Bethlehem. They are usually called the Three Kings of Cologne.

quotation: Laborum Dulce levamen.
translation: The sweet soother of my cares.
notes: The words addressed by the poet to his lyre, the solace of his leisure hours.

quotation: Jejunus raro stomachus vulgaria temnit.
translation: A hungry stomach rarely despises plain food.

quotation: Lachrymaeque decorae, Gratior et pulchro veniens in corpore virtus.
translation: His graceful tears, and a merit that still more commends itself in a beauteous person.

quotation: Jovis omnia plena.
translation: All things are full of Jove.
notes: The hand of Providence is visible everywhere.

quotation: Lactuca innatat acri Post vinum stomacho.
translation: Lettuce after wine floats on an acrid stomach.
notes: Words to be borne in mind by the bon vivant.

quotation: Jubeo totas aperire fenestras.
translation: I bid you open all the windows.

quotation: Laetus in praesens animus, quod ultra est Oderit curare, et amara lento Temperet risu. Nihil est ab omni Parte beatum.
translation: The mind that is cheerful at the present hour, will be indifferent ahout anything beyond it, and meet the bitters of life with a complacent smile. Nothing is blessed on every side.

quotation: Libra justa justitiam servat.
translation: A just balance preserves justice.

quotation: Jubilate Deo.
translation: O be joyful in the Lord.
notes: The beginning of the Hundreth Psalm.

quotation: Laetus sorte tua vives sapienter.
translation: If you are wise you will live contented with your lot.

quotation: Liceat concedere veris.
translation: It is only right to yield to truth..

quotation: Jucunda et idonea dicere vitae.
translation: To relate what is agreeable and suited to our conduct in life.
notes: The useful as well as the amusing. See Omne tulit, &c.

quotation: Lapides loquitur, caveant lectores ne cerebrum iis excutiat.
translation: He speaks stones; let his readers take care that he does not knock their brains out.
notes: See Plautus, Aulul. II. i. 29.

quotation: Jucunda est memoria praeteritorum malorum.
translation: The recollection of past evils is pleasant.

quotation: Lapis philosophorum.
translation: The philosopher's stone.
notes: A supposed mineral, sought by the alchemists of the middle ages, the property of which was to transmute the base metals into gold.

quotation: Jucunda rerum vicissitudo.
translation: A delightful change of circumstances.

quotation: Licet superbus ambules pecunia, Fortuna non mutat genus.
translation: Although you may strut about, proud of your money, fortune does not change birth.
notes: Words addressed to a conceited parvenu.

quotation: Lapis qui volvitur algam non generat.
translation: A rolling stone finds no sea-weed.
notes: Or as we say, "A rolling stone gathers no moss." The figure, in the Latin, refers to the stone on the sea-shore, upon which, as it rolls to and fro, the sea-weed does not collect.

quotation: Jucundi acti labores.
translation: The remembrance of difficulties overcome is delightful.

quotation: Licuit, semperque licebit Parcere personis, dicere de vitiis.
translation: It ever has been lawful, and ever will be, to spare the person, but to censure the vice.

quotation: Lapsus calami.
translation: A slip of the pen.

quotation: Jucundum et carum sterilis facit uxor amicum.
translation: A barren wife makes a dear and interesting friend.
notes: To those, namely, who are looking for her husband's money after his decease.

quotation: Lignum vitae.
translation: The wood of life.
notes: Boxwood, or the wood of the guaiacum officinale, is popularly so called.

quotation: Jucundum nihil est, nisi quod reficit varietas.
translation: Nothing is pleasant that is not enlivened with variety.

quotation: Lapsus linguae.
translation: A slip of the tongue.

quotation: Limae labor et mora.
translation: The labour and tediousness of the file.
notes: The wearisome labour of correcting and giving the last polish to a work.

quotation: Judex damnatur cum nocens absolvitur.
translation: The judge is condemned when the guilty is acquitted.
notes: That is, when the sentence is supposed to be dictated by corrupt motives, or to betray incapacity.

quotation: Lascivi soboles gregis.
translation: The descendants of a wanton race.

quotation: Lingua mali loquax malae mentis est indicium.
translation: An evil tongue is the proof of an evil mind.
notes: Because "Out of the abundance of the heart the mouth speaketh." Luke vi. 4, 5.

quotation: Lateat scintillula forsan.
translation: Some small spark may lie perchance concealed.
notes: These words (in reference to the vital spark) have been adopted as the motto of the Humane Society for the recovery of persons apparently drowned.

quotation: Judex non potest esse testis in propria causa.
translation: A judge cannot be a witness in his own cause.

quotation: Lingua mali pars pessima servi.
translation: The tongue is the worst part of a bad servant.
notes: If a servant is unprincipled, the opportunities which he has for slander render his power for evil ten-fold greater.

quotation: Laterem lavas.
translation: You are washing a brick.
notes: This was originally said of unburnt bricks, which the more they were scoured, the more muddy they became. "You are making bad worse."

quotation: Judex non solum quid possit, sed etiam quid deceat ponderare debet.
translation: A judge ought to weigh well not only what he may do, but also what he ought to do.

quotation: Lingua melior, sed frigida bello Dextera.
translation: Excelling in speech, but of a right hand slow to war.
notes: The description given of Drances.

quotation: Lingua, sile; non est ultra narrabile quicquam.
translation: My tongue, be silent; not another word must be said.

quotation: Latet anguis in herba.
translation: A snake lies hidden in the grass.
notes: Individuals, like armies, suffer most from perils that lie in ambush.

quotation: Linguae centum sunt, oraque centum, Ferrea vox.
translation: It has a hundred tongues, a hundred mouths, a voice of iron.
notes: The attributes of rumour.

quotation: Latius regnes, avidum domando Spiritum, quam si Libyam remotis Gadibus jungas, et uterque Poenus Serviat uni.
translation: You may possess a more extensive dominion by controlling a craving disposition, than if you could unite Libya to the distant Gades, and the natives of either Carthage were subject to you alone.

quotation: Linguae prorsus non nego Habere atque agere maximas me gratias Verum oculis ut priveris opto perfidis.
translation: I do not deny that to your tongue I owe most sincere thanks, and I return them; but I wish you may be deprived of your perfidious eyes.
notes: Said to one who, though he may hold his tongue, still acts the traitor by his significant looks.

quotation: Latrant me, lateo ac taceo.
translation: They bark at me, but I lie hid, and hold my tongue.

quotation: Linguam alicujus futilem ac ventosam retundere.
translation: To silence the babbling empty tongue of a person.

quotation: Latrante uno, latrat statim et alter canis.
translation: When one dog barks, another at once barks too.

quotation: Linguam compescere, virtus non minima est.
translation: To restrain the tongue is not the least of virtues.

quotation: Linquenda tellus, et domus, et placens Uxor, neque harum, quas colis, arborum, Te, praeter invisas cupressos, Ulla brevem dominum sequetur.
translation: Your estate, your house, and your pleasing wife must be left, nor shall any of these trees which you are tending follow you, their owner for a brief space, except the hated cypresses.
notes: The cypress was planted near the graves of the dead.

quotation: Latrantem curatne alta Diana canem?
translation: Does Diana on high care for the dog that bays her?

quotation: Lis litem generat.
translation: Strife begets strife.

quotation: Laudari a laudato viro.
translation: To be praised by a man who deserves praise.

quotation: Litem paret lis, noxa item noxam parit.
translation: Dispute begets dispute, and injury begets injury.

quotation: Laudat venales qui vult extrudere merces.
translation: He praises the wares he has to sell who wishes to push them off upon others.

quotation: Litera canina.
translation: The canine letter.
notes: The letter R is so called, as it seems to be pronounced by a dog when he snarls, " Grr, Grrr," as Rabelais says.

quotation: Laudato ingentia rura, Exiguum colito.
translation: Commend large estates, but cultivate a small one.
notes: You will both avoid giving offence to others, and will insure your own happiness and peace of mind.

quotation: Litera scripta manet.
translation: The written letter remains.
notes: Words may escape our memory, but that which is written remains established as proof of the intention of the writer. Probably a portion of a mediaeval pentameter.

quotation: Laudator temporis acti.
translation: A praiser of times past.
notes: An old man, who, like Nestor in the Iliad, is always praising the men and manners of former times. A weakness both amiable and natural. See Aetas parentum, &c.

quotation: Literae Bellerophontis.
translation: Letters of Bellerophon.
notes: Proetus, king of Argos, suspecting that Bellerophon had attempted to corrupt the chastity of his wife, sent him to the king of Syria with a sealed letter directing him to put the bearer to death. Hence letters which are dangerous to the bearer are called Literae Bellerophontis.

quotation: Laudatur ab his, culpatur ab illis.
translation: He is praised by these, censured by those.

quotation: Literae humaniores.
translation: Polite literature.
notes: Or "arts," in University parlance.

quotation: Laudibus arguitur vini vinosus.
translation: The drunkard is convicted by his praises of wine.

quotation: Littus ama, altum alii teneant.
translation: Hug the shore, let others stand out into the deep.
notes: Figuratively applied, these words warn us not to launch out into hazardous enterprises, but to consult the dictates of prudence.

quotation: Laudis amore tumes? sunt certa piacula quae te Ter pure lecto, poterunt recreare, libello.
translation: Do you swell with the love of praise? There are [in philosophy] certain purgations which can restore you, a certain treatise being thrice perused with purity of mind.

quotation: Lividi limis oculis semper aspiciunt aliorum commoda.
translation: Envious men always view with jealousy the prosperity of others.

quotation: Judicandum est legibus, non exemplis.
translation: We must judge according to law, not by precedent.

quotation: Laudo Deum verum, plebem voco, congrego clerum, Defunctos ploro, pestem fugo, festa decoro.
translation: I praise the true God, I summon the people, I assemble the clergy, I mourn the dead, I put to flight the plague, I celebrate festivals.
notes: Inscription on a church bell. See Funera, &c.

quotation: Loc. cit.
translation: In the place quoted.
notes: For Loco citato.

quotation: Judice te mercede caret, per seque petenda est Externis virtus incomitata bonis.
translation: In thy judgment, virtue needs no reward, and is to be sought for her own sake, unaccompanied by external benefits.

quotation: Laudo, malum cum amici tuum ducis malum.
translation: I commend you for considering the affliction of your friend your own affliction.

quotation: Locum tenens.
translation: Holding his place.
notes: Meaning, a person acting for, or holding the office of, another. A substitute or deputy, or, more strictly speaking, a lieutenant.

quotation: Judices qui ex lege judicatis, legibus obtemperare debetis.
translation: You judges who judge according to the law, ought to be obedient to the law.

quotation: Laureum baculum gesto.
translation: I carry a sprig of laurel.
notes: I am proof against all dangers. The laurel was thought by the ancients to be an antidote against poison, and to afford security against lightning.

quotation: Locus est et pluribus umbris.
translation: There is room enough for more to introduce their friends.
notes: The "umbra," or "shadow," was a guest's friend, allowed by the Roman custom to accompany him at banquets and entertainments.

quotation: Judicia Dei sunt ita recondita ut quis illa scrutari nullatenus possit.
translation: The decrees of God are so impenetrable, that no one can possibly scrutinize them.
notes: The ways of Heaven are unsearchable. See Job v. 9; Rom. ii. 33.

quotation: Locus in quo.
translation: The place in which.
notes: Meaning, the place or position which was previously occupied.

quotation: Judicio acri perpendere.
translation: To weigh with keen discernment.

quotation: Locus sigilli.
translation: The place for the seal.
notes: Which is pointed out in copies of deeds or sealed documents by the letters L. S.

quotation: Judicis est innocentiae subvenire.
translation: It is the duty of the judge to succour innocence.

quotation: Locus standi.
translation: A place for standing.
notes: A position assumed in argument.

quotation: Judicis officium est, ut res, ita tempora rerum Quaerere.
translation: It is the duty of a judge, to consider not only the facts, but the circumstances of the case.

quotation: Longa est injuria, longae Ambages.
translation: Lengthened is the story of my wrongs, tedious the detail.

quotation: Judicium Dei.
translation: The judgment of God.
notes: The name by which the ordeal by fire or water was called in the middle ages, because it was supposed that God would by his intervention manifest the guilt or innocence of the party tried.

quotation: Longa mora est, quantum noxae sit ubique repertum Enumerare: minor fuit ipsa infamia vero.
translation: It were an endless task to enumerate how great an amount of guilt everywhere prevailed; even the report itself was below the truth.
notes: The words of Jupiter when he found it necessary to destroy mankind by the deluge.

quotation: Judicium parium aut leges terrae.
translation: The judgment of our peers, or the laws of the land.
notes: By these only can an Englishman be condemned. Words from the Magna Charta, selected as his motto by that eminent judge, Lord Camden. The nobles are judged by the nobles, the commons by the commons, each by their peers.

quotation: Longa via est, nec tempora longa supersunt, Dixit; et hospitibus janua nostra patet.
translation: 'Long is the road,' said he, 'and little of the day remains; my door too is ever open to the stranger.'

quotation: Judicium subtile videndis artibus.
translation: An acute discernment in understanding the arts.

quotation: Longe aberrat scopo.
translation: He is wide of the mark.
notes: He has wandered far from his sphere.

quotation: Jugulare mortuos.
translation: To stab the dead.
notes: To be guilty not only of needless cruelty, but also of cowardice.

quotation: Longe absit.
translation: Far be it from me.
notes: Or as we say, "God forbid."

quotation: Juncta juvant.
translation: United, they assist.
notes: Said of things trifling in themselves, but which, put together, acquire strength.

quotation: Longe mea discrepat istis Et vox et ratio.
translation: Both my language and my sentiments differ widely from theirs.

quotation: Jungere dextras.
translation: To join right hands.
notes: Or, as we say, "to shake hands."

quotation: Longum iter est per praecepta, breve et efficax per exempla.
translation: The road by precept is long; by example, short and effectual.

quotation: Jungere equos Titan velocibus imperat Horis.
translation: Titan commands the swift-flying Hours to yoke the horses.
notes: The poet speaks of the Hours, which were personified under the names of Eunomia, Dice, Irene, Carpo, and Thallo, as harnessing the horses of the sun.

quotation: Jupiter est quodcunque vides, quocunque moveris.
translation: Where'er you turn your eyes, where'er you move, 'tis God you see.
notes: The doctrine of Pantheism.

quotation: Laus Deo.
translation: Praise be to God.

quotation: Jupiter in multos temeraria fulmina torquet, Qui poenam culpa non meruere pati.
translation: Jupiter hurls his lightnings at random against many who have not deserved punishment for any commensurate fault.

quotation: Laus in proprio ore sordescit.
translation: A man's own praise of himself is unseemly.
notes: Self-praise is no recommendation.

quotation: Leberide caecior.
translation: Blinder than a serpent's slough.
notes: Which has holes only instead of eyes.

quotation: Loquendum ut vulgus, sentiendum ut docti.
translation: We should speak with the populace, think with the learned.

quotation: Lege totum si vis scire totum.
translation: Read the whole if you wish to know the whole.
notes: It is not easy to judge of a book on one connected subject, by reading a bit here and there.

quotation: Lotis manibus.
translation: With clean hands.

quotation: Legem brevem esse oportet quo facilius ab imperitis teneatur.
translation: A law ought to be short that it may be the more easily understood by the unlearned.

quotation: Lubrica nascentes implent conchylia lunae.
translation: The increasing moon plumps up the slippery oyster.
notes: A dictum to be remembered by the epicure.

quotation: Leges a victoribus dicuntur, accipiuntur a victis.
translation: Conditions are made by the conquerors, accepted by the conquered.

quotation: Lubrica statio et proximo praecipitio.
translation: A slippery spot, and on the edge of a precipice.

quotation: Leges ad civium salutem, civitatumque incolumitatem conditae sunt.
translation: Laws were made for the safety of citizens, and the security of states.

quotation: Lubrici sunt fortunae gressus.
translation: The footsteps of fortune are slippery.

quotation: Leges mori serviunt.
translation: The laws are subservient to usage.

quotation: Lubricum linguae non facile in poenam est trahendum.
translation: A slip of the tongue ought not to be punished without due consideration.

quotation: Jupiter tonans.
translation: The thunderer Jove.
notes: "The Jupiter tonans of debate," i.e. a "great gun" in argument.

quotation: Leges sunt invented quae cum omnibus semper una atque eadem voce loquerentur.
translation: Laws are so made that they may always speak with one and the same voice to all.
notes: Good laws are no respecters of persons.

quotation: Lucem redde tuae, dux bone, patriae; Instar veris enim vultus ubi tuus Affulsit populo, gratior et dies, Et soles melius nitent.
translation: Restore, O excellent prince, light to thy country; for, like the spring, wherever thy countenance has shone, the day passes more agreeably for the people, and the sun has a superior lustre.
notes: An eulogium, addressed by the poet to the emperor Augustus, during his absence from Rome.

quotation: Jura negat sibi nata, nihil non arrogat armis.
translation: He denies that laws were framed against him; he arrogates everything to himself by force of arms.
notes: The acts of a tyrant or usurper.

quotation: Lucet, eamus Quo ducit gula.
translation: It is day, let us go whither appetite leads us.

quotation: Juratores sunt judices facti.
translation: The jurors are the judges of the facts.

quotation: Juravi lingua, mentem injuratam gero.
translation: I have sworn with my tongue, but I have a mind unsworn.
notes: I feel no constraint to perform my oath. The words of a man from whom an oath has been extorted by unlawful means and under duress, or the mental reservation of a subtle casuist.

quotation: Jure divino.
translation: By Divine law.
notes: Meaning, "by the will of Heaven," irrespective of the will of the people. The sovereigns of the line of the Stuarts were the last monarchs of Great Britain who claimed to govern by this title.

quotation: Jure humano.
translation: By human law.
notes: By laws made and upheld by men. The present emperor of France professes to reign jure humano, "by the will of the people."

quotation: Jure repraesentationis.
translation: By right of representation.
notes: As representing another party.

quotation: Legis constructio non facit injuriam.
translation: The construction of the law does injury to no man.
notes: For instance, it will not suppose a man to grant away that which right fully belongs to another.

quotation: Jurgia praecipue vino stimulata caveto.
translation: Especially avoid quarrels excited by wine.

quotation: Legitima fraudatur litera voce; Blaesaque fit jusso lingua coacta sono.
translation: The letters are deprived of their full sound, and the lisping tongue is contracted with an affected pronunciation.

quotation: Legum ministri magistratus, legum interpretes judices; legum aenique idcirco omnes servi sumus, ut liberi esse possimus.
translation: The magistrates are the ministers of the law, the judges the interpreters of the laws; we all, in fine, are the servants of the law, that we may be free.

quotation: Lenior et melior fis, accedente senecta?
translation: Do you become milder and better, as old age approaches?

quotation: Leniter ex merito quidquid patiare ferendum est, Quae venit indigne poena dolenda venit.
translation: Whatever you suffer deservedly should be borne with patience; the penalty that comes upon us undeservedly comes as a ground for complaint.
notes: The poet thus consoles himself, upon his banishment to Thrace without having deserved it.

quotation: Jus aliquod faciunt affinia vincula nobis.
translation: The links of connexion form a certain tie between us.

quotation: Lentiscum mandere.
translation: To chew mastich.
notes: Said of people over-nice about their personal appearance. Gum mastich is a whitener of the teeth, and a preserver of the gums.

quotation: Leonem larva terres.
translation: You are for frightening a lion with a mask.

quotation: Lucidus ordo.
translation: Perspicuous arrangement.
notes: Method.

quotation: Leonina societas.
translation: A lion's society.
notes: A partnership where one individual engrosses the whole power and authority. See the Fable of the Lion in Partnership, in Phaedrus, b. i. f. 1.

quotation: Jus civile.
translation: The civil law.
notes: i.e. the Roman law, which, to a certain extent, is still used in our ecclesiastical courts.

quotation: Lucri bonus est odor ex re Qualibet.
translation: The smell of gain is good, come from what it may.
notes: Vespasian made this reply to his son Titus, when he expostulated with him upon his imposing a tax upon urine.

quotation: Jus civile neque inflecti gratia, neque perfringi potentia, neque adulterari pecunia debet.
translation: The law of the land ought neither to be warped by favour, nor broken through by power, nor corrupted by money.

quotation: Jus divinum.
translation: Divine right.

quotation: Leonini versus.
translation: Leonine verses.
notes: These consist of Latin hexameters, or hexameters and pentameters, in rhyme. There are various kinds; but the most common is that in which the caesura in the fifth syllable rhymes with the end of the line, thus: En rex Edvardus debacchans ut leopardus. ("Lo! king Edward, raging like a leopard.") Other metres are however used in the Leonine hymns of the Roman Catholic Church. The name is said to have been derived from Leoninus, a monk of the twelfth century. He may very possibly have revived the use of these rhymes; but we find them composed as far back as the third century.

quotation: Jus gentium.
translation: The law of nations.
notes: Laws formed on strict principles of universal justice, and acknowledged by all nations of the civilized world as the basis of their international relations.

quotation: Lucrum amare nullum amatorem decet.
translation: No lover ought to be in love with pelf.

quotation: Jus postlimini.
translation: The law of recovery.
notes: A Roman law which restored certain rights and privileges to one who had lost them was thus called.

quotation: Lucrum malum aequale dispendio.
translation: An evil gain is equal to a loss.
notes: What is ill-gotten rarely thrives.

quotation: Jus primogenitures.
translation: The right of eldership.

quotation: Leonum ora a magistris impune tractantur.
translation: The mouths of lions are handled with impunity by their keepers.
notes: That which is dangerous to one man may be done in safety by another.

quotation: Jus proprietatis.
translation: The right of property.

quotation: Jus regium.
translation: Royal right.

quotation: Lepidi mores turpem ornatum facile factis comprobant.
translation: Good morals have no difficulty in setting off a lowly garb.

quotation: Jus sanguinis quod in legitimis successionibus spectatur, ipso nativitatis tempore quaesitum est.
translation: The right of consanguinity, which is regarded in successions by law, is established at the very moment of our birth.

quotation: Leporis vitam vivit.
translation: He lives the life of a hare.
notes: He is always full of fears and anxiety.

quotation: Luctantem Icariis fluctibus Africum Mercator metuens, otium et oppidi Laudat rura sui: mox reficit rates Quassas, indocilis pauperiem pati.
translation: The merchant, dreading the south-west wind contending with the Icarian waves, commends the tranquillity and the rural retirement of the country-town; but soon, incapable of being taught to endure poverty, he refits his shattered bark.

quotation: Lepos et festivitas orationis.
translation: The pleasantry and playfulness of his conversation.

quotation: Luctantes ventos tempestatesque sonoras Imperio premit.
translation: He represses by his control the struggling winds, and the resounding tempests.
notes: Said in allusion to the sway of Aeolus, the god of the winds.

quotation: Leve fit quod bene fertur onus.
translation: The load becomes light which is borne with cheerfulness.

quotation: Lucus a non lucendo.
notes: That is, Lucus, "a grove," is derived, by antiphrasis, from non lucere, "not to admit light," because, as the grammarians said, it does not allow the light of the sun to shine through it. This derivation is found in Servius on Aeneid I., Charisius, and Diomedes. Quintilian (i. 6) also notices it, but merely to ask whether such derivations from contraries can possibly be received by reasonable people; some critics having also imagined that ludus, "a school," was so called a non ludendo, because no play was allowed in it, and that Pluto was called Ditis, "rich," because he was minime dives, "not at all rich." Vossius condemns the derivation of lucus from luceo as a mere fancy of the grammarians, and alludes to another given by Isidore, xiv. 8, a collucendo crebris luminibus religionis causa, "from the number of lamps or torches that were often lighted in the sacred groves," lucus being properly a grove consecrated to some deity, though often used in a general sense. But Vossius prefers on the whole to derive it from λόχος, " an ambush." Others would have it for lugus from λύγη, " darkness." The real etymology is quite uncertain. Servius, who favours the derivation from luceo, adduces, in support of it, another imagination of the grammarians, bellum, "war," a nulla re bella, because it has nothing pleasing in it; and Varro, de L. L., book v., rather inclines to think that coelum, "heaven," may be derived a celando, from "to conceal," quia apertum est, "because it is open." Lucus a non lucendo has become proverbial in ridicule of absurd or far-fetched etymologies. See Non sequitur, and Obscurum per obscurius.

quotation: Jus summum saepe summa malitia est.
translation: Extreme law is often extreme wrong.
notes: See Summum jus, &c.

quotation: Leves homines futuri sunt improvidi.
translation: Light-minded men are careless of the future.

quotation: Ludere cum sacris.
translation: To play with holy things.
notes: To jest on sacred subjects.

quotation: Levia perpessi sunius, si flenda patimur.
translation: We have had to suffer but trifles if our sufferings are merely such as we should weep for.
notes: Real misfortunes require something more than tears as their remedy.

quotation: Ludit in humanis Divina potentia rebus; Et certam praesens vix habet hora fidem.
translation: The Divine power finds sport in the affairs of men, and the present moment hardly carries positive assurance.

quotation: Leviora sunt injuria, quae repentino aliquo motu accidunt, quam ea quae meditate praeparata inferuntur.
translation: The injuries which befall us unexpectedly are less severe than those which we are deliberately anticipating.

quotation: Justae causae facilis est defensio.
translation: It is easy to defend a just cause.

quotation: Ludus animo debet aliquando dari, Ad cogitandum melior ut redeat tibi.
translation: Recreation ought sometimes to be given to the mind, that it may return to you better fitted for thought.

quotation: Levis est dolor qui capere consilium potest.
translation: That grief is but light which can take counsel.

quotation: Lugete Veneres Cupidinesque.
translation: Mourn, ye Venuses and Cupids.
notes: These words, used by the poet in commemorating the death of Lesbia's favourite sparrow, are sometimes employed ironically.

quotation: Levius solet timere qui propius timet.
translation: A man's fears are diminished when the danger is near at hand.
notes: Dangers appears less formidable when looked in the face.

quotation: Lex appetit perfectum.
translation: The law aims at perfection.

quotation: Lex citius tolerare vult privatum damnum quam publicum malum.
translation: The law will sooner tolerate a private loss than a public evil.

quotation: Lex est, quae in Graecorum conviviis obtinetur, aut bibat aut abeat. Et recte. Aut enim fruatur aliquis, pariter cum aliis, voluptate potandi; ut ne sobrius in violentiam vinolentorum incidat ante discedat.
translation: At the banquets of the Greeks a custom prevails, that every man shall either drink or begone: and with good reason: for every man should enjoy, equally with the rest, the pleasure of drinking; lest he, being sober, should witness any violence of conduct, before he departs, on the part of those who are overtaken with wine.

quotation: Justissimus unus Et servantissimus aequi.
translation: Most just and most observant of what is right.
notes: The character of Ripheus.

quotation: Lex neminem cogit ad impossibilia.
translation: The law compels no man to do impossibilities.
notes: If a man under a penalty in a bond undertakes to do a physical impossibility, the law will not allow the penalty to be recovered.

quotation: Justitia erga Deum religio dicitur; erga parentes pietas.
translation: Fulfilment of our duty towards God is called religion; towards our parents, piety.

quotation: Lex nemini operator iniquum; nemini facit injuriam.
translation: The law works injustice to no man, does injury to none.

quotation: Justitia est obtemperatio scriptis legibus.
translation: Justice is obedience to the written law.

quotation: Justitia nihil expetit praemii.
translation: Justice seeks no reward.

quotation: Lex non scripta.
translation: The unwritten law.
notes:
The common law of England, which originated in custom prior to the time of Richard I., and has never been committed to writing. 
The eldest son inherits realty to the exclusion of the younger children under the Lex non scripta.

quotation: Justitia non novit patrem nec matrem, solum veritatem spectat.
translation: Justice knows neither father nor mother; it looks at truth alone.

quotation: Justitia tanta vis est, ut ne illi quidem, qui maleficio et scelere pascuntur, possint sine ulla particula justitiae vivere.
translation: There is so vast a power in justice, that those even who live by crime and wickedness, cannot live without some small portion of justice among them.
notes: Hence the proverb which says that "There is honour among thieves."

quotation: Justitiae partes sunt, non violare homines, verecundiae non offendere.
translation: It is the duty of justice to do injury to no man; of propriety, to offend none.

quotation: Lex prospicit non respicit.
translation: The law is prospective, not retrospective.

quotation: Justum bellum quibus necessarium, et pia arma quibus nulla nisi in armis relinquitur spes.
translation: War is just to those to whom it is necessary; and an appeal to arms is a sacred duty with those who have no hope left except in arms.

quotation: Lex scripta.
translation: "The written" or "statute law."

quotation: Lex talionis.
translation: "The law of retaliation," or "of requital."
notes: "An eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth." This is the law of revenge, not of justice, and not unlike what the Americans call "Lynch Law."

quotation: Lex terrae.
translation: The law of the land.
notes: A term used in contradistinction to the "civil law."

quotation: Lex universa est quae jubet nasci et mori.
translation: There is one universal law which commands that we shall be born and shall die.

quotation: Libera te metu mortis.
translation: Deliver thyself from the fear of death.
notes: By doing your best to insure the reward of a good life.

quotation: Liberi parentes alant, aut vinciantur.
translation: Let children support their parents, or be imprisoned.
notes: A Roman law.

quotation: Liberius quam ut imperantium meminissent.
translation: Too freely to remember their own rulers.

quotation: Libertas est potestas faciendi id quod jure licet.
translation: Liberty is the power of doing that which the law permits.
notes: The proper estimate of real liberty.

quotation: Libertas, quae sera, tamen respexit inertem.
translation: Liberty which, though late, looked back upon me in my helpless state.

quotation: Libertas ultima mundi Quo steterit ferienda loco.
translation: In the spot where liberty has made her last stand must she be smitten.
notes: A sentiment attributed by Lucan to Julius Caesar.

quotation: Libidinosa et intemperans adolescentia effoetum corpus tradit senectuti.
translation: A youth of sensuality and intemperance transmits to old age a worn-out body.

quotation: Lumen soli mutuum das.
translation: You are lending light to the sun.
notes: Said of persons who affect to explain what is perfectly clear and intelligible, or, as Young says of commentators,"Hold their farthing candle to the sun."

quotation: Lupus in fabula.
translation: The wolf in the fable.
notes: Alluding to the accidental arrival of the person who happens at that moment to be the subject of conversation. Like the wolf of ancient fable, which was said to have that power, his appearance deprives the speakers of their voice, or, in other words, puts a stop to their conversation. See Edere non poteris, &c.

quotation: Libido effrenata effrenatam appetentiam efficit.
translation: Unbridled gratification produces unbridled desire.
notes: See Sic quibus, &c.

quotation: Lupus pilum mutat, non mentem.
translation: The wolf changes his hair, but not his nature.
notes: See Naturam expellas, &c.

quotation: Lusisti satis, edisti satis, atque bibisti. Tempus abire tibi est.
translation: Thou hast trifled enough, hast eaten and drunk enough, 'tis time for thee to depart.
notes: Words addressed to an aged sensualist, on the verge of the grave.

quotation: Lusit amabiliter, donec jam saevus apertam In rabiem verti coepit jocus.
translation: This raillery sported on pleasantly enough, till at length, becoming bitter, it began to turn into virulence.

quotation: Lusus naturae.
translation: A freak of nature.
notes: A deformed or unnatural production is so called.

quotation: Lutum nisi tundatur, non fit urceus.
translation: Unless the clay be well pounded, no pitcher can be made.
notes: Nothing of value can be produced without industry.

quotation: Luxum populi expiare solent bella.
translation: The luxury of a people is usually expiated by war.
notes: Luxury and dissipation produce disorder, the fruitful parent of turbulence and war.

quotation: Luxuriae desunt multa, avaritiae omnia.
translation: Luxury is in want of many things; avarice, of everything.

quotation: Ex nihilo nihil fit.
translation: From nothing nothing is made.
notes: Nothing can come of nothing.

quotation: Ex officio.
translation: By virtue of his office.

quotation: Luxuriant animi rebus plerumque secundis; Nec facile est aequa commoda mente pati.
translation: The feelings often run riot amid prosperity; and to bear good fortune with evenness of mind is no easy task.

quotation: Ex otio plus negotii quam ex negotio habemus.
translation: From our leisure we get more to do, than from our business.
notes: Especially when it gives us the opportunity of falling into mischief.

quotation: Ex parte.
translation: On one part.
notes: Evidence given on one side only is called ex parte.

quotation: Ex pede Herculem.
translation: You may judge of Hercules from his foot.
notes: Pythagoras ascertained the length of the foot of Hercules by taking the length of the Olympic stadium or course, which was six hundred feet, originally measured by the foot of the hero. He thence came to the conclusion that his height was six feet seven inches. From this circumstance was formed the proverb, meaning

quotation: Ex post facto.
translation: Done after another thing.
notes: A law enacted purposely to take cognizance of an offence already committed, is, so far as that individual offence is concerned, an ex post facto law.

quotation: Ex quovis ligno non fit Mercurius.
translation: A Mercury is not to be made out of every log.
notes: Mercury being a graceful god, it was not out of every piece of wood that his statue could be made.

quotation: Ex tempore.
translation: Off-hand.
notes: On the spur of the moment, or, without preparation.

quotation: Ex umbra in solem.
translation: Out of the shade into the sunshine.
notes: You have rendered clear what was obscure before.

quotation: Ex ungue leonem.
translation: You can tell the lion by his claw.
notes: The master's hand may be known in the specimen.

quotation: Ex uno disce omnes.
translation: From one learn all.
notes: From one example you may judge of all. What has been said of one may be said of the rest. See Crimine ab uno, &c.

quotation: Ex uno specta omnia.
translation: From one circumstance judge of all.

quotation: Ex vita, discedo, tanquam ex hospitio, non tanquam ex domo.
translation: I depart from life as from an inn, not as from my home.
notes: I die without regret, just as one quits an inn, where he has been a sojourner for a time only.

quotation: Ex vitio alterius sapiens emendat suum.
translation: From the faults of another a wise man corrects his own.

quotation: Ex vitulo bos fit.
translation: The calf becomes an ox.
notes: Small things enlarge to great.

quotation: Ex vultibus hominum mores colligere.
translation: To judge of men's manners from their countenance.

quotation: Exceptio probat regulam.
translation: The exception proves the rule.
notes: The fact of there being an exception proves the existence of a rule.

quotation: Excepto quod non simul esses, caetera laetus.
translation: Except that you were not with me, I was in other respects happy.

quotation: Excessit ex ephebis.
translation: He is out of his minority.
notes: He is of age, and has come to years of discretion.

quotation: Excludat jurgia finis.
translation: Let this settlement terminate all disputes.

quotation: Excusatio non petita fit accusatio manifesta.
translation: An excuse that is uncalled for is a convincing proof of guilt.

quotation: Exeat.
translation: Let him depart.
notes: The leave given for temporary absence from college is so called.

quotation: Exeat aula Qui vult esse pius.
translation: Let him withdraw from court, who wishes to remain uncorrupted.

quotation: Exegi monumentum aere perennius.
translation: I have completed a monument more durable than brass.
notes: The prophecy of a poet, who formed a just estimate of his works.

quotation: Exempli gratia.
translation: For example.
notes: For instance. Usually written e.g.

quotation: Exemplo plus quam ratione vivimus.
translation: We live more by example than by reason.
notes: On this is based the tyranny of fashion.

quotation: Exemplo quodcunqne malo committitur ipsi Displicet auctori; prima est haec ultio, quod, se Judice, nemo nocens absolvitor.
translation: Every deed that will furnish a precedent for crime, must be condemned by the author himself. This is his first punishment, that, being his own judge, no guilty man is acquitted.

quotation: Exempta juvat spinis e pluribus una.
translation: A single thorn extracted out of many, is a point gained.
notes: As the passage stands in the original, the poet puts the question, "Of what use is it to have one thorn plucked out when you are smarting from many?"

quotation: Exercent illi sociae commercia linguae: Per gestum res est significanda mihi.
translation: They enjoy the intercourse of a common language: by me everything has to be signified by gestures.

quotation: Exercitatio optimus est magister.
translation: Practice is the best master.

quotation: Exercitatio potest omnia.
translation: Continued practice can accomplish everything.
notes: Practice makes perfect.

quotation: Exeunt omnes.
translation: All depart.
notes: A stage direction.

quotation: Exi, Intonat horrendum.
translation: Begone! she thunders out with awful voice.

quotation: Exigit et a statuis farinas.
translation: He exacts meal from a statue even.
notes: He can make something out of everything, and can "get blood out of a stone."
